A band of thunderstorms with torrential downpours moved slowly east. The heaviest rainfall, estimated by radar to be one to two inches per hour, extended from West Frankfort to Harrisburg. Flooding of some flood-prone, low-lying roads was reported in Saline County.

Water was reported over several roads in the Murray area, with around 4 inches of water flowing across Highway 121. Thunderstorms  moved through Calloway and southern Marshall Counties, producing up to 1.5 inches in an hour. A spotter reported 2 inches of rain in Hardin during the storm. Amounts near Murray ranged from less than an inch on the south side of the city to 1.5 inches about 4 miles north of Murray.

After a short break in the heat in which temperatures dropped into the middle 80's to around 90 degrees, the heat returned to the area. High temperatures were back in the middle 90s to around 100 with head indices ranging from 105 to 110 degrees. Columbia had two straight days of a high of 101 degrees, on the 25th and 26th. St. Louis hit 101 degrees on the 26th. Many area schools again reduced their schedules to a half day or closed until the heat subsided.

Severe thunderstorms rolled south across areas of south-central Nebraska along and east of U.S. Highway 281.  Initially, thunderstorms northeast of Grand Island spawned several funnels and at least one tornado.  The tornado was sighted about 10 miles west of Fullerton along Highway 22 but no damage was reported.  As the thunderstorms continued to march south, numerous wind and hail reports were noted.  A semi-tractor was blown over on Interstate 80 in western Hamilton county.  The driver was uninjured.  Hail ranging from the size of pennies to golf balls was a common occurrence.  Some of the larger hail reports were near Chapman and Ayr.  While wind damage was mostly in terms of fallen trees on buildings or snapped power poles, the nursing home in Blue Hill did sustain major roof damage.  The front roof facade was ripped off by the wind and left the front dining and living areas exposed to the elements.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Very heavy rainfall flooded many roads including South Main Street, Bacon Road, and Easy Street.  Several vehicles were trapped in the water and a house was flooded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm during the afternoon of the 19th produced damaging winds.Thunderstoorm winds downed trees 1 mile south of Stuart, in the town of Ferrum, 4 miles west of Stewartsville, and Indian Valley.

Lightning was the probable cause of this wildfire which became known as the JB Fire. The fire occurred on Bureau of Land Management public lands and consumed 1,007 acres of ponderosa pine, sage, oak brush, and grass. Five residences and four commercial properties were threatened by the fire.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High temperatures reached the middle to upper 90s during the afternoon hours of August 21st.  Heat indices ranged from 105 to 110 degrees.  Northerly Island and Midway Airport reached 97 degrees while Ohare Airport reached 95 degrees.  Temperatures were also in the middle 90s across much of the rest of Northern Illinois.  No fatalities were reported from the heat.

High temperatures reached the lower to middle 90s on August 25th and 26th with heat indices in the middle to upper 90s.  One person died of a heat stroke in Skokie and another person died of heat stress in Chicago.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lightning was the probable cause of this wildfire which occurred in the San Juan National Forest. The fire became known as the Devil Creek Fire and consumed 235 acres of mixed conifer forest and oak brush. The estimated cost of fighting the fire was 294 thousand dollars.

This wildfire was likely caused by lightning and became known as the Hamilton Fire. The fire occurred on Bureau of Land Management public lands and consumed 2,064 acres of pinyon pine and juniper. The fire threatened 3 residences. The estimated cost of fighting the fire was 290 thousand dollars.

A strong cold front moved through the region early on the 13th, leaving behind frigid temperatures and strong winds. Widespread damage due to downed trees and power lines resulted. In Northern Virginia at least two people were injured. In Loudoun county, a student in Sterling was  hit by a falling tree while waiting for the school bus, and a Leesburg man was struck by a large falling tree limb. A tractor trailer truck was overturned on Highway 81 in Shenandoah county.  The driver was not injured. A poultry house was completely destroyed in Harrisonburg, and a bill board was blown down at the Winchester Regional Airport. At the height of the storm about 150,000 homes and business in Northern Virginia were without power.

Extreme drought conditions persisted across eastern Utah with an area of exceptional drought in southeast Utah. Although monsoon moisture resulted in thunderstorms and scattered precipitation, rainfall was generally light across the area. Additionally, temperatures were well above normal across the region. See the August 2003 Storm Data publication for a continuation of this drought situation.

Two homes struck. In the first, and more serious case, part of the home was set ablaze, with fire apparently spreading from the basement, up thru a laundry chute, then into the walls and attic of the home. The roof was also damaged, with most damage occurring toward the back of the home. Approximately six hours were required to extinguish the fire.In the second case, wiring was struck, igniting a small fire. Damage estimate: $100. Independence Daily contributed greatly to this narrative.
The hail fell at Balsam Lake.
The wind lasted one minute.
Tops of trees were snapped off.
The hail fell at Sea Gull Lake.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved through the region early on the 13th, leaving frigid temperatures and strong winds. Widespread damage due to downed trees and power lines resulted. In Prince Georges County, one fatality was reported in Hyattsville when a wall at a construction site collapsed and pinned a worker underneath it. A second wall collapsed in Bowie at a department store. The strong winds also overturned an empty trailer truck in Anne Arundel County. The driver had minor injuries. Another truck was also overturned in Frederick County on US Highway 15. A large recreational/housing tent (26,000 sq ft) was destroyed at Fort Meade. The tent was valued at 150,00 dollars. Later a crane was blown off the Woodrow Wilson Bridge and onto a barge in the Potomac River. No injuries were reported from the crane incident and the damage was superficial. At the height of the storm about 150,000 homes and business in Maryland were without power.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quarter size hail was observed near West Independence.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement officials, storm spotters and the general public reported hail ranging in size from dimes to as large as half dollars.
Law enforcement officials, storm spotters and the general public reported hail ranging in size from dimes to as large as half dollars.
Law enforcement officials, storm spotters and the general public reported hail ranging in size from dimes to as large as half dollars.
A cooperative weather observer reported large tree limbs were blown down as winds gusted to near 60 mph.

Thunderstorms on the afternoon of the 6th produced damaging winds, flash flooding, and hail up to nickel size.Thunderstorm winds downed numerous trees in Patrick Springs.  Trees were also downed 3 miles south of Rocky Mount, in Madison Heights, onto Route 56, 11 miles northwest of Buckingham, across southeast Buckingham county and onto Route 20 in Dillwyn.  Thunderstorm winds also downed trees 1 miles west of Buckingham onto Route 60.Heavy thunderstorm rains caused flash flooding in Tazewell with numerous roads flooded and closed. Several homes had flooded basements.  Flash flooding also occured across the western portion of the county with numerous roads flooded and closed. Flash flooding of Whitley Creek, 2 miles east of Staffordsville, washed two cars off of Route 730.Heavy thunderstorm rains caused a large mudslide across Route 601, 5 miles southeast of Bland, and caused a stream to flood across a road 5 miles southeast of Rural Retreat. Another thunderstorm produced 5 inches of rain in 90 minutes, causing flash flooding, washing out portions of Route 609 near Alleghany Springs.

This wildfire occurred in the White River National Forest and was named the Langlas Draw Fire. The fire threatened 15 residences and consumed 720 acres of ponderosa pine, aspen, and oak brush by the end of July. See the August 2003 Storm Data publication for a continuation on this wildfire.

Lightning was the probable cause of this wildfire which became known as the Red Rock Fire. The fire occurred on Bureau of Land Management public lands and threatened one residence and one commercial property. The fire consumed 134 acres of pinyon pine and  juniper forest.

Extreme drought conditions persisted across eastern Utah with an area of exceptional drought in southeast Utah. Although monsoon moisture resulted in thunderstorms and scattered precipitation, rainfall was generally light across the area. Additionally, temperatures were well above normal across the region. See the August 2003 Storm Data publication for a continuation of this drought situation.

Extreme drought conditions persisted across eastern Utah with an area of exceptional drought in southeast Utah. Although monsoon moisture resulted in thunderstorms and scattered precipitation, rainfall was generally light across the area. Additionally, temperatures were well above normal across the region. See the August 2003 Storm Data publication for a continuation of this drought situation.

Extreme drought conditions persisted across eastern Utah with an area of exceptional drought in southeast Utah. Although monsoon moisture resulted in thunderstorms and scattered precipitation, rainfall was generally light across the area. Additionally, temperatures were well above normal across the region. See the August 2003 Storm Data publication for a continuation of this drought situation.
Several trees reported down by sheriff's office along Clover Hill Ridge and Morganton roads.

Summer heat and humidity resulted in at least a couple cases of heat exhaustion. Afternoon high temperatures reached the mid 90's with peak heat indices near 105 degrees. Two employees of the Land Between The Lakes National Recreation Area, located between Kentucky Lake and Lake Barkley, got moderate to severe cases of heat exhaustion while at work. The employees spent too much time in direct sunlight during the hottest time of day.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Unspecified number of power poles struck, severing power to 586 residences. By approximately 10 AM the following morning, power had been restored to all but 20 residences. Times of incidents are approximate. Narrative courtesy of Parsons Sun.
Warehouse owned by Greif Brothers Corporation struck. The lightning struck the fuse box, however damage to the structure and it's contents was minimal. (Arkansas City Traveler).

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm winds downed a number a trees over parts of White County, mainly in and around the Joy and Rose Bud areas.  A barn east of Rose Bud sustained some minor roof damage.

Water was reported over several roads in the Murray area, with around 4 inches of water flowing across Highway 121. Thunderstorms  moved through Calloway and southern Marshall Counties, producing up to 1.5 inches in an hour. A spotter reported 2 inches of rain in Hardin during the storm. Amounts near Murray ranged from less than an inch on the south side of the city to 1.5 inches about 4 miles north of Murray.

In Stoddard County, minor flooding was reported on Highway 25 at J Highway near Bloomfield. In Cape Girardeau County, minor flooding was  reported on Highway 25 near Delta. Thunderstorms dumped from 3 to 6 inches of rain over the area. At the Cape Girardeau airport, an automated observing system measured 3.05 inches during the morning hours, including about 1.5 inches in an hour. Reports from co-operative observers included 5.0 inches in Advance and 4.0 inches in Jackson.

In Stoddard County, minor flooding was reported on Highway 25 at J Highway near Bloomfield. In Cape Girardeau County, minor flooding was  reported on Highway 25 near Delta. Thunderstorms dumped from 3 to 6 inches of rain over the area. At the Cape Girardeau airport, an automated observing system measured 3.05 inches during the morning hours, including about 1.5 inches in an hour. Reports from co-operative observers included 5.0 inches in Advance and 4.0 inches in Jackson.

Thunderstorms during the afternoon and evening of the 13th produced flash flooding, hail up to nickel size, and damaging winds.Heavy thunderstorm rains flooded and closed Fairview Church Road and Meadow Creek Road, 6 miles south southwest of Christiansburg, caused Spoon Creek to flood and close Route 680 at Patrick Springs, Rangely Creek, 1 mile west of Fieldale, to flood Route 683 with up to 4 feet of water, and Marrowbone Creek to flood Soapstone Road 2 miles northwest of Ridgeway.Heavy thunderstorm rains flooded and closed several roads in Roanoke. Thunderstorm winds downed numerous trees in Roanoke, Riner, Andersonville, Alum Ridge, Penhook, 8 miles south of Stone Mountain, 2 miles north of Burnt Chimney, and along Highway 360 in Keeling.    Trees and power lines were downed in Radford.

An area of low pressure that developed off the southeast coast of the United States on the morning of the 14th intensified as it moved rapidly northeastward through the Gulf of Maine on the 15th.  The storm produced heavy snow across all of western and central Maine with amounts generally ranging from 10 to 20 inches.

An area of low pressure that developed off the southeast coast of the United States on the morning of the 14th intensified as it moved rapidly northeastward through the Gulf of Maine on the 15th.  The storm produced heavy snow across all of western and central Maine with amounts generally ranging from 10 to 20 inches.
Amateur radio operators reported dime size hail on the west side of Austin.
Many trees were blown down or damaged from estimated wind gusts of 52 knots ( 60 mph ).
Numerous trees were blown down along the Saint John River from estimated wind gusts of 52 knots ( 60 mph ).
The hail damaged 50 acres of potato crops.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees down on power lines on Northampton Boulevard.
A few trees were blown down across Highway 395 in the northern part of the county.
A few trees were blown down on Highway 19 in SE Attala county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A storm system organized off the North Carolina coast Friday, December 5th and moved northeast to coastal Delaware Saturday, December 6th. The storm then intensified as it moved to near Cape Cod Sunday morning, December 7th, then moved out to sea south of Nova Scotia Sunday night. Snow developed across the area by late morning on December 6th, and became steady and heavy during the afternoon and evening. Another burst of heavy snow occurred overnight of December 6th into early Sunday, December 7th. Snow accumulations were generally: between 15 and 25 inches in Addison county. Numerous, mostly minor traffic accidents were reported.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Location was at Old Spanish Trail and Cullen.
Location was at US 59 and the Hardy Toll Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: This lightning caused fire was named the Yankee Gulch Fire. The fire occurred on Bureau of Land Management public lands and consumed 1,501 acres of pinyon pine, juniper, and sage.

Heavy rainfall from the line of thunderstorms that moved through the region on the 19th caused some minor to moderate river flooding along the Potomac River from the 19th through the 21st. The South Branch of the Potomac at Franklin rose 5 feet above bankful. A large portion of Route 220 flooded as well as Snow Mountain Road. Several other roads were also flooded. The South Branch of the Potomac at Petersburg  rose 2.5 feet above flood stage. Water inundated a good portion of the south end of town along Route 220. The South Branch of the Potomac at Springfield rose 3 feet above flood stage. Water inundated the meadow land. Opequon Creek rose to bankful stage during this event, and water overflowed the low lying portions of Sulpry Spring Road. The Potomac River at Shepherdstown rose a little above flood stage. The river overflowed low lying areas just down stream of Shepherdstown.

A strong cold front moved through the region early on the 13th, leaving frigid temperatures and strong winds. Widespread damage due to downed trees and power lines were reported throughout the District of Columbia. Two men were injured when debris from a torn roof fell on them.

A MCS thunderstorm complex bowed out and raced across Eastern Iowa and Northwest Illinois in the pre dawn hours.  Due to high freezing levels, hail was minimal.  Along the Highway 20 corridor in Northeast Iowa and Northwest Illinois winds were estimated at 60 to 70 knots in places (70-80 mph).  The cities of Dubuque, Iowa and Freeport, Illinois were particularly hard hit with many trees downed or uprooted. In Stephenson County Illinois, a well defined path of straight line winds was noted from 5 miles West of Freeport, across the northern part of the city, and east to the Stephenson/Winnebago county line.  On the US 20 bypass around Freeport at Jct IL 75 five (5) 90 foot high voltage power poles were downed.  One injury was reported on a campground southeast of Pearl City in Stephenson county were a tree limb fell on a tent.  About 2 hours after the storms passed, a machine shed caught fire 4 to 5 miles north of Andrew, Iowa due to downed power lines.
Several trees reported down by sheriff's office including along highway 321 in Wears Valley, along Kellum Creek road near Sevierville and along Cummings Chapel road 7 miles northeast of Sevierville.
Ping pong ball size hail reported by emergency management agency.
Several trees reported down by utility company.

A late summer heat wave hit in mid August, just as many area schools were starting the new school year. As a result, most schools reduced their schedule to a half day while a few closed completely. There were two deaths reported by the State Health Department that were heat related. One occurred  in St. Louis County with the other in the City of St. Louis. High temperatures ranged from the mid 90's to around 100 degrees. Columbia had five straight days of 100 degrees or higher,  hitting 105 degrees on August 21st. St. Louis had a high of 104 degrees which also occurred on the 21st.

A band of thunderstorms with torrential downpours moved slowly east. The heaviest rainfall, estimated by radar to be one to two inches per hour, extended from West Frankfort to Harrisburg. Flooding of some flood-prone, low-lying roads was reported in Saline County.

Thunderstorms developed along and ahead of a cold front that moved southward across western Kentucky. The storms produced torrential rainfall and continuous lightning after dark. Rainfall at a co-operative observer station in Canton (Trigg County) measured 4.10 inches in three hours. The storms downed many trees, including a few that landed on homes, but there were no reports of structures damaged directly by wind. Isolated reports of large hail were received. A weak tornado produced a broken path of tree damage in western Calloway County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several trees were blown down.
Tree was blown down onto a house in the city. No damage estimates were available and no injuries were reported.
Measured by ASOS on site.
Numerous trees were reported down over the northern half of the county, with the heaviest concentration in the northwest.

Thunderstorms during the afternoon of the 19th produced  a tornado, damaging winds, and hail up to golfball size.A small tornado developed about 2 miles north-northwest of Dillard and traveled southeast about four tenths of a mile before dissipating. The tornado was about 60 yards wide and damaged an abandoned house, moved a barn off of its fountain, and knocked  down and snapped off numerous trees and branches. A 3 foot diameter tree was also snapped off.Thunderstorm winds downed trees 6 miles north of Danbury, downed trees and power lines in Pilot Mountain, downed trees blocked Route 772 near Duggins Road 8 miles north-northeast of Walnut Cove, downed trees along Route 52 near Pinnancle, and downed trees 1 north of Elkin and Mt. Airy.

A line of strong to severe thunderstorms moved across the region on the 19th. These storms preceded a cold front and produced gusty, damaging winds and heavy rainfall. Rainfall amounts averaged 2 to 4 inches. Some streets in and around the District were closed due to high water.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Some streets were closed due to high, standing water.

A stationary thunderstorms produced an estimated two and a half inches of rain just south of Twentynine Palms. Spotters reported two feet of water in local washes along with water running across roads making them impassable.
Flash flooding from a stationary thunderstorm caused Highway 168 near Westgard Pass to become impassable. Four vehicles were stuck in mud and debris for a short period of time.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of low pressure that developed off the southeast coast of the United States on the morning of the 14th intensified as it moved rapidly northeastward through the Gulf of Maine on the 15th.  The storm produced heavy snow across all of northern, central, and southeastern New Hampshire with amounts generally ranging from 10 to 20 inches.

A storm system organized along the coastal area of the Carolinas early Sunday, December 14th. This system intensified and moved northeast to Cape Cod by early Monday, December 15th. The storm then moved into the Canadian Maritimes by Tuesday, December 16th. Snow developed around noon on Sunday, December 14th, and became heavy during the afternoon and night. Across northern and southwestern portions of the county, 7 to 10 inches of snow fell. Ogdensburg International Airport was closed. A number of automobile accidents were reported.

A storm system organized along the coastal area of the Carolinas early Sunday, December 14th. This system intensified and moved northeast to Cape Cod by early Monday, December 15th. The storm then moved into the Canadian Maritimes by Tuesday, December 16th. Snow developed Sunday afternoon, December 14th, and became heavy Sunday night into Monday morning, December 15th. Across southeastern St Lawrence county, there was generally between 7 and 9 inches of snow.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees were blown down across the county.
Numerous trees were blown down. One shed was destroyed. One home had a large limb blown into the roof. Skirting was blown out from two mobile homes.
Several large limbs were blown across a road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms on the afternoon of the 9th produced damaging winds, damaging lightning and hail up to quarter size.Thunderstorm winds downed trees in Fairfield, Roanoke, Bent Mountain, Huddleston, Amherst, Pilot, Wytheville, Clear Fork, onto Route 91 and Route 608, 14 miles southwest of Tazewell, onto Route 42, 2 miles east of Bland, 8 miles east of Pulaski onto Route 663, onto Route 43 in Buchanan, 3 miles east of Stewartsville and 2 miles north of Amherst. Thunderstorm winds also downed trees and power lines in Covington, and near Paint Bank onto Route 658 and Route 311, numerous trees in Warm Springs, Kerrs Creek, Pearisburg, across Campbell County, 7 miles west of Appomattox, and onto Route 29 near Gretna.Thunderstorm winds downed trees in Meadows of Dan, Ringgold, Red Oak, Laural Fork, Clover, 1 mile south of Amherst, 4 miles northeast of Radford City,  and 5 miles west of Independence.Thunderstorom winds also downed trees countywide across Halifax County, with a tree downed onto a car in Halifax.Lightning struck a house in Laurel Fork, starting a fire which destroyed the house.

Thunderstorms on the afternoon of the 9th produced damaging winds, damaging lightning and hail up to quarter size.Thunderstorm winds downed trees in Fairfield, Roanoke, Bent Mountain, Huddleston, Amherst, Pilot, Wytheville, Clear Fork, onto Route 91 and Route 608, 14 miles southwest of Tazewell, onto Route 42, 2 miles east of Bland, 8 miles east of Pulaski onto Route 663, onto Route 43 in Buchanan, 3 miles east of Stewartsville and 2 miles north of Amherst. Thunderstorm winds also downed trees and power lines in Covington, and near Paint Bank onto Route 658 and Route 311, numerous trees in Warm Springs, Kerrs Creek, Pearisburg, across Campbell County, 7 miles west of Appomattox, and onto Route 29 near Gretna.Thunderstorm winds downed trees in Meadows of Dan, Ringgold, Red Oak, Laural Fork, Clover, 1 mile south of Amherst, 4 miles northeast of Radford City,  and 5 miles west of Independence.Thunderstorom winds also downed trees countywide across Halifax County, with a tree downed onto a car in Halifax.Lightning struck a house in Laurel Fork, starting a fire which destroyed the house.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees and powerlines were blown down. A few trees fell on houses.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms during the afternoon and evening of the 13th produced flash flooding, hail up to nickel size, and damaging winds.Heavy thunderstorm rains flooded and closed Fairview Church Road and Meadow Creek Road, 6 miles south southwest of Christiansburg, caused Spoon Creek to flood and close Route 680 at Patrick Springs, Rangely Creek, 1 mile west of Fieldale, to flood Route 683 with up to 4 feet of water, and Marrowbone Creek to flood Soapstone Road 2 miles northwest of Ridgeway.Heavy thunderstorm rains flooded and closed several roads in Roanoke. Thunderstorm winds downed numerous trees in Roanoke, Riner, Andersonville, Alum Ridge, Penhook, 8 miles south of Stone Mountain, 2 miles north of Burnt Chimney, and along Highway 360 in Keeling.    Trees and power lines were downed in Radford.
Thunderstorms during the afternoon of the 16th produced damaging winds and hail up to nickel size.Thunderstorm winds downed trees in Ridgeway, and onto Route 220, 2 miles southwest of Ridgeway.

Very strong Thunderstorms across Baker county produced a peak gust of 84 mph at the Oregon Trail Interpretive center, damaging several old wagons at the site. Wind gust to 60 mph at the airport and other reports of 60 to 70 mph winds blew down trees and power lines.
A cold front moving eastward across Eastern Oregon produced a Severe Thunderstorm with 66 mph winds and very heavy rain fall.
Very Strong Thunderstorms across the area produced hail near Bruneau and Three quarters of an inch of rain south of Murphy in fifteen minutes with minor flooding.
Wide spread Thunderstorms  over SW Idaho produced, hail, heavy rain and strong gusty winds.
An area of Thunderstorms with very strong winds blew down a commerial greenhouse.
Wide spread Thunderstorms developed over southwest Idaho ahead of a  cold front moving across Eastern Oregon.

A very moist upper level trough moving eastward across southern Idaho produced wide spread Thunderstorms over the region. Several  Severe Thunderstorms occurred with winds in excess of 60  mph.  Hail to three quarters of on inch was reported three miles south of Reynolds Creek in Owyhee county.

A slow moving cold front with weak waves of low pressure riding along it produced heavy rain during the first half of the day on the 24th. In addition to the poor drainage flooding, runoff from the heavy rain caused flooding in the Passaic River Basin from late in the day on the 24th through the 28th. The Woodlawn section of Lincoln Park Borough was in thigh high water from the Pompton River on the 24th. The Rockaway River below the Boonton Reservoir was above its 5 foot flood stage from 11 p.m. EST on the 24th through 700 a.m. EST on the 26th. It crested at 5.67 feet at 9 a.m. EST on the 25th. The Passaic River at Pine Brook was above its 19 foot flood stage from 730 a.m. through 1015 p.m. EST on the 26th. It crested at 19.01 feet at 9 a.m. EST. Farther downstream, the Passaic River at Two Bridges was above its 9 foot flood stage from 1249 a.m. EST on the 25th through 615 a.m. EST on the 28th. It crested at 9.85 feet at 1145 a.m. EST on the 26th.Storm totals included 1.83 inches in Chatham and 1.70 inches in Boonton. The frontal system responsible for the heavy rain moved from the central Ohio Valley during the afternoon of the 23rd to central Pennsylvania during the morning of the 24th to just east of the New Jersey coast during the early evening of the 24th. The heavy rain preceded and accompanied the cold frontal passage. December 2003 was unseasonably wet as was all of 2003. On a statewide average, 2003 was the fifth wettest year on record in New Jersey  with a preliminary average of 57.45 inches, 10.26 inches wetter than normal. In New Jersey yearly precipitation totals included 43.13 inches in Trenton (Mercer County) and 48.36 inches at the Atlantic City International Airport.

Low pressure tracking from the mid Atlantic coast to southeast New England brought heavy snow and strong winds to southwest New Hampshire.  Snowfall totals of 6 to 10 inches were widely reported in Cheshire and Hillsborough Counties, along with winds of 35 to 45 mph.  The combination of falling snow and strong winds created dangerous travel conditions, and there were many reports of minor accidents.Some specific snowfall totals, as reported by trained spotters, included 13 inches in Francestown; 11 inches in Temple; 10 inches in Westmoreland; 9 inches in Greenfield, Milford, Peterborough, and South Weare; 8 inches in Rindge, New Ipswich, Hudson, and Manchester; and 6 inches in Winchester, East Alstead, Hillsborough, and Wilton.

A warm front, loaded with moisture, slowly approached eastern New York during the morning hours of December 17. While temperatures aloft were mild enough for all rain, temperatures at the ground level were well below freezing during the morning and early afternoon across the Lake George Saratoga region, which meant freezing rain fell. While ice accumulations were well below warning thresholds, the thin glaze turned many surface, including roadways, into skating rinks. The ice came during the morning commute and resulted in numerous vehicular accidents throughout the Lake George Saratoga region. At one point, the Adirondrack Northway was temporarily closed near Queensbury as were stretches of Route 149 in both Warren and Washington counties. Several other state highways were briefly closed as well. At least thirty vehicles were reported off road in the city of Saratoga Springs in Saratoga County alone.  Fortunately, no major injuries were reported to the National Weather Service.
A line of severe thunderstorms pulled down numerous large tree limbs, several trees and wires in Dover and Manchester Townships. About 6,000 homes and businesses lost power in the county.

Snow and ice fell across most of southwest and south central Kansas.  Snow mixed with sleet or ice pellets occurred southeast of a line from Ashland to Greensburg to Kinsley to Larned.  Strong north winds of 30 to 45 MPH caused plenty of blowing and drifting snow, with every county in the CWA reporting less than a quarter mile visibility for several hours, with occasional white out conditions.  Snowfall amounts were banded, with the two highest reports both being 6 inches, from southern Gray county and central Stanton county.  A 30 to 40 mile wide band of snowfall amounts from 4 to 5 inches fell from just north of Scott City southwest through northern Kearny county to southwest of Johnson City in Stanton County.  Another swath of snow 35 to 45 miles wide, also with snow amounts from 4 to 5 inches, fell from near Meade to Cimarron through Dodge City and Greensburg to near Medicine Lodge.  One more band of 4 to 5 inch amounts fell from extreme northwest Hodgeman County to just northwest of Ness City to near Hays.  Many schools and other planned activities were cancelled due to the weather, especially the low visibilities.  Numerous traffic accidents were reported in Liberal, Dodge City, Pratt, and Medicine Lodge.  Two jack-knifed semi-trailers, on a portion of Kansas Highway 96 between Scott City and Leoti, caused the highway to be closed for an hour and a half.  Zero visibility conditions closed U.S. Highway west of Ulysses for about 3 hours Tuesday afternoon on the 10th.

CZ_NAME: BIG AND LITTLE WOOD RIVER REGION
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A long lasting winter storm brought blizzard conditions to much of southeast Idaho beginning the night of the 28th and peaking on December 29th and drawing to a close on the 30th.  The worst conditions occurred on the 29th and many major interstates closed due to the blizzard conditions.  Interstate 86 was closed from Pocatello to the interstate 84 interchange.  Interstate 84 was closed from Burley to the Utah state line.  Interstate 15 shut down south of Pocatello and State highway 37 was closed from Oneida County to American Falls.  Some details from the storm including snow totals were 13 inches at Galena Summit, 8 inches at Minidoka with 4 foot drifts, 12 inches at Driggs and 18 inches at Palisades with 4 feet drifts, 16 inches at Holbrook, 8 inches at Malad with 2 foot drifts, 12 inches at Kilgore with 3 foot drifts, 50 to 60 mph wind gusts in Pocatello, 12 to 14 inches at Hailey, 18 to 20 inches at Ketchum, over 300 road slideoffs and 60 crashes reported by the Idaho State Police, 12 inches at Sublett with whiteout conditions on the 29th, blizzard conditions on highway 91 at Swan Lake on the 29th, 9 inches at Swan Valley, 10 inches at Shoshone, 6 inches at McCammon with 2 foot drifts, 6 inches on the east benches of Pocatello, 6 inches at Burley with 3 foot drifts, 24 inches at Ashton, 10 inches at Bone, 12 inches at Springfield, 7 inches at Malta, 12 inches at Stone, 1 to 3 feet in Buist, 2 feet in Spencer, 18 inches at Island Park, 10 inches at Richfield, and 8 inches at Henry.  In addition to the interstate closures, several state highways and local roadways were closed during the day on the 29th.

The combination of runoff from the heavy rain during the first half of the day on the 11th, higher than normal tides from the recent full moon and a southeasterly flow into Delaware Bay and the Delaware River caused tidal flooding along the Delaware River and tidal sections of its tributaries during the morning and afternoon. The incoming afternoon tide also slowed the discharge from the inland rivers. Admiral Wilson Boulevard in Camden (Camden County) was under water for several hours. Several drivers were rescued by the Camden Police. The tide on the Delaware River in Burlington reached 10.37 feet above mean lower low water. Minor tidal flooding begins at 9.0 feet. In Philadelphia, the tide on the Delaware River reached 8.73 feet above mean lower low water. Minor tidal flooding begins at 8.2 feet. The low pressure system passed near Philadelphia during the morning of the 11th and a south to southeast flow preceded the low pressure system.

A second storm developed quickly on the heels of the first winter storm . This storm affected the region from the evening of the 5th through the morning of the 6th. The second storm produced another 5 to 6  inches of snow across North and Central Maryland. A medical condition rendered a Frederick, MD woman unconscious after  she walked outside to check her mailbox on the 6th. The elderly woman died of hypothermia on the 7th.

A soggy couple of days in Utah with snow down to some valley locations. The "dreaded lake effect" brought a band of heavy snow to the western half of the Salt Lake Valley late on the 6th and early on the seventh, with Herriman picking up 9 inches of snow in just 2 hours. Other snow totals included 26 inches in Alta, 21 inches at Brian Head, 9 inches in East Layton, 8 inches in Ibapah, 6 inches in Tooele, 5 inches in Cedar City and 4 inches in Pleasant Grove.

CZ_NAME: W UTAH T X NW/P X E JUAB
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving storm really pounded the mountains with heavy snow. Some of the totals reported over the tree day period included 55 inches at Farnsworth Lake, 48 inches at the Gooseberry Ranger Station, 31 inches at Solitude, 28 inches at Brian Head and 27 inches at Brighton. The Tooele bench reported 10 inches, Cedar City 9 inches, and Nephi had 5 inches.

A swell from Tropical Storm Jimena generated surf of 4 to 8 feet along the east- and southeast-facing shores of Kauai, Oahu, Molokai, Lanai, and Maui.  No serious property damage or injuries were reported.  However, more than 350 swimmers had to be rescued from waters off the south shore of Oahu during the Waikiki Roughwater Swim during the morning hours of the 1st of September.  Strong currents forced many of the event's participants to seek assistance in getting out of the water.  Those who had to be helped were rescued by city lifeguards, the fire department, the Coast Guard, and Good Samaritans.  The Honolulu Police Department and Emergency Medical Services also contributed to the overall operation.

Strong northeast winds behind a cold front, sustained at 30 to 40 mph with gusts to over 65 mph, downed trees and power poles, and damaged roofs on several homes, across the island chain.  A 30-foot kiawe tree on the Big Island of Hawaii fell onto a housing unit and knocked it off its foundation at the Kawaihae Transitional Housing Program on the Kohala coast.  Cost of damages was not available.  No serious injuries were reported.

A powerful storm low northwest of Hawaii generated surf of 15 to 30 feet along the northwest-facing shores of all the islands.  One man, visiting Hookena Beach in the South Kona District on the Big Island of Hawaii, drowned as he was pulled out to sea by a strong current caused by the high surf on the 5th.  A 20 year-old man from Switzerland suffered lacerations while boogie boarding in the high surf near   The Pines in North Kona on the 6th of January.  No other serious injuries were reported.Some damage occurred along beaches and beach-front properties, especially on the west side of the Big Island and the North Shore of Oahu.  However, no damage estimates were available.

A powerful winter storm roared across pretty much the whole state. Even Utah's Dixie received measurable snow. Slick roads contributed to hundreds of minor traffic accidents. Though the snow amounts were not overly impressive, it was the widespread nature of the event that made it unusual. The highest total reported was 14 inches at Brian Head. Most mountain locations picked up 6-10 inches, with some valley totals including 7 inches in South Ogden, 5 inches in Cedar City, 4 inches at Delta, 3 inches in Zion National Park and 1 inch in St. George.

CZ_NAME: E NEVADA/E PLACER/E EL DORADO/NE ALPINE
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong winter storm moved through the region over the Christmas holiday.  A cold front moved through on the 24th before the upper low moved across on the 25th.  The strong jet stream associated with the system helped intensify snowfall rates.  One to two inches of rain fell in some valley locations on the 24th.Snowfall totals:South Lake Tahoe			16-20 inchesTruckee				11 inchesEcho Summit			12 inchesBoreal Ski Resort			8-10 inchesAlpine Meadows Ski Resort		20-30 inchesSquaw Valley Ski Resort (8200 ft)	16-20 inchesNorthstar at Tahoe Ski Resort		18-22 inches

A strong winter storm moved across the Rockies and into the Central Plains, bringing heavy snows to parts of Northeast Wyoming. Snow increased in intensity during the early morning and continued through much of the day. Snow then began to taper off during the evening. Snowfall amounts across the Northeast Wyoming Plains were generally in the 3 to 6 inch range. Across the Wyoming Black Hills, snowfall totals of 8 to 12 inches were common, with up to 16 inches falling near Four Corners.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Baseball hail was reported at 31st and Harvard and then again at 21st and Harvard.  The hail broke windows and damaged numerous roofs of buildings and cars. Damage is estimated; pending supplemental insurance reports.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Snow and ice fell across most of southwest and south central Kansas.  Snow mixed with sleet or ice pellets occurred southeast of a line from Ashland to Greensburg to Kinsley to Larned.  Strong north winds of 30 to 45 MPH caused plenty of blowing and drifting snow, with every county in the CWA reporting less than a quarter mile visibility for several hours, with occasional white out conditions.  Snowfall amounts were banded, with the two highest reports both being 6 inches, from southern Gray county and central Stanton county.  A 30 to 40 mile wide band of snowfall amounts from 4 to 5 inches fell from just north of Scott City southwest through northern Kearny county to southwest of Johnson City in Stanton County.  Another swath of snow 35 to 45 miles wide, also with snow amounts from 4 to 5 inches, fell from near Meade to Cimarron through Dodge City and Greensburg to near Medicine Lodge.  One more band of 4 to 5 inch amounts fell from extreme northwest Hodgeman County to just northwest of Ness City to near Hays.  Many schools and other planned activities were cancelled due to the weather, especially the low visibilities.  Numerous traffic accidents were reported in Liberal, Dodge City, Pratt, and Medicine Lodge.  Two jack-knifed semi-trailers, on a portion of Kansas Highway 96 between Scott City and Leoti, caused the highway to be closed for an hour and a half.  Zero visibility conditions closed U.S. Highway west of Ulysses for about 3 hours Tuesday afternoon on the 10th.

The winter storm over central North Dakota began moving northeast producing strong northwest winds over western North Dakotain its wake. The winter storm warning for the west was upgraded to a blizzard warning due to the strong winds. Winds of 30 to45 mph with gust around 50 mph were producing near zero visibilities in blowing snow. No travel was advised by the North Dakota Highway Patrol over much of western North Dakota.

The winter storm over central North Dakota began moving northeast producing strong northwest winds over western North Dakotain its wake. The winter storm warning for the west was upgraded to a blizzard warning due to the strong winds. Winds of 30 to45 mph with gust around 50 mph were producing near zero visibilities in blowing snow. No travel was advised by the North Dakota Highway Patrol over much of western North Dakota.

CZ_NAME: COCOA BEACH TO JUPITER INLET FL OUT 20NM
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm winds produced a wind gust to 39 knots at Vero Beach.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A small part of south-central Wisconsin received 6 to 7 inches of snow by about 1500 CST in a marginal winter storm. Seven inches was measured at Montello (Marquette Co.), and Reedsburg (Sauk Co.).  Accumulating snow started about 0400 CST, and was preceded by rain.  Being that this was the first appreciable accumulating snow of the 2003-04 winter season, probably an estimated (based on newspaper reports) dozen or two dozen vehicle accidents occurred due to "driving to fast for conditions."  Elsewhere in south-central Wisconsin two to four inches fell, and just 1 to 2 inches fell over southeast Wisconsin.

A complex area of low pressure approached eastern New York from the Ohio Valley on the morning of December 18. A potpourri of precipitation was associated with it. Across portions of the Mohawk Valley and the Lake George Saratoga region, freezing rain took place during morning and midday hours. While the freezng rain was light, it glazed many surfaces, including roadways making them nearly impossible to negogiate. The result was many vehicular accidents. No serious injuries were reported to the National Weather Service.

Heavy showers caused ponding of roadways, and minor stream and drainage ditch flooding in areas of leeward Kohala on the Big Island of Hawaii.  There were no reports of serious injuries or property damage.

A brush fire, of an unknown but suspicious origin, burned 100 acres of mainly trees and grass near Koko Crater at the Koko Head District Park.  The blaze came within 25 feet of a dozen homes at the foot of the crater but was controlled by firefighters and residents before being able to do any damage.  Six engine companies with 45 personnel, a helicopter, and a tanker were used to contain the fire.  No serious injuries were reported.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Penny size hail was reported near the intersection of 11th Street and 193rd East Avenue or County Line Road.
Penny size hail was reported near the intersection of 11th Street and 193rd East Avenue or County Line Road.

CZ_NAME: W SUMMIT T NW/SE SALT LAKE/WASATCH X SC/E UTAH/P X E JUAB/X NW SAN PETE
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow fell in the Wasatch Mountains and valleys, with 7 inches reported at Kimball Junction, 6 inches in Coalville and Alta, and 5 inches at Snowbird.

Low pressure tracking from the mid Atlantic states to southeast New England brought heavy snow and strong winds to Massachusetts.  Snowfall totals of 6 to 10 inches were widely observed from the east slopes of the Berkshires into north central and interior northeast Massachusetts.  Locations along and south of the Massachusetts Turnpike received lesser amounts, on the order of 3 to 6 inches, since warmer air coming in off the ocean caused the snow to change to rain.Heavy snow across the interior combined with strong winds to produce dangerous travel conditions, due to the combination of falling snow and 40 to 50 mph winds.  This resulted in dozens of minor traffic accidents throughout the region.Official snowfall totals from the storm included 7.0 inches at Worcester Airport, 4.4 inches at Logan International Airport in Boston, and 3.8 inches at the National Weather Service Office in Taunton.Other snowfall totals, as reported by trained spotters, included 11 inches in Goshen and Russell; 10 inches in Northfield; 8 inches in Ashfield, Orange, Leverett, South Hadley, Ashburnham, and Pepperell; 7 inches in Montgomery, Westfield, Westhampton, Bolton, Littleton, Groton, Reading, Haverhill, Methuen, and North Andover; and 6 inches in Greenfield, Colrain, Amherst, Springfield, West Brookfield, Fitchburg, Tyngsboro, Acton, Topsfield, and Newburyport.

Intensifying low pressure tracking from the Mid Atlantic Coast...through the Gulf of Maine...to Nova Scotia brought heavy snow and near blizzard conditions to the region. Snow began during the evening of the 6th then continued...heavy at times...through the 7th before tapering to snow showers during the early morning hours of the 8th. Winds of 20 to 30 mph combined with the heavy snow to produce near blizzard conditions at times during the height of the storm. Storm total snow accumulations generally ranged from 12 to 20 inches at lower elevation areas. Persistent upsloping winds into the mountains enhanced accumulations across higher terrain areas where total snow accumulations of 20 to 35 inches were reported.

Low pressure developed over Wyoming moving into central North Dakota on the 26th of December and intensified into a winter storm. The storm was a prolonged event producing 6 to 13 inches of snow in the west. The most snow fell at Power Lakes with 13 inches and Williston with 10 inches.

Low pressure developed over Wyoming moving into central North Dakota on the 26th of December and intensified into a winter storm. The storm was a prolonged event producing 6 to 13 inches of snow in the west. The most snow fell at Power Lakes with 13 inches and Williston with 10 inches.

CZ_NAME: NORTHEAST SISKIYOU AND NORTHWEST MODOC COUNTIES
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Winter Storm Warning was issued for California zones CAZ080/081/082/083/084/085 above 2000 feet on 12/28/03 at 0315 PST and expired on 12/29/03 at 1830 PST.  The observations above verified the warning, which likely should have included all elevations above 1000 feet or so.  Snow observations at high altitudes indicated the event occurred from 1200 PST on 12/28 to 1200 PST on 12/29.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotter SY20 in Tulelake reported 4 inches of snow.

Freezing rain, sleet, and snow fell across portions of west central and central Oklahoma causing dangerous driving conditions across the area. Many traffic accidents were reported, especially along Interstate 40. Freezing rain which caused icy roads fell for several hours on Dec. 12th before the precipitation eventually changed to sleet and then snow. Interstate 40 was closed for a time due to numerous traffic accidents in a small area in western Oklahoma. One man was reported injured in one of these accidents. Snowfall accumulations varied across the area from less than an inch to 6 inches. The greatest snowfall where the mix of winter precipitation occurred fell in Kingfisher, Logan, and Payne counties where 4 to 6 inches of snow fell.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Snowfall of 6 to 12 inches was accompanied by freezing rain in some areas early in the event...and by winds strong enough to cause blowing and drifting snow as the snow accumulated. The 12 inch report was from Lake Andes. Schools were delayed or closed, and several school related athletic events were postponed. Travel was severely hampered.

Low pressure developed over Wyoming moving into central North Dakota on the 26th of December and intensified into a winter storm. The storm was a prolonged event producing 6 to 13 inches of snow in the west. The most snow fell at Power Lakes with 13 inches and Williston with 10 inches.

Snow started to fall shortly after dawn Friday in far southwestern Kansas, then quickly spread north and east across other parts of southwest and south central Kansas.  This snow basically fell south of a line from Johnson City to Garden City to Jetmore to Larned.  The heaviest snow reported was in the Medicine Lodge area, where 9 inches fell.  6 to 8 inches of new snow fell east of a Jetmore to Greensburg to Coldwater line, including the communities of Pratt and St. John.  From 2 to 4 inches of snowfall was reported across the remainder of southern sections of southwest Kansas.  Numerous traffic accidents were reported in the Garden City area, but none with serious injury.

A prodigious winter storm affected nearly all of southeastern Idaho beginning Christmas evening and continuing until the morning of the 27th.  Generally 1 to 2 feet of snow were common across the Snake River Plain and southeastern Highlands with the storm.  In Pocatello, it set the one day December record for snowfall with 13 inches on the 26th.  The storm totaled 14.9 inches at the NWS office at the airport.  High winds accompanied the storms with blizzard conditions in Pocatello during the evening and overnight on the 26th.  Other specific snow amounts from the storm were 20 inches on the east benches of Pocatello with 4 feet drifts.  18 inches 8 miles east of Fort Hall, 1 foot in American Falls, 1 foot in the Idaho Falls area, 15 inches in Bone, 9 inches in Grace, 16 inches at Howell Canyon, 16 inches at Wild Horse Divide, 9 inches at Soda Springs, and 15 inches at Driggs.  The Pocatello airport shut down on the 26th and although not receiving heavy snow, blizzard conditions were reported in Burley on the morning of the 26th with whiteout conditions reported on interstate 84.
Snowfall of 6 to 10 inches was accompanied by areas of blowing and drifting snow, mainly late in the event. The snowfall caused numerous school closings and delays, and hampered travel.

Rain with pockets of freezing rain preceded a warm front that moved through Sussex County during the evening and overnight on the 20th. In addition to the freezing rain, sleet was reported. The sleet briefly covered the ground in Lincoln Park (Morris County) during the evening of the 20th. In Sussex County, precipitation fell mainly as rain in the valleys, but temperatures remained below freezing over the higher terrain. Ice accretions were generally less than five hundredths of an inch. Untreated roads and walkways were hazardous.

A deep low northeast of Hawaii combined with a strong high far north of the state to produce surf of 10 to 25 feet, with some sets over 30 feet, along the east- and north-facing shores of all the islands.  The large surf caused destruction of property; and closed beaches, schools and parks; primarily along the east shores of Kauai, Oahu, Maui, and the Big Island of Hawaii.  Break walls were damaged, some makeshift homes on the Big Island were destroyed and several homes on Kauai were evacuated, and roads near the shorelines were occasionally closed when inundated with water from the pounding surf.  No serious injuries were reported, however.  The dollar cost of total damages was not available.

Thanks to 1.5 to almost 2.5 inches of precipitation that fell on Dec 9th and 10, long-term drought conditions ended across south-central and southeast Wisconsin.  The precipitation started as rain but switched over to snow on the 10th from west to east. The much-needed precipitation was associated with low pressure moving east across southern Wisconsin.  An amateur radio operator near Delavan (Walworth Co.) had a two-day total of 2.49 inches.  Milwaukee Mitchell Field (Milwaukee Co.) gathered 1.46 inches and Madison Truax Field (Dane Co.) came in with 1.66 inches.  The drought conditions (at least D0 - abnormally dry) began on August 1, 2003.  However, parts of south-central and southeast Wisconsin would go on to finish 2003 several inches below normal for yearly precipitation.  Milwaukee only had 22.30 inches of precipitation in 2003 (normal is 34.81 inches) - the driest year since 1963 when only 19.10 inches was measured.  Madison had 31.74 inches for 2003 (normal is 32.95 inches).  In addition, much of south-central and southeast Wisconsin was 5 to 8 inches below normal in 2002 for yearly precipitation.

1 to 2 inches and localized areas of 3 inches of rain fell across much of the southern half of the White River Basin on the 22nd and 23rd with an additional half inch of rain falling on the 29th. This caused lowland flooding. Location:		FS:	Crest:	Date of Crest:Spencer		14	15.8	12/26/03Elliston		18	21.3	12/26/03Newberry		13	14.8	12/27/03

EVENT_NARRATIVE: River Road flooded in Bryson City. The Little Tennessee overflowed its banks and flooded a portion of highway 28 near Needmore at the Macon County line. The Tuckasegee also flooded in spots in and around Bryson City.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow fell over the Rocky Mountain Front and portions of Southwest Montana during the afternoon of the 13th through midday on the 14th. Reported snow fall amounts include: 11 inches at the Pike Creek SNOTEL site, 10 inches at the Black Bear SNOTEL site, 7 inches at the Copper Camp SNOTEL site, 7 inches at the Darkhorse Lake SNOTEL site and 6 inches at the Badger Pass SNOTEL site. Gusty west winds accompanied the snow.

Heavy snow fell over the Rocky Mountain Front and portions of Southwest Montana during the afternoon of the 13th through midday on the 14th. Reported snow fall amounts include: 11 inches at the Pike Creek SNOTEL site, 10 inches at the Black Bear SNOTEL site, 7 inches at the Copper Camp SNOTEL site, 7 inches at the Darkhorse Lake SNOTEL site and 6 inches at the Badger Pass SNOTEL site. Gusty west winds accompanied the snow.

Heavy snow fell over the Rocky Mountain Front and portions of Southwest Montana during the afternoon of the 13th through midday on the 14th. Reported snow fall amounts include: 11 inches at the Pike Creek SNOTEL site, 10 inches at the Black Bear SNOTEL site, 7 inches at the Copper Camp SNOTEL site, 7 inches at the Darkhorse Lake SNOTEL site and 6 inches at the Badger Pass SNOTEL site. Gusty west winds accompanied the snow.

Low pressure intensified as it moved from the Gulf Coast up the mid-Atlantic coast to New England and brought a general snow to the entire region. The event lasted 24 to 30 hours from the early morning of  Sunday the 14th through early Monday. Amounts across the Genesee Valley and western Finger Lakes ranged from six to twelve inches while across the eastern Lake Ontario region one to two feet of snow fell. Specific storm total amounts reported were:  21" in Brantingham; 20" in Lowville; 18" in West Monroe and Redfield; 17" in Fulton; 16" in Woodville and Hooker;  15" in Highmarket, Fairhaven and Macedon; 14" in Fort Drum; 13" in Oswego and Spencerport; 12" in Walworth and Greece; 11" in Webster and Fairport; 10" in Penfield and Rochester; 9" in Victor; 8" in Whitesville and Batavia; and 7" in Geneva, Dansville, Wellsville, Warsaw, Leroy and Albion.  The typical rash of automobile accidents occurred as a result of the wintry conditions. Several injuries, some serious, and one fatality (in Ira) were a reported in the accidents. At the Rochester International Airport, a small plane slid off a taxiway and got stuck in the snow.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding began in the eastern part of the county, where a trailer park was evacuated. Several small streams and small retention ponds overflowed their banks. This resulted in some roads being washed out. Some roads were impassable for most of the day. Eventually, flooding spread to the northern part of the county, where the North Toe and other streams flooded. Numerous evacuations were required.

Some of the worst flooding in 5 years developed across the county during the morning hours. The Toe River system flooded across most of the county. This flooding and flooding along smaller creeks and streams required several evacuations across the county. Every town in the county reported sewage overflows.

Severe flash flooding occurred at Capitol Reef National Park, with water up to Silver Creek bridge. Highway 24 was reported under water with boulders rolling across the highway. Park visitors were being evacuated, and the Fremont river was 5 feet over flood stage.

CZ_NAME: W SALT LAKE T X W/E TOOLE T X E
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The spring storm that brought the strong winds to the state brought a good dose of snow after the winds shifted and died down. Most of the snow was confined to the northern mountains and Wasatch Front. Some of the higher totals included 21 inches at Alta, 19 inches at Snowbird, 14 inches at Brighton and 11 inches at Solitude. In the lower elevations, Liberty reported 9 inches, Pineview Dam 8 inches, Upper Millcreek 7 inches, Brigham City and Alpine 6 inches, Centerville and South Ogden 5 inches and Provo 4 inches.

Heavy rains were reported along the central and west part of St.Croix during the late morning and early afternoon. Flooded streets and guts approaching bankfull were reported in in Fredericksted.

Dense fog affected the coastal section and adjacent waters from south of Tijuana to north of Seal Beach for several days. Visibilities were less than 300 feet, mainly during the night and morning hours. Ground, air, and marine transportation were either halted or significantly delayed.

Strong west winds created a high wind event from the morning of the 16th until early morning on the 17th. Reported wind speeds include: a wind gust of 67 mph at Lewistown 10S, a gust of 59 mph at the Two Medicine DOT site, and sustained wind speeds of 40 mph at the Cut Bank airport, Pendroy 7W and at the Sweetgrass DOT site.

A fire burned 640 acres of brush and grassland; and abandoned cars, rubbish and other debris; just north of Kealia Road near an old airstrip in northeast Kauai.  No homes or other structures were threatened by the fire, and there were no serious injuries.  Kauai County firefighters contained the blaze, along with help from two helicopters from Interisland Helicopters that dropped water on the fire.  The cause of the blaze was not known.

A strong cold front accompanied by thunder-snow ushered winter back into Utah. Over 2 feet of powder fell in the mountains, with up to a foot in some valley locations. Some of the highest amounts were 33 inches at Snowbird, 28 inches at Alta, 21 inches at Farnsworth Lake, 20 inches at Brian Head, 14 inches in Kimball Junction, 12 inches in Fillmore, 10 inches in Tooele and Alpine, 9 inches in Laketown and 8 inches in North Salt Lake.

Low pressure over wyoming moved into the northern plains and intensified into a winter storm over central North Dakota. The storm system brought a prolonged period of snow to southwestern North Dakota. Snow amounts ranged 6 to 8 inches.

The winter storm warning for the west was upgraded to a blizzard warning due to the strong winds. Winds of 30 to45 mph with gust around 50 mph were producing near zero visibilities in blowing snow. No travel was advised by the North Dakota Highway Patrol over much of western North Dakota.

The combination of the already saturated soil and heavy rain around noon EST on the 17th caused poor drainage flooding and flooding along parts of the Millstone River in New Castle County. The Millstone River in Griggstown was above its 10 foot flood stage from 108 p.m. EST on the 17th through 655 p.m. EST on the 18th. It crested at 11.44 feet at 2 a.m. EST on the 18th.  Storm totals included 0.72 inches in Somerville and 0.70 inches in Bound Brook. The heavy rain preceded and accompanied an occluded frontal passage during the day on the 17th. Moisture from the Gulf of Mexico was entrained into this frontal system as it moved through Delaware.

Intensifying low pressure tracking from the Mid Atlantic Coast...through the Gulf of Maine...to Nova Scotia brought heavy snow and blizzard conditions to the region. Snow began during the afternoon of the 6th...with blizzard conditions developing that night.  Sustained winds of 30 to 40 mph with gusts to 60 mph were common at the height of the storm. The strong winds and heavy snow frequently reduced visibilities below a quarter mile along with producing extensive blowing and drifting snow. Although blizzard conditions diminished during the morning of the 7th...snow continued through the rest of the 7th. Storm total snow accumulations generally ranged from 7 to 12 inches...with localized totals to around 16 inches.

Snow and ice fell across most of southwest and south central Kansas.  Snow mixed with sleet or ice pellets occurred southeast of a line from Ashland to Greensburg to Kinsley to Larned.  Strong north winds of 30 to 45 MPH caused plenty of blowing and drifting snow, with every county in the CWA reporting less than a quarter mile visibility for several hours, with occasional white out conditions.  Snowfall amounts were banded, with the two highest reports both being 6 inches, from southern Gray county and central Stanton county.  A 30 to 40 mile wide band of snowfall amounts from 4 to 5 inches fell from just north of Scott City southwest through northern Kearny county to southwest of Johnson City in Stanton County.  Another swath of snow 35 to 45 miles wide, also with snow amounts from 4 to 5 inches, fell from near Meade to Cimarron through Dodge City and Greensburg to near Medicine Lodge.  One more band of 4 to 5 inch amounts fell from extreme northwest Hodgeman County to just northwest of Ness City to near Hays.  Many schools and other planned activities were cancelled due to the weather, especially the low visibilities.  Numerous traffic accidents were reported in Liberal, Dodge City, Pratt, and Medicine Lodge.  Two jack-knifed semi-trailers, on a portion of Kansas Highway 96 between Scott City and Leoti, caused the highway to be closed for an hour and a half.  Zero visibility conditions closed U.S. Highway west of Ulysses for about 3 hours Tuesday afternoon on the 10th.

Snowfall of 6 to 12 inches was accompanied by freezing rain in some areas early in the event...and by winds strong enough to cause blowing and drifting snow as the snow accumulated. The 12 inch report was from Lake Andes. Schools were delayed or closed, and several school related athletic events were postponed. Travel was severely hampered.

Snowfall of 6 to 12 inches was accompanied by freezing rain in some areas early in the event...and by winds strong enough to cause blowing and drifting snow as the snow accumulated. The 12 inch report was from Lake Andes. Schools were delayed or closed, and several school related athletic events were postponed. Travel was severely hampered.

CZ_NAME: RICH/CACHE T NW/P E C WEBER/MOST OF MORGAN/NW SUMMIT/NE SALT LAKE/X NE BOX ELDER
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful winter storm brought damaging winds and some snow to Northern Utah. High winds and thunderstorms wreaked havoc as they move through the Wasatch Front. A roof was partially blown off a restaurant and several trees and fences were blown over in Kaysville. Wind also damaged 3 jet bridges at the Salt Lake City International Airport. Some recorded wind gusts included 68 mph (59 kts) at Gunnison Island, 58 mph (50 kts) in West Valley City and 56 mph (48 mph) in Salt Lake City. Snow amounts in the mountains were 4-10 inches.

A trade wind swell generated surf of 6 to 10 feet, with occasional sets near 15 feet, along the east-facing shores of Kauai and the Big Island of Hawaii.  No serious injuries or property damage were reported.

CZ_NAME: NORTH AND EAST HAWAII INCLUDING WINDWARD KOHALA / HAMAKUA / HILO / PUNA
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A trade wind swell generated surf of 6 to 10 feet, with occasional sets near 15 feet, along the east-facing shores of Kauai and the Big Island of Hawaii.  No serious injuries or property damage were reported.

A squall line of showers produced wind gusts as strong as 70 mph mainly along the coastal communities of extreme southeast Monmouth County. Trees and wires were knocked down in Manasquan and Brielle Boroughs. In Manasquan, the roof of a dugout blew away. Fences were damaged at Stockton Lake Park. In Belmar, a home under construction on 12th Avenue collapsed and damaged the side and roof of the home next door. Jersey Central Power and Light reported about 5,000 of its customers lost power in Monmouth County. The low pressure system that helped mix the near hurricane force winds aloft down to the surface moved from the lower Chesapeake Bay at 4 p.m. EST on the 14th to Delaware Bay at 7 p.m. EST on the 14th to  Hammonton, New Jersey at 10 p.m. EST on the 14th and then just south of Jones Beach, New York at 1 a.m. EST on the 15th.

CZ_NAME: W SALT LAKE T X W/E TOOLE T X E
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful winter storm brought damaging winds and some snow to Northern Utah. High winds and thunderstorms wreaked havoc as they move through the Wasatch Front. A roof was partially blown off a restaurant and several trees and fences were blown over in Kaysville. Wind also damaged 3 jet bridges at the Salt Lake City International Airport. Some recorded wind gusts included 68 mph (59 kts) at Gunnison Island, 58 mph (50 kts) in West Valley City and 56 mph (48 mph) in Salt Lake City. Snow amounts in the mountains were 4-10 inches.

CZ_NAME: WEST HAWAII INCLUDING LEEWARD KOHALA AND KONA
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep storm low east of New Zealand generated surf of 6 to 16 feet along the south-facing shores of all the islands.  The unusually high surf for the south shores of the isles kept lifeguards busy, especially on the 18th of June and mainly on Oahu at Ala Moana Beach Park and Waikiki.  The lifeguards rescued around 400 swimmers and surfers, and assisted nearly 800 more.  More than 100 surfers had their boards broken by the pounding waves.  A small boat was overturned by the high waves as it left the Ala Wai Yacht Harbor, and four people were thrown overboard.  All were rescued by the Coast Guard, with one man sustaining minor injuries.  The boat harbor was later closed for the rest of the afternoon.  Two other individuals were hurt, one on Oahu and the other on Maui.  The person on Maui sustained a spinal injury, though its seriousness was not known.  No serious property damage was reported.

CZ_NAME: RICH/CACHE T NW/P E C WEBER/MOST OF MORGAN/NW SUMMIT/NE SALT LAKE/X NE BOX ELDER
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A mammoth 3-day winter storm blasted portions of Utah, just in time for Christmas travelers. The worst hit area was from the Tooele Valley east through Salt Lake and Davis Counties, and east into the Wasatch Mountains. Freeways and side streets alike were snow packed and slick, resulting in nearly 1500 accidents statewide. Amazingly, no fatalities were reported from the accidents and injuries were minor. The heavy wet snow knocked out power to at least 70,000 people, mainly in Salt Lake and Davis Counties, as tree limbs fell on power lines. Almost 10,000 people went without pour for 48 hours or more, causing emergency shelters to be opened in Salt Lake City and Ogden. The threat of avalanches closed Little Cottonwood Canyon and placed Snowbird and Alta on inter-lodge restrictions. An empty light rail train derailed near the University of Utah, with dozens of airline flights being delayed or cancelled at the Salt Lake City International Airport, though one runway was kept open throughout the storm. The 10.6 inches of snow that fell at the Salt Lake Airport on the 26th smashed the record snowfall for the date of 4.3 inches set in 1936, and was the second snowiest December day on record. Some of the impressive snow totals included, Snowbird 65 inches, Alta 64 inches, Farmington Canyon 63 inches, Spruces 53 inches, Solitude 47 inches, Snowbasin 45 inches, The Canyons 40 inches and Brian Head 30 inches. And in the lower elevations, Upper Millcreek had an amazing 40 inches, East Layton 32 inches, Bountiful 30 inches, Centerville 28 inches, Kimball Junction 26 inches, South Ogden 24 inches, Tooele 23 inches, Salt Lake City Airport 19 inches, Spanish Fork 15 inches, Logan 14 inches, Brigham City 13 inches and Alpine, Fillmore and Morgan with 10 inches. It was a skiers dream, but a travelers nightmare.
A storm low far northwest of the state produced surf of 10 to 20 feet along the northwest-facing shores of all the islands.  No serious property damage or injuries were reported.

Rain with pockets of freezing rain preceded a warm front that moved through the Poconos during the evening and overnight on the 20th. Precipitation fell mainly as rain in the valleys, but temperatures remained below freezing on the plateau. Ice accretions were one tenth of an inch or less. Untreated roads and walkways were hazardous.

Precipitation fell mainly as rain in the valleys, but temperatures remained below freezing on the plateau. Ice accretions were one tenth of an inch or less. Untreated roads and walkways were hazardous.

A second storm developed quickly on the heels of the first winter storm . This storm affected the region from the evening of the 5th through the morning of the 6th. The second storm produced another 5 to 6  inches of snow across North and Central Maryland. A medical condition rendered a Frederick, MD woman unconscious after  she walked outside to check her mailbox on the 6th. The elderly woman died of hypothermia on the 7th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding began when several streams overflowed their banks and flooded roads in the northern part of the county. The Catawba River flooded, and water was overflowing the dam at Lake Tahoma by almost 4 feet. Several other dams were threatened. Several mudslides and a large sewage spill also occurred.
Little Laurel Creek overflowed its banks and flooded several roads and highways, some of which required closing. The French Broad rose to flood stage at Hot Springs.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Dense fog affected the coastal section and adjacent waters from south of Tijuana to north of Seal Beach for several days. Visibilities were less than 300 feet, mainly during the night and morning hours. Ground, air, and marine transportation were either halted or significantly delayed.

Dense fog affected the coastal section and adjacent waters from south of Tijuana to north of Seal Beach for several days. Visibilities were less than 300 feet, mainly during the night and morning hours. Ground, air, and marine transportation were either halted or significantly delayed.
Large tree limbs broken off below Cajon Pass. Sustained winds of over 40 mph with gusts in excess of 58 mph measured for three consecutive hours over Santa Ana Mountains.
Large tree limbs broken off below Cajon Pass. Sustained winds of over 40 mph with gusts in excess of 58 mph measured for three consecutive hours over Santa Ana Mountains.

Snow and ice fell across most of southwest and south central Kansas.  Snow mixed with sleet or ice pellets occurred southeast of a line from Ashland to Greensburg to Kinsley to Larned.  Strong north winds of 30 to 45 MPH caused plenty of blowing and drifting snow, with every county in the CWA reporting less than a quarter mile visibility for several hours, with occasional white out conditions.  Snowfall amounts were banded, with the two highest reports both being 6 inches, from southern Gray county and central Stanton county.  A 30 to 40 mile wide band of snowfall amounts from 4 to 5 inches fell from just north of Scott City southwest through northern Kearny county to southwest of Johnson City in Stanton County.  Another swath of snow 35 to 45 miles wide, also with snow amounts from 4 to 5 inches, fell from near Meade to Cimarron through Dodge City and Greensburg to near Medicine Lodge.  One more band of 4 to 5 inch amounts fell from extreme northwest Hodgeman County to just northwest of Ness City to near Hays.  Many schools and other planned activities were cancelled due to the weather, especially the low visibilities.  Numerous traffic accidents were reported in Liberal, Dodge City, Pratt, and Medicine Lodge.  Two jack-knifed semi-trailers, on a portion of Kansas Highway 96 between Scott City and Leoti, caused the highway to be closed for an hour and a half.  Zero visibility conditions closed U.S. Highway west of Ulysses for about 3 hours Tuesday afternoon on the 10th.

The combination of spring astronomical tides associated with the new moon and a weak southeast flow caused by an approaching cold front from the west in conjunction with a high pressure system over the nearby Atlantic Ocean produced minor tidal flooding at times of high tide during the morning of the 24th. The high tide at Cape May reached 7.24 feet above mean lower low water and at Sandy Hook reached 7.18 feet above mean lower low water. Minor tidal flooding begins at 6.7 feet above mean lower low water. Less widespread minor tidal flooding occurred during the mornings of the 23rd and 25th.

The high tide at Cape May reached 7.24 feet above mean lower low water and at Sandy Hook reached 7.18 feet above mean lower low water. Minor tidal flooding begins at 6.7 feet above mean lower low water. Less widespread minor tidal flooding occurred during the mornings of the 23rd and 25th.

Freezing rain caused widespread icing of roads and other surfaces. The icing severely hampered travel, with numerous accidents reported. The freezing rain was followed by 1 to 3 inches of snow, with areas of blowing snow as winds increased. Numerous schools were closed or delayed, and some other events were cancelled.

A deep low northeast of Hawaii combined with a strong high far north of the state to produce surf of 10 to 25 feet, with some sets over 30 feet, along the east- and north-facing shores of all the islands.  The large surf caused destruction of property; and closed beaches, schools and parks; primarily along the east shores of Kauai, Oahu, Maui, and the Big Island of Hawaii.  Break walls were damaged, some makeshift homes on the Big Island were destroyed and several homes on Kauai were evacuated, and roads near the shorelines were occasionally closed when inundated with water from the pounding surf.  No serious injuries were reported, however.  The dollar cost of total damages was not available.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding occurred in Johnson Canyon just east of Kanab, washing out a bridge and creating some road damage.
