A commuter-rail worker was struck by a freight train as he was clearing snow from the tracks near the Wellesley Hills station.Official snowfall totals from the storm included 25.9 inches at the National Weather Service Office in Taunton, 24.3 inches at Blue Hill Observatory in Milton, 16.9 inches at Logan International Airport in Boston, and 14.2 inches at Worcester Airport.Other snowfall totals, as reported by trained spotters, included 32 inches in Beverly; 30 inches in Topsfield; 29 inches in Everett; 27 inches in Swampscott; 25 inches in Malden and Wakefield; 24 inches in Brockton, East Mansfield, Foxborough, Needham, Randolph, and North Andover; 23 inches in Beverly, Manchester, Reading, East Cambridge, Westwood, and Norwood; 21 inches in Ashfield, Easton, Dover, Dedham, Walpole, and Jamaica Plain; 18 inches in Monson, West Brookfield, Stoneham, Bridgewater, and Seekonk; 14 inches in Leverett, Montgomery, Springfield, Warren, Fitchburg, Littleton, Billerica, Framingham, Gloucester, and Somerset; 12 inches in Whately, Ware, Worthington, Longmeadow, Southwick, Granville, Leicester, Spencer, Southbridge, Tewksbury, Lincoln, and Duxbury; 11 inches in West Falmouth; 8 inches in Eastham; 7 inches on Nantucket; and 6 inches in West Tisbury.

A major winter storm brought heavy snow and strong winds to southern New England, dumping 1 to 3 feet of snow over a large area as it tracked slowly off the coast.  In Massachusetts, snowfall amounts averaged1 to 2 feet across most of the state, with as little as 6 to 12 inches near Cape Cod and the Islands, where most of the snow fell early in the storm before an eventual change to rain.  Pockets of 28 to 35 inch amounts fell near Interstate 95 in Boston's southwest suburbs, as well as to the north of Boston from Everett to Peabody.  The highest snowfall total reported was 36 inches in Peabody.Seas as high as 30 feet just off the eastern Massachusetts coast combined with an astronomically high tide to produce minor coastal flooding from Cape Ann through Scituate and Hull to Provincetown.A peak wind gust of 58 mph was reported at Provincetown during the height of the storm.There was one death indirectly attributed to the storm.  A commuter-rail worker was struck by a freight train as he was clearing snow from the tracks near the Wellesley Hills station.Official snowfall totals from the storm included 25.9 inches at the National Weather Service Office in Taunton, 24.3 inches at Blue Hill Observatory in Milton, 16.9 inches at Logan International Airport in Boston, and 14.2 inches at Worcester Airport.Other snowfall totals, as reported by trained spotters, included 32 inches in Beverly; 30 inches in Topsfield; 29 inches in Everett; 27 inches in Swampscott; 25 inches in Malden and Wakefield; 24 inches in Brockton, East Mansfield, Foxborough, Needham, Randolph, and North Andover; 23 inches in Beverly, Manchester, Reading, East Cambridge, Westwood, and Norwood; 21 inches in Ashfield, Easton, Dover, Dedham, Walpole, and Jamaica Plain; 18 inches in Monson, West Brookfield, Stoneham, Bridgewater, and Seekonk; 14 inches in Leverett, Montgomery, Springfield, Warren, Fitchburg, Littleton, Billerica, Framingham, Gloucester, and Somerset; 12 inches in Whately, Ware, Worthington, Longmeadow, Southwick, Granville, Leicester, Spencer, Southbridge, Tewksbury, Lincoln, and Duxbury; 11 inches in West Falmouth; 8 inches in Eastham; 7 inches on Nantucket; and 6 inches in West Tisbury.

A series of snow showers associated with an arctic cold front caused slippery traveling conditions during the morning from Sussex County south through Mercer County. Hundreds of accidents were reported and massive tie-ups occurred in and around Trenton. Actual accumulations were light, generally less than one inch. But, on roadways the snow melted, the water then froze and black ice formed. In Sussex County, numerous accidents occurred on U.S. Route 206 in Newton, New Jersey State Route 15 in Sparta and New Jersey State Routes 23 and 94. One school district in the county cancelled school for the day, about half a dozen others had delayed openings. In Warren County, the second wave of snow showers around 1030 a.m.. EST wreaked havoc. Ten accidents occurred within a  twenty minute span on Interstate 80. The interstate was closed for 90 minutes. A tractor trailer driver was critically injured when he was struck by another tractor trailer after his trailer jackknifed. In Hunterdon County, a multi-vehicle accident closed the U.S. Route 202 bridge to Pennsylvania. In Mercer County, traffic backed up to 25 miles as multi-vehicle accidents occurred on every major roadway. There were 30 highway crashes on Interstates 95, 295 and 195 in the county. Interstate 295 was backed up halfway south through Burlington County. Interstate 195 was closed for a 16 mile stretch between Millstone Township (Monmouth County) and Trenton for five hours because of over a dozen crashes. The Scudder Falls Bridge (Interstate 95) to Bucks County was closed because of a truck accident. Accidents were not confined to the major interstates. In Trenton there were 40 crashes in the city with U.S. Route 1 and New Jersey State Route 29 hit the hardest. On New Jersey State Route 29, thirteen vehicles were involved in four separate accidents. U.S. Route 1 was closed for three hours in Lawrence Township.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding of access roads was reported in eastern Brownsville.  No flooding of businesses or homes was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Light to moderate snow fell across parts of northern Arkansas starting during the evening hours of the 12th and ending during the early morning hours of the 13th.  Snowfall amounts of 3 to 4 inches were common across the area.  Many roads across the region were hazardous at times due to snow.  Conditions improved later in the morning on the 13th as temperatures climbed above the freezing mark.

Light to moderate snow fell across parts of northern Arkansas starting during the evening hours of the 12th and ending during the early morning hours of the 13th.  Snowfall amounts of 3 to 4 inches were common across the area.  Many roads across the region were hazardous at times due to snow.  Conditions improved later in the morning on the 13th as temperatures climbed above the freezing mark.

Snow showers associated with an arctic cold front caused slippery traveling conditions during the morning commute from the Poconos south to Bucks County. In the Poconos, reported accumulations reached as high as 2.5 inches in Tobyhanna (Monroe County). Dozens of accidents occurred. Interstate 80 was closed for hours during the morning of the 2nd in Pocono Township after two tractor trailers collided. Numerous accidents were also reported on Interstate 380. Farther to the south lighter accumulations occurred. But, on roadways the snow melted, the water then froze and black ice formed. In Bucks County, both the Scudder Falls Bridge (Interstate 95) and U.S. Route 202 bridge were closed heading into New Jersey because of accidents on their respective spans. U.S. Route 1 in Bucks County was backed up because of alternate volume and its own icy conditions. A fifteen to twenty minute commute took up to two and a half hours. U.S. Route 13 was closed in Falls Township.

A powerfull upper level system  moved northeast out of west Texas and began producing snow across parts of northeast Oklahoma to the north and west of Tulsa during the late afternoon and early evening hours.  The snow lasted throughout the night and gradually translated to the south and east.  Points east and south of Tulsa had some rain before the precipitation turned to snow.  Thus, accumulations there were not as high as those in the areas to the north and west of Tulsa.  Some accumulations from the areas which did see heavy snowfall were 10 inches at Pawhuska, 9 inches at Nowata, 8 inches at Bartlesville, 6 inches at Cleveland and 6 inches at Pawnee.

A strong upper level system produced snow across parts of northeast Oklahoma mainly during the evening hours of the the 9th.  Within the larger area of snow a heavy snow band set up from north central Osage County through western and southern Tulsa County.  Snow accumulations of 4 inches or more also occurred near the heavy snow band in Pawnee, Washington and Wagoner Counties and also over the far northeast corner of the state in Ottawa and Delaware Counties.  The larger snowfall amounts from that night were 8 inches at Jenks, 7 inches at Foraker, 6 inches at Pawhuska, 6 inches at Bixby, 5 inches at Ralston, 5 inches at Miami, 4 inches at Coweta, 4 inches at Copan and 4 inches at Grove.

Thanks to 1.5 to almost 2.5 inches of precipitation that fell on Dec 9th and 10, long-term drought conditions ended across south-central and southeast Wisconsin.  The precipitation started as rain but switched over to snow on the 10th from west to east. The much-needed precipitation was associated with low pressure moving east across southern Wisconsin.  An amateur radio operator near Delavan (Walworth Co.) had a two-day total of 2.49 inches.  Milwaukee Mitchell Field (Milwaukee Co.) gathered 1.46 inches and Madison Truax Field (Dane Co.) came in with 1.66 inches.  The drought conditions (at least D0 - abnormally dry) began on August 1, 2003.  However, parts of south-central and southeast Wisconsin would go on to finish 2003 several inches below normal for yearly precipitation.  Milwaukee only had 22.30 inches of precipitation in 2003 (normal is 34.81 inches) - the driest year since 1963 when only 19.10 inches was measured.  Madison had 31.74 inches for 2003 (normal is 32.95 inches).  In addition, much of south-central and southeast Wisconsin was 5 to 8 inches below normal in 2002 for yearly precipitation.

A low moved northward from the Southern Gulf of Alaska up into Prince William Sound during this time.  The associated frontal system swept through the Panhandle and generated widespread high south-southeast winds.   Peak winds included:  90 mph Ketchikan airport roof, 71 mph Ketchikan harbor, 83 mph Hydaburg, and 67 mph Cape Decision.  Significant damage occurred in the Ketchikan area.  A DeHavilland Beaver floatplane that was tied down on the tarmac at the airport, was flipped by the winds violently and totaled.  The aircraft was strapped by rope to metal rings in three concrete blocks weighing one ton each.  The rope was pulled right through the metal by the winds.  There were also numerous reports of downed trees, as well as siding and roof shingle wind damage.  The winds also combined with the rain from this storm to cause a major landslide that blocked South Point Higgins Road in Ketchikan for about eight hours.

A strong and powerful storm brought heavy snows to central Montana during the Christmas holiday season, December 26 and 27. A swath of snow (over 3 feet of snow fall) fell from northern Meagher to Southern Phillips counties. The storm tied the maximum 24-hour snowfall total for Montana when 48 inches fell at Millegan 14SE (near the Cascade-Meagher county line). Reported snow fall amounts include: 53 inches at Shonkin 7S, 48 inches near Millegan 14SE, 41 inches at the Crystal Lake SNOTEL site, 36 inches at Hobson, 25 inches at the Onion Park SNOTEL site, 24 inches at Stanford, 20 inches at Lewistown, 14 inches at Chinook, 13 inches at Valentine, 12 inches at Grassrange, 12 inches at Utica, 12 inches at Bozeman, and 5 inches at Ennis and White Sulphur Springs. The heavy snow was notable for its high water content. Water equivalents of 2 to 3 inches were common with the storm.  In addition to the heavy snow, northwest wind gusts up to 50 mph created blizzard conditions over portions of central and eastern Montana. Snow drifts 3 to 4 feet high were reported in some areas.The storm caused dozens of traffic accidents including numerous semi tractor-trailers sliding off roads or into ditches. Hundreds of motorists were stranded and many roads were closed including portions of Interstate 90. Holiday air travelers were also stranded as airlines canceled many flights. Some ski areas were forced to postpone opening due to the heavy snow. Bridger Bowl (a ski area 16 miles north of Bozeman) received more than 5 feet of snow and could not open as planned on the 26th.

The combination of a high pressure system over nearby New England and a low pressure system moving northeast along the Eastern Seaboard produced a wintry mix of snow, sleet and freezing rain in Eastern Pennsylvania. While precipitation changed to plain rain during the afternoon in southeastern Pennsylvania, the cold air could not be scoured from Berks County, the Lehigh Valley and the Poconos. This caused up to half an inch of ice to accrue. Hazardous driving conditions and scattered power outages resulted. Precipitation began as snow across the region during the early morning. As warmer air moved in aloft from the southeast and south, the snow changed to freezing rain and sleet in Philadelphia around 10 a.m. EST. This change spread north to Berks County by Noon EST, the Lehigh Valley by 2 p.m. EST and the Poconos by 3 p.m. EST. The change to plain rain occurred in Philadelphia around Noon EST, Doylestown (Bucks County) at 130 p.m. EST and Pottstown (Montgomery County) at 230 p.m. EST. It took until 10 p.m. EST for the change to plain rain to occur in Reading (Berks County).Temperatures remained below freezing farther north and precipitation never changed from freezing rain to plain rain. Snow accumulations were 1 to 4 inches, with up to 8 inches reported in the Poconos. Ice accretions were less than one-tenth of an inch in Philadelphia, around two-tenths of an inch in the northern Philadelphia suburbs and around half an inch in Berks County, the Lehigh Valley and the Poconos. Numerous accidents were reported. In Allentown, five accidents occurred within 30 minutes when the freezing rain began. The wind instrumentation froze at the Lehigh Valley International Airport. A few flights were cancelled. About 3,000 homes and businesses lost power as the ice took down some trees and poles. In Berks County, in South Heidelberg Township, about 1,000 homes and businesses lost power when a tree fell onto a power line. In Longswamp Township, several hundred people lost power on the 15th after three trees collapsed from the weight of the ice. In Northampton County, a pole collapsed onto an Easton House. All power was restored by the evening of the 15th. Schools in Allentown were closed on the 15th. Other schools either cancelled classes or had delayed openings in Bucks, Carbon, Lehigh, Montgomery, Monroe and Northampton Counties. Specific accumulations included 8.0 inches in Saylorsburg (Monroe County), 6.0 inches in Pocono Summit (Monroe County), 5.5 inches in Lehighton (Carbon County), 5.0 inches in Tobyhanna and half an inch of ice (Monroe County), 4.2 inches in East Stroudsburg (Monroe County), 3.4 inches in Williams Township and six-tenths of an inch of ice (Northampton County), 3.0 inches at the Lehigh Valley International Airport, 2.0 inches in Phoenixville (Chester County) and Conshohocken (Montgomery County), 1.3 inches in Furlong (Bucks County) and 1.2 inches at the Philadelphia International Airport.    The low pressure system responsible for the winter storm went from near Mobile, Alabama at 7 p.m. EST on the 13th, northeast to just east of Wilmington, North Carolina at 7 a.m. EST on the 14th, near Norfolk at 1 p.m. EST on the 14th, in the lower Chesapeake Bay at 4 p.m. EST, in Delaware Bay at 7 p.m. EST on the 14th, near Hammonton, New Jersey at 10 p.m. EST on the 14th and just south of Jones Beach, New York at 1 a.m. EST on the 15th. The high pressure system that locked in the cold air near the surface retreated from Maine at 7 a.m. EST on the 14th to Nova Scotia at 7 p.m. EST on the 14th.

It took until 10 p.m. EST for the change to plain rain to occur in Reading (Berks County).Temperatures remained below freezing farther north and precipitation never changed from freezing rain to plain rain. Snow accumulations were 1 to 4 inches, with up to 8 inches reported in the Poconos. Ice accretions were less than one-tenth of an inch in Philadelphia, around two-tenths of an inch in the northern Philadelphia suburbs and around half an inch in Berks County, the Lehigh Valley and the Poconos. Numerous accidents were reported. In Allentown, five accidents occurred within 30 minutes when the freezing rain began. The wind instrumentation froze at the Lehigh Valley International Airport. A few flights were cancelled. About 3,000 homes and businesses lost power as the ice took down some trees and poles. In Berks County, in South Heidelberg Township, about 1,000 homes and businesses lost power when a tree fell onto a power line. In Longswamp Township, several hundred people lost power on the 15th after three trees collapsed from the weight of the ice. In Northampton County, a pole collapsed onto an Easton House. All power was restored by the evening of the 15th. Schools in Allentown were closed on the 15th. Other schools either cancelled classes or had delayed openings in Bucks, Carbon, Lehigh, Montgomery, Monroe and Northampton Counties. Specific accumulations included 8.0 inches in Saylorsburg (Monroe County), 6.0 inches in Pocono Summit (Monroe County), 5.5 inches in Lehighton (Carbon County), 5.0 inches in Tobyhanna and half an inch of ice (Monroe County), 4.2 inches in East Stroudsburg (Monroe County), 3.4 inches in Williams Township and six-tenths of an inch of ice (Northampton County), 3.0 inches at the Lehigh Valley International Airport, 2.0 inches in Phoenixville (Chester County) and Conshohocken (Montgomery County), 1.3 inches in Furlong (Bucks County) and 1.2 inches at the Philadelphia International Airport.    The low pressure system responsible for the winter storm went from near Mobile, Alabama at 7 p.m. EST on the 13th, northeast to just east of Wilmington, North Carolina at 7 a.m. EST on the 14th, near Norfolk at 1 p.m. EST on the 14th, in the lower Chesapeake Bay at 4 p.m. EST, in Delaware Bay at 7 p.m. EST on the 14th, near Hammonton, New Jersey at 10 p.m. EST on the 14th and just south of Jones Beach, New York at 1 a.m. EST on the 15th. The high pressure system that locked in the cold air near the surface retreated from Maine at 7 a.m. EST on the 14th to Nova Scotia at 7 p.m. EST on the 14th.

The combination of a high pressure system over nearby New England and a low pressure system moving northeast along the Eastern Seaboard produced a wintry mix of snow, sleet and freezing rain in New Jersey. While precipitation changed to plain rain by early afternoon in southern New Jersey and late afternoon in the Raritan Basin, the cold air could not be scoured from Northwest New Jersey. This caused between a quarter of an inch and half an inch of ice to accrue. Hazardous driving conditions and scattered power outages resulted. Precipitation began as snow across the region around daybreak. As warmer air moved in aloft from the southeast and south, the snow changed to plain rain along the coastal plain. Farther inland, precipitation changed to freezing rain. This change spread north to the Raritan Valley by 3 p.m. EST and throughout Northwest New Jersey by 7 p.m. EST. The change to plain rain occurred in the Raritan Valley around 4 p.m. EST, but struggled through the evening to move through Warren and Morris Counties and never reached Sussex County.  Snow accumulations averaged 2 to 6 inches in the northern half of the state. Accumulations in the southern half of the state were less than two inches. Precipitation started as plain rain near the coast.  Ice accretions ranged from around one-tenth of an inch in the Raritan Valley to half an inch in Sussex County. Numerous accidents were reported. Power outages were mainly restricted to Sussex County. About 2,100 homes and businesses lost power in the county with Hopatcong Borough hardest hit. Road closures and power outages because of downed poles lasted through the afternoon of the 15th in the borough. Schools were either closed or had delayed openings in the county on the 15th.  Specific accumulations included 7.0 inches in Boonton (Morris County), 5.5 inches in Chatham (Morris County), 5.0 inches in Wantage (Sussex County), 4.5 inches in Butler (Morris County), 4.0 inches in Newton (Sussex County), Belvidere (Warren County) and Newton (Sussex County), 3.8 inches in New Brunswick (Middlesex County), 3.5 inches in Hackettstown (Warren County), 3.0 inches in Metuchen (Middlesex County), Belle Mead (Somerset County) and Long Valley (Morris County), 1.8 inches in Ewing (Mercer County), 1.4 inches in Mount Holly (Burlington County), 1.2 inches in Somerdale (Camden County) and 1.0 inch in Freehold (Monmouth County).  The low pressure system responsible for the winter storm went from near Mobile, Alabama at 7 p.m. EST on the 13th, northeast to just east of Wilmington, North Carolina at 7 a.m. EST on the 14th, near Norfolk at 1 p.m. EST on the 14th, in the lower Chesapeake Bay at 4 p.m. EST, in Delaware Bay at 7 p.m. EST on the 14th, near Hammonton, New Jersey at 10 p.m. EST on the 14th and just south of Jones Beach, New York at 1 a.m. EST on the 15th. The high pressure system that locked in the cold air near the surface retreated from Maine at 7 a.m. EST on the 14th to Nova Scotia at 7 p.m. EST on the 14th.

Gusty west winds blew a modular home off a trailer hauling it along northbound Pennsylvania State Route 309 in Lynn Township. The wind pushed the home off the trailer and onto its side. The home slid 280 feet before striking and breaking a telephone pole. The trailer then disconnected from the cab. The cab then veered into the southbound lanes where it struck a dump truck carrying coal silt head-on. The dump truck ended on its side. Both drivers suffered head injuries. The roadway was closed for three and a half hours. The peak wind gust that day at the Lehigh Valley International Airport was 38 mph.

CZ_NAME: SALISBURY SOUND TO CAPE FAIRWEATHER COASTAL AREA
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low moved northward from the Southern Gulf of Alaska up into Prince William Sound during this time.  The associated frontal system swept through the Panhandle and generated widespread high south-southeast winds.   Peak winds included:  90 mph Ketchikan airport roof, 71 mph Ketchikan harbor, 83 mph Hydaburg, and 67 mph Cape Decision.  Significant damage occurred in the Ketchikan area.  A DeHavilland Beaver floatplane that was tied down on the tarmac at the airport, was flipped by the winds violently and totaled.  The aircraft was strapped by rope to metal rings in three concrete blocks weighing one ton each.  The rope was pulled right through the metal by the winds.  There were also numerous reports of downed trees, as well as siding and roof shingle wind damage.  The winds also combined with the rain from this storm to cause a major landslide that blocked South Point Higgins Road in Ketchikan for about eight hours.

Parts of south-central and southeast Wisconsin experienced the fringe effects of a heavy snow event that affected primarily central and northern Wisconsin.  Two to four inches fell west of a Portage (Columbia Co.) to Madison (Dane Co.) to Brodhead (Green Co.) line, after several hours of rain.  Lesser amounts fell east of this line.  The precipitation change-over resulted in icy road conditions that led to dozens of vehicle accidents.  The driver of a pickup truck was killed (indirect-related death) when their vehicle slid into another truck near Janesville (Rock Co.) at about 1830 CST.  Several other drivers of vehicles involved in accidents needed medical treatment at local hospitals.  This event was the first widespread, accumulating snow of the 2003-04 winter season, consequently drivers were traveling too fast for the conditions.

A 972mb low moved northward through the eastern Gulf (roughly 80 miles offshore) during this time.  Strong southeasterly winds developed throughout Southeast Alaska, but reached warning criteria in the Southern Panhandle.  Peak winds included:  Ketchikan airport roof winds at 74 mph, Metlakatla harbor at 66 mph, and Hydaburg at 63 mph.  Minor damage was reported.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rains were widespread across Deep South Texas during the period.  Monthly rainfall totals ranged from 7 to 15 inches.  Portions of Hidalgo, Willacy and Cameron counties experienced heavy rains during a 5 day period from 17th through the 21st resulting in long-lasting flooding of low-lying areas.  During this period, rainfall totals averaged 5 to 9 inches over Hidalgo County, with 6 inches over Willacy County. Cameron County received 6 to 12 inches of rain, with Bayview, reporting 12.74 inches, 12.05 inches falling at Port Isabel,  9.69 falling at Los Fresnos, and 7.87 inches at Brownsville. The heavy rains caused extensive flooding of urban areas.  Damage reports from Cameron county officials indicate, that approximately 467 homes were affected by flooding rains.  Another 175 homes and businesses in Hidalgo and Willacy counties were also affected.  The region had experienced heavy rainfall much of the previous week due to abundant tropical moisture from the Gulf of Mexico.  The rainfall led to saturated soil moisture values and low flash flood guidance values.  From the 19th on, heavy rainfall was caused by a slow moving tropical wave in combination with a cold front and moisture from the Gulf of Mexico.  The American Red Cross opened an emergency shelter in the San Benito area of Cameron County which housed 223 people, primarily from the Green Valley acres subdivision and from areas surrounding the City of Los Fresnos.  The Salvation Army provided over 3200 meals for individuals impacted by the flooding, while the Texas Baptist Men Association provided 2100 hot meals and over 1000 showers.

A strong weather disturbance combined with abundant tropical moisture across the region to produce intense rainfall across Deep South Texas during the period.  The heaviest rains fell across Brooks, Jim Hogg, Starr, Hidalgo, Cameron and Willacy counties. La Joya in western Hidalgo county received over 13 inches of rain, Harlingen received 11 inches, with 10 inches falling at Mc Cook and Falfurrias. Unofficial  reports of 14 inches of rain falling over southern Brooks county. The heavy rains over Starr county caused a rise of Los Olmos Creek. The creek crested at 13 feet at Rio Grande City, on Oct 14, flood stage is 10 feet. The creek quickly fell from flood stage that same afternoon. Numerous homes along Los Olmos Creek suffered water damage. The heavy rains across the rest of Deep South Texas caused flooding over mostly low lying, flood prone areas.Over 550 homes across Deep South Texas suffered minor to moderate damage due to the rising flood waters. The flooding in Brooks county resulted in the closure of U.S. Highway 281 for several days.  Emergency shelters were established in Hidalgo, Brooks and Starr counties to house evacuees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A developing squall line of showers produced wind gusts as strong as 64 mph along coastal communities of Cape May County. Wind gusts to 64 mph at Cape May Harbor. Other wind gusts included 62 mph in Avalon and 58 mph in Cape May City. Trees and wires were reported knocked down in Wildwood. Conectiv Energy reported about 4,700 of its customers lost power in southern New Jersey from Ocean County to Cape May County.The low pressure system that helped mix the near hurricane force winds aloft down to the surface moved from the lower Chesapeake Bay at 4 p.m. EST on the 14th to Delaware Bay at 7 p.m. EST on the 14th to  Hammonton, New Jersey at 10 p.m. EST on the 14th and then just south of Jones Beach, New York at 1 a.m. EST on the 15th.

Several other drivers of vehicles involved in accidents needed medical treatment at local hospitals.  This event was the first widespread, accumulating snow of the 2003-04 winter season, consequently drivers were traveling too fast for the conditions.

CZ_NAME: LINCOLN COUNTY HIGH PLAINS/HONDO VALLEY / LINCOLN EXCEPT SC
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High winds of 40-45 mph with gusts of 60-75 mph developed during mid day as a strong upper level storm center approached from Arizona.

CZ_NAME: NORTHEAST HIGHLANDS / ALL BUT X W AND X SE COLFAX / ALL BUT X W MORA / C SAN MIGUEL / X NW UNION
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High winds of 40-45 mph with gusts of 60-75 mph developed during mid day as a strong upper level storm center approached from Arizona.

Thanks to 1.5 to almost 2.5 inches of precipitation that fell on Dec 9th and 10, long-term drought conditions ended across south-central and southeast Wisconsin.  The precipitation started as rain but switched over to snow on the 10th from west to east. The much-needed precipitation was associated with low pressure moving east across southern Wisconsin.  An amateur radio operator near Delavan (Walworth Co.) had a two-day total of 2.49 inches.  Milwaukee Mitchell Field (Milwaukee Co.) gathered 1.46 inches and Madison Truax Field (Dane Co.) came in with 1.66 inches.  The drought conditions (at least D0 - abnormally dry) began on August 1, 2003.  However, parts of south-central and southeast Wisconsin would go on to finish 2003 several inches below normal for yearly precipitation.  Milwaukee only had 22.30 inches of precipitation in 2003 (normal is 34.81 inches) - the driest year since 1963 when only 19.10 inches was measured.  Madison had 31.74 inches for 2003 (normal is 32.95 inches).  In addition, much of south-central and southeast Wisconsin was 5 to 8 inches below normal in 2002 for yearly precipitation.

A low pressure system that developed in the plains, moved northeast through the central Great Lakes. Rain and snow developed over Upper Michigan on the 9th, and then changed to a heavy wet snow on 10th. By the time the storm moved away on the 12th, the combination of system and lake effect snows deposited as much as 23 inches at Phoenix and 22 inches at Mohawk in Keweenaw County and 22 inches at the Marquette National Weather Service office. Nineteen inches fell at Watton in Baraga County, 17 inches at Ironwood, 15 inches at Bruce Crossing in Ontonagon County, 12 Inches at Wetmore in Alger County, and 11 inches at McMillan in Luce County and at Germfask in Schoolcraft County..
High winds of 40-45 mph with gusts of 60-75 mph developed during mid day as a strong upper level storm center approached from Arizona.
High winds of 40-45 mph with gusts of 60-75 mph developed during mid day as a strong upper level storm center approached from Arizona.

CZ_NAME: GUADALUPE MOUNTAINS OF CHAVES COUNTY / X SW CHAVES
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High winds of 40-45 mph with gusts of 60-75 mph developed during mid day as a strong upper level storm center approached from Arizona.
High winds of 40-45 mph with gusts of 60-75 mph developed during mid day as a strong upper level storm center approached from Arizona.

CZ_NAME: DIXON ENTRANCE TO CAPE DECISION COASTAL AREA
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A 972mb low moved northward through the eastern Gulf (roughly 80 miles offshore) during this time.  Strong southeasterly winds developed throughout Southeast Alaska, but reached warning criteria in the Southern Panhandle.  Peak winds included:  Ketchikan airport roof winds at 74 mph, Metlakatla harbor at 66 mph, and Hydaburg at 63 mph.  Minor damage was reported.

A 972mb low moved northward through the eastern Gulf (roughly 80 miles offshore) during this time.  Strong southeasterly winds developed throughout Southeast Alaska, but reached warning criteria in the Southern Panhandle.  Peak winds included:  Ketchikan airport roof winds at 74 mph, Metlakatla harbor at 66 mph, and Hydaburg at 63 mph.  Minor damage was reported.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The resacas in the Paseo de la Resaca development overflowed their banks due to heavy rains, threatening several homes.
The general public reported water entering the school buildings at Hanna High School.
Flash flooding of Paredes Line road in Brownsville stranded numerous automobiles north of the Paseo de la Resaca development near Cameron Park.
The general public reported street and yard flooding.  Rising water levels were also reported in the Los Morenos creek.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A major winter storm brought heavy snow and strong winds to southern New England, dumping 1 to 2 feet of snow over a large area as it tracked slowly off the coast.  In Rhode Island, snowfall amounts averaged between 10 and 20 inches, and had a major disruption on transportation due to the combination of poor visibility and snow covered roads.  Dozens of minor accidents were reported.Two deaths were indirectly attributed to the storm.  One man was killed when the inner tube he was riding in, towed behind a truck, hit a utility pole.  Another man was killed when he was hit by a train while crossing the tracks on a snowmobile in Exeter.Officially, the snowfall total at T.F. Green State Airport in Warwick was 17.0 inches.Other snowfall totals, as reported by trained spotters, included 21 inches in North Foster; 19 inches in Johnston; 18 inches in downtown Providence and West Warwick; 16 inches in Cranston and North Kingstown; 15 inches in South Kingstown and Barrington; 14 inches in Woonsocket; 12 inches in Exeter and Westerly; and 8 inches in Hope Valley.

CZ_NAME: W SALT LAKE T X W/E TOOLE T X E
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A long spell of cold and unsettled weather moved over mainly Northern Utah. Several episodes of lake effect snow squalls added to the totals. Mountain totals were impressive over the period, with Tony Grove Lake checking in with 43 inches, Alta with 31 inches, Snowbird 25 inches and Brian Head 17 inches. Most valley and bench locations along the Wasatch Front picked up 4-8 inches of snow.

A series of snow showers associated with an arctic cold front caused slippery traveling conditions during the morning from Sussex County south through Mercer County. Hundreds of accidents were reported and massive tie-ups occurred in and around Trenton. Actual accumulations were light, generally less than one inch. But, on roadways the snow melted, the water then froze and black ice formed. In Sussex County, numerous accidents occurred on U.S. Route 206 in Newton, New Jersey State Route 15 in Sparta and New Jersey State Routes 23 and 94. One school district in the county cancelled school for the day, about half a dozen others had delayed openings. In Warren County, the second wave of snow showers around 1030 a.m.. EST wreaked havoc. Ten accidents occurred within a  twenty minute span on Interstate 80. The interstate was closed for 90 minutes. A tractor trailer driver was critically injured when he was struck by another tractor trailer after his trailer jackknifed. In Hunterdon County, a multi-vehicle accident closed the U.S. Route 202 bridge to Pennsylvania. In Mercer County, traffic backed up to 25 miles as multi-vehicle accidents occurred on every major roadway. There were 30 highway crashes on Interstates 95, 295 and 195 in the county. Interstate 295 was backed up halfway south through Burlington County. Interstate 195 was closed for a 16 mile stretch between Millstone Township (Monmouth County) and Trenton for five hours because of over a dozen crashes. The Scudder Falls Bridge (Interstate 95) to Bucks County was closed because of a truck accident. Accidents were not confined to the major interstates. In Trenton there were 40 crashes in the city with U.S. Route 1 and New Jersey State Route 29 hit the hardest. On New Jersey State Route 29, thirteen vehicles were involved in four separate accidents. U.S. Route 1 was closed for three hours in Lawrence Township.

The combination of an extensive snowpack from an early winter storm and a rainstorm on December 11, produced minor flooding on the Esopus and Schoharie Creeks as well as the Mohawk River in eastern New York. One to 2 inches of rain fell over a snowpack with a water equivalent of around 2 inches, melting most of it. The result on the Esopus Creek in Ulster County was for the creek at Mount Tremper to crest at 11.9 feet, 0.9 over flood stage. The Esopus crested at 7.59 feet at Allaben, 0.59 above flood stage. On the Schoharie Creek, the excessive runoff did not happen until the following day, December 12. The creek at Breakabeen crested at 11.41 feet, 0.41 above flood stage. The creek at Burtonsville crested at 6.44 feet, 0.44 above flood stage. On the Mohawk River, the gage at Utica reached the 403.0 flood stage for a few hours on the 12th. No unusual problems were reported to the National Weather Service as a result of this minor flooding.

CZ_NAME: COCOA BEACH TO JUPITER INLET FL OUT 20NM
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A waterspout was reported a mile east of Stuart.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Snow and ice fell across most of southwest and south central Kansas.  Snow mixed with sleet or ice pellets occurred southeast of a line from Ashland to Greensburg to Kinsley to Larned.  Strong north winds of 30 to 45 MPH caused plenty of blowing and drifting snow, with every county in the CWA reporting less than a quarter mile visibility for several hours, with occasional white out conditions.  Snowfall amounts were banded, with the two highest reports both being 6 inches, from southern Gray county and central Stanton county.  A 30 to 40 mile wide band of snowfall amounts from 4 to 5 inches fell from just north of Scott City southwest through northern Kearny county to southwest of Johnson City in Stanton County.  Another swath of snow 35 to 45 miles wide, also with snow amounts from 4 to 5 inches, fell from near Meade to Cimarron through Dodge City and Greensburg to near Medicine Lodge.  One more band of 4 to 5 inch amounts fell from extreme northwest Hodgeman County to just northwest of Ness City to near Hays.  Many schools and other planned activities were cancelled due to the weather, especially the low visibilities.  Numerous traffic accidents were reported in Liberal, Dodge City, Pratt, and Medicine Lodge.  Two jack-knifed semi-trailers, on a portion of Kansas Highway 96 between Scott City and Leoti, caused the highway to be closed for an hour and a half.  Zero visibility conditions closed U.S. Highway west of Ulysses for about 3 hours Tuesday afternoon on the 10th.

A non-thunderstorm high wind event from late on the 12th to the early morning hours on the14th knocked down trees and power lines in portions of Franklin County and knocked down trees across Patrick, Carroll, Grayson, Bedford, Botetourt, Craig, Smyth, Roanoke, Montgomery, Bland, Tazewell, and Amherst Counties, as well as in Lexington, Rural Retreat, Laurel Fork, Willis, and 2 miles east of Covington.In Patrick County, trees were toppled onto power lines. In Grayson County, the roof was blown off of a building. In Roanoke County, winds downed a large tree limb which damaged a vehicle. In Floyd County, wind blew out a window at a business.A wind gust of 60 mph was measured at Hot Springs Airport in Bath County.

A storm system deepened as it moved through eastern Quebec on the 25th and 26th of December. Cold air moved into northern Vermont changing rain to snow in the afternoon of December 25th. The snow became heavy at times the night of the 25th and tapered off to flurries on the 26th. Accumulations ranged from 10 to 20 inches in Franklin county, 8 to 16 inches in Orleans county and in eastern Chittenden county, around 7 inches in Essex county, and between 7 and 9 inches in Lamoille and Caledonia counties.

A storm system deepened as it moved through eastern Quebec on the 25th and 26th of December. Cold air moved into northern Vermont changing rain to snow in the afternoon of December 25th. The snow became heavy at times the night of the 25th and tapered off to flurries on the 26th. Accumulations ranged from 10 to 20 inches in Franklin county, 8 to 16 inches in Orleans county and in eastern Chittenden county, around 7 inches in Essex county, and between 7 and 9 inches in Lamoille and Caledonia counties.

A series of very moist pacific storm systems moved across Eastern Oregon and Southwest Idaho during the period 12 to 14 December 2003 with heavy snow in the mountains. Strong winds developed behind the cold front as it passed Saturday night, with areas of blowing and drifting snow.

Clear skies and light winds behind a cold front lead to the first hard freeze of the season for parts of west central Florida. Overnight low temperatures in the low to mid 20s were found in Levy, Citrus, Hernando, and Sumter counties. Low temperatures included 20 degrees in Brooksville, 22 in Chiefland, 25 in Inverness, and around 30 degrees along the Hillsborough/Polk county line.

Moderate to heavy rainfall late on the 18th and on the 19th resulted in flash flooding and small stream flooding. In addition, an isolated severe thunderstorm knocked down large tree limbs in Huddleston.Runoff from heavy rainfall resulted in numerous creeks and streams out of their banks, some of which flooded roads in Grayson, Roanoke, Bath, Alleghany, Tazewell, Wythe, Carroll, and Bland Counties and in and near Sugar Grove. In Bland County, sections of some roads were washed away by the flood waters. In Pembroke, Doe Creek flooded and damaged a barber shop. Near Lexington route 11 was closed because flood waters pushed debris into the road. In Tazewell county, businesses were damaged as creeks overflowed their banks, especially in Bluefield. In Rockbridge County, Kerrs Creek flooded all along it's reach. In the town of Kerrs Creek it reached its highest level since 1985. Some houses had minor damage.  15 people were trapped on Big Springs Rd between Kerrs Creek and Lexington. There was damage to driveways and fences.  South river had significant flash flooding that caused minor damage to homes, and necessitated a water rescue.In Grayson County, Beaver Creek washed out a culvert (72" pipe), and damaged Rt 625.  There was significant flash flooding in the Fairview area along Chestnut Creek. A woman in her vehicle in the Daleheart area was washed into Meadow Creek and had to be rescued.

An area of low pressure moved across the region and produced some heavy rainfall late the 10th and early on the 11th. This rain fell on top of snow covered grounds and led to melting. The combination of the heavy rainfall and the melting snow produced widespread road flooding of over portions of Maryland during the  morning and afternoon hours. Rainfall amounts averaged 2 to 3 inches. Three water rescues were necessary in Frederick County. 40 to 50 cars had to be moved from a parking lot in a low lying area to prevent damage to the vehicles in Laurel. Several rivers and creeks also flooded. Baltimore County authorities closed a number of roads along the Patapsco River due to flooding. The River flooding persisted through the 13th. In Washington County, the Conococheague Creek at Fairview crested nearly 5 feet above flood stage, and the Antietam Creek at Sharpsburg crested 1.5  ft above flood stage at 5:30 am. In Montgomery County, The Potomac River at Little Falls crested almost a foot above flood stage, and The Seneca Creek at Dawsonville rose 2 feet above flood stage before cresting. In Frederick County, the Monocacy River at Frederick rose 6 ft above flood stage at 3 am and fell below flood stage at 2:30 pm, and the Potomac River at Point of Rocks crested 3.5 ft above flood stage on the 12th and fell below flood stage early on the 13th.

High surf, in excess of 8 feet broke over the Ocean Beach pier. Wind gusts in excess of 45 mph also broke power poles and downed trees along the San Diego County Coast, the Inland Empire, and the Coachella Valley. A lightning strike near a soccer game caused a minor injury to an 18 year old male spectator.

Steady light to moderate rain began falling over the burned areas of the San Bernardino Mountains on 0600 PST 12/24/03. Approximately 24 hours later, mud, rock, and debris flows were being reported along highways and roads leading into the mountain resort communities. By 0800 PST on Christmas Day, more than two inches of rain had fallen at many locations. Between 0800 PST and 1320 PST, rainfall rates increased from 0.20 to 0.70 inches per hour. Between 1300 and 1305 PST, mud, water, and rock slides moved through the Pohl Ranch, located about 1.3 miles south of Crestline. This flow continued down the canyon, moving through a  campground at approximately 1309 PST killing 14 people. It then flowed into the main Waterman Canyon, taking out two bridges downstream at approximately 1316 PST. It finally fanned out and filled the percolation basins located 3.5 miles north of San Bernardino City center between 1337 and 1400 PST. Rainfall rates stayed heavy after 1320 PST. At 1335 PST, downstream ofthe south fork of Lytle Creek, water began to rise rapidly. A flash flood moved downstream from Scotland, taking out much of the roadway and causing mud, rocks, trees and other debris to wash across the frontage road next to Interstate 15 near Glen Helen. Between 1400 and 1500 PST, a large mud and debris flow came down City Creek, crossed several roads in Highlands, covered a portion of the runway at the old Norton Air force Base, and deposited 18 feet of mud in the Santa Ana River Basin.  Moderate to heavy rain continued until approximately 1930 PST, averaging near 0.70 inches/hour. At 1800 PST, a flash flood/mud slide moved down Cable Canyon, through another campground, killing two people, a bear, and a horse, destroying 32 travel trailers, many vehicles, and roads. Heavy rain began to taper off after 2000 PST, with rain ending about 2200 PST on 12/25/03. In all, 33 of the 34 debris basins along the foothills of the San Bernardino Mountains were filled with rocks, trees, and mud.

Many trees were blown down, falling on power lines, cars, houses, and roads between Crestline and Forest Falls.

The third of three major December rainstorms of 2003 took place on Christmas Eve across eastern New York. One to two inches of rain on very saturated ground. The rain melted additional snow causing more excessive runoff and some minor flooding on the Esopus Creek, the Wappingers Creek. as well as the Mettawee and Hoosic Rivers. The flooding lingered into Christmas day. On the Esopus Creek in Ulster County, a crest of 11.97 feet took place at  Mount Tremper, nearly a foot above flood stage. The gage at Allaben reported a crest of 7.87 feet, 0.87 above flood stage. The Mettawee at Granville in Washington County reported a crest of 8.91 feet, nearly 2 feet above the flood stage. On the Hoosic in Rensselaer County, the river crested at 12.26 feet, slightly above the 12-foot flood stage. Despite this flooding being a bit more significant than the previous two during this month, no unusual problems were reported to the National Weather Service.

A strong upper level storm system dove south out of Canada, and moved into Kentucky by early Thursday, December 18th.  Heavy snow fell over portions of eastern Kentucky beginning in the afternoon on Thursday, December 18th.  Snow began accumulating in areas north of the Mountain parkway, along with ridge tops over other areas during the mid-afternoon hours, with many valley locations not switching from rain to snow until 8 or 9 pm the same day.  While many locations accumulated 4 inches of snow or more, only eight counties recorded totals of 4 inches or more within a 12 hour period.  By about 10 am on Friday, December 19th, accumulating snow ended for locations north of Interstate 64 and along the Interstate 75 corridor.  Accumulating snow ended for the rest of eastern Kentucky by around 6 am on Saturday, December 20th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Five inches of snow were reported in the community of McKee.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A combination of high wind gusts up to fifty-one knots and blowing snow which reduced visibilities to near zero resulted in four accidents during the afternoon hours. The four accidents involved nine vehicles in which six people were injured. Three of the injured were examined and released while the other three people remained for treatment. One of the accidents occurred south of Elkhart Kansas on State Highway 95 and the other accidents occured on U.S. Highway 64 and State Highway 136 north of Guymon Oklahoma to near the Kansas state line. Both U.S. Highway 64 and State Highway 136 were closed north of Guymon for a few hours during the afternoon.

Snow started to fall shortly after dawn Friday in far southwestern Kansas, then quickly spread north and east across other parts of southwest and south central Kansas.  This snow basically fell south of a line from Johnson City to Garden City to Jetmore to Larned.  The heaviest snow reported was in the Medicine Lodge area, where 9 inches fell.  6 to 8 inches of new snow fell east of a Jetmore to Greensburg to Coldwater line, including the communities of Pratt and St. John.  From 2 to 4 inches of snowfall was reported across the remainder of southern sections of southwest Kansas.  Numerous traffic accidents were reported in the Garden City area, but none with serious injury.

Clear skies and light winds behind a cold front lead to the first hard freeze of the season for parts of west central Florida. Overnight low temperatures in the low to mid 20s were found in Levy, Citrus, Hernando, and Sumter counties. Low temperatures included 20 degrees in Brooksville, 22 in Chiefland, 25 in Inverness, and around 30 degrees along the Hillsborough/Polk county line.

Snow started to fall shortly after dawn Friday in far southwestern Kansas, then quickly spread north and east across other parts of southwest and south central Kansas.  This snow basically fell south of a line from Johnson City to Garden City to Jetmore to Larned.  The heaviest snow reported was in the Medicine Lodge area, where 9 inches fell.  6 to 8 inches of new snow fell east of a Jetmore to Greensburg to Coldwater line, including the communities of Pratt and St. John.  From 2 to 4 inches of snowfall was reported across the remainder of southern sections of southwest Kansas.  Numerous traffic accidents were reported in the Garden City area, but none with serious injury.

Intensifying low pressure tracking along the Maine coast to central Nova Scotia produced heavy snow across the region. The snow started during the early morning hours of the 15th. Very heavy snow fell during the 15th with snowfall rates of 2 to 3 inches per hour at times...particularly across northern portions of the region. Strong winds produced near blizzard conditions at times with extensive blowing and drifting snow along with visibilities reduced below a quarter mile at times. Storm total snow accumulations generally ranged from 6 to 12 inches along the Downeast coast...with localized totals to around 18 inches. Across interior Downeast areas...storm total snow accumulations generally ranged from 10 to 20 inches...with localized totals to around 24 inches. Across central and northern areas...storm total snow accumulations generally ranged from 16 to 24 inches with localized totals to around 30 inches. The 27.3 inch storm total at Caribou ( 27.1 inches of which fell during the 15th ) represented the second greatest snowfall ever recorded.

The combination of heavy rain between 3 a.m. and 10 a.m. EST on the 11th and runoff from the melting snow produced widespread poor drainage and creek flooding in Philadelphia. The incoming tide during the afternoon slowed the runoff and exacerbated the flooding. Storm totals averaged 1.5 to 2.0 inches. The Frankford Creek at Castor Avenue was above its 7 foot flood stage from 825 a.m. through 940 a.m. EST on the 11th. It crested at 7.75 feet at 845 a.m. EST. The Wissahickon Creek at its mouth was above its 5 foot flood stage from 821 a.m. EST through 637 p.m. EST on the 11th. It crested at 6.06 feet at 245 p.m. EST. The Pennypack Creek at the Rhawn Street Bridge was above its 7 foot flood stage 702 a.m. EST through 711 p.m. EST on the 11th. It crested at 11.75 feet at 315 p.m. EST on the 11th. Flooding along the Pennypack Creek inundated the Pennypack Park near Frankford Avenue.    Storm totals included 1.97 inches at the Franklin Institute and 1.51 inches at the Philadelphia International Airport. The heavy rain was caused by an intense low pressure system at both the surface and aloft that developed over the Southern Plains on the 9th. The primary low pressure system moved toward the Great Lakes on the morning of the 10th while a secondary low pressure system was forming near the upper air support over the Tennessee Valley. This secondary low pressure system continued to intensify and was located over North Carolina the evening of the 10th, near Philadelphia around 7 a.m. EST on the 11th and in western Connecticut early in the evening on the 11th. This secondary low pressure system helped wring the moisture in the atmosphere from the Gulf of Mexico and the Atlantic Ocean onto the region.

The first in a pair of low pressure systems tracked across the region on the 4th and 5th. This system brought light snowto portions of Lower Southern Maryland. Snow totals averaged 1 to 2 inches.  Three fatalities were reported, two from shoveling snow and one from an automobile accident. Other minor, non life threatening injuries were also reported by the Emergency and Law Enforcement Officers.

A second storm developed quickly on the heels of the first winter storm . This storm affected the region from the evening of the 5th through the morning of the 6th. The second storm produced another 5 to 6  inches of snow across North and Central Maryland. A medical condition rendered a Frederick, MD woman unconscious after  she walked outside to check her mailbox on the 6th. The elderly woman died of hypothermia on the 7th.

A second storm developed quickly on the heels of the first winter storm . This storm affected the region from the evening of the 5th through the morning of the 6th. The second storm produced another 5 to 6  inches of snow across North and Central Maryland. A medical condition rendered a Frederick, MD woman unconscious after  she walked outside to check her mailbox on the 6th. The elderly woman died of hypothermia on the 7th.

Intensifying low pressure tracking along the Maine coast to central Nova Scotia produced heavy snow across the region. The snow started during the early morning hours of the 15th. Very heavy snow fell during the 15th with snowfall rates of 2 to 3 inches per hour at times...particularly across northern portions of the region. Strong winds produced near blizzard conditions at times with extensive blowing and drifting snow along with visibilities reduced below a quarter mile at times. Storm total snow accumulations generally ranged from 6 to 12 inches along the Downeast coast...with localized totals to around 18 inches. Across interior Downeast areas...storm total snow accumulations generally ranged from 10 to 20 inches...with localized totals to around 24 inches. Across central and northern areas...storm total snow accumulations generally ranged from 16 to 24 inches with localized totals to around 30 inches. The 27.3 inch storm total at Caribou ( 27.1 inches of which fell during the 15th ) represented the second greatest snowfall ever recorded.

An upper level low closed off over the state on Christmas Eve and continued to slowly track east overnight. This produced snowfall accumulations of two to four inches across the Tri-Cities and western Thumb region by Christmas morning. A warm conveyor belt from the northwest Atlantic ocean then wrapped in behind this low toward Northern Lower Michigan late in the afternoon on Christmas Day. This snow band then progressed south during the evening into the Tri-Cities and Thumb, producing an additional three to five inches. Total snowfall accumulations for this 30 hour event were 5 to 9 inches.

A prodigious winter storm affected nearly all of southeastern Idaho beginning Christmas evening and continuing until the morning of the 27th.  Generally 1 to 2 feet of snow were common across the Snake River Plain and southeastern Highlands with the storm.  In Pocatello, it set the one day December record for snowfall with 13 inches on the 26th.  The storm totaled 14.9 inches at the NWS office at the airport.  High winds accompanied the storms with blizzard conditions in Pocatello during the evening and overnight on the 26th.  Other specific snow amounts from the storm were 20 inches on the east benches of Pocatello with 4 feet drifts.  18 inches 8 miles east of Fort Hall, 1 foot in American Falls, 1 foot in the Idaho Falls area, 15 inches in Bone, 9 inches in Grace, 16 inches at Howell Canyon, 16 inches at Wild Horse Divide, 9 inches at Soda Springs, and 15 inches at Driggs.  The Pocatello airport shut down on the 26th and although not receiving heavy snow, blizzard conditions were reported in Burley on the morning of the 26th with whiteout conditions reported on interstate 84.

A prodigious winter storm affected nearly all of southeastern Idaho beginning Christmas evening and continuing until the morning of the 27th.  Generally 1 to 2 feet of snow were common across the Snake River Plain and southeastern Highlands with the storm.  In Pocatello, it set the one day December record for snowfall with 13 inches on the 26th.  The storm totaled 14.9 inches at the NWS office at the airport.  High winds accompanied the storms with blizzard conditions in Pocatello during the evening and overnight on the 26th.  Other specific snow amounts from the storm were 20 inches on the east benches of Pocatello with 4 feet drifts.  18 inches 8 miles east of Fort Hall, 1 foot in American Falls, 1 foot in the Idaho Falls area, 15 inches in Bone, 9 inches in Grace, 16 inches at Howell Canyon, 16 inches at Wild Horse Divide, 9 inches at Soda Springs, and 15 inches at Driggs.  The Pocatello airport shut down on the 26th and although not receiving heavy snow, blizzard conditions were reported in Burley on the morning of the 26th with whiteout conditions reported on interstate 84.
Snowfall varied from 2 to 5 inches. The snow was accompanied by a little freezing rain at the start of the event. Travel was hampered, and some schools were closed or delayed.
Snowfall of 2 to 5 inches was accompanied by blowing and drifting snow as winds increased. Travel was hampered and some schools were closed or delayed.

The river forecast point, Sherburne on the Chenango River, rose to its flood stage of 8 feet briefly late on the 11th.  The crest was at 8.02 feet at 7:45 PM EST.  A cold front slowly moved northeast through the area on the 11th.  It brought 1 to 1.5 inches of rain, basin averaged.  The rain and warmer weather also melted most of the snow that fell earlier in the week.  This added up to another inch of runoff.  The flooding was minor.

The river forecast point, Waverly (NY)/Sayre (PA) on the Susquehanna River, rose above its flood stage of 11 feet on the 12th.  The crest was at 11.38 feet at 9:46 AM EST.  A cold front slowly moved northeast through the area on the 11th.  It brought around 1 inch of rain to the area around and just upstream.  Rainfall amounts of up to 2 inches fell in the headwaters of the North Branch of the Susquehanna River.  The rain and warmer weather also melted most of the snow that fell earlier in the week.  This added another half inch to an inch of runoff.  The flooding was minor.

Rainfall amounts of up to 2 inches fell in the headwaters of the North Branch of the Susquehanna River.  The rain and warmer weather also melted most of the snow that fell earlier in the week.  This added another half inch to an inch of runoff.  The flooding was minor.

The river forecast point, Cortland on the Tioughnioga River, rose above its flood stage of 8 feet on the 12th.  The crest was at 8.47 feet at 11:13 AM EST.  A cold front slowly moved northeast through the area on the 11th.  It brought around 1 inch of rain to the basin.   The rain and warmer weather also melted most of the snow that fell earlier in the week.  This added up to an inch of additional runoff.  The flooding was minor.

Gusty northwest winds around an intensifying low pressure system produced wind gusts to around 50 mph during the afternoon of the 29th in New Jersey. In Burlington County in Shamong Township, a 2-year-old girl was killed when a limb fell on her from a 40 foot tall tree. She apparently wandered into the area as her father was removing a wind damaged tree. Peak wind gusts included 52 mph in Cape May (Cape May County), 50 mph at the Marina within Atlantic City, 48 mph in Barnegat (Ocean County), 46 mph in Belmar (Monmouth County) and Wrightstown (Burlington County) and 39 mph in Trenton (Mercer County). The strong winds were caused by the difference in surface pressure between a powerful (about 975 millibars) low pressure system moving through the Saint Lawrence River Valley and a high pressure system building northeast from the Gulf Coast States.

An upper level low closed off over the state on Christmas Eve and continued to slowly track east overnight. This produced snowfall accumulations of two to four inches across the Tri-Cities and western Thumb region by Christmas morning. A warm conveyor belt from the northwest Atlantic ocean then wrapped in behind this low toward Northern Lower Michigan late in the afternoon on Christmas Day. This snow band then progressed south during the evening into the Tri-Cities and Thumb, producing an additional three to five inches. Total snowfall accumulations for this 30 hour event were 5 to 9 inches.

Polar high pressure settled into Florida producing clear skies and near calm winds.  Strong radiational cooling dropped low temperatures to 31 degrees in Bronson, 28 in Chiefland, 30 in Inverness, and 28 near Brooksville.

Intensifying low pressure tracking along the Maine coast to central Nova Scotia produced heavy snow across the region. The snow started during the early morning hours of the 15th. Very heavy snow fell during the 15th with snowfall rates of 2 to 3 inches per hour at times...particularly across northern portions of the region. Strong winds produced near blizzard conditions at times with extensive blowing and drifting snow along with visibilities reduced below a quarter mile at times. Storm total snow accumulations generally ranged from 6 to 12 inches along the Downeast coast...with localized totals to around 18 inches. Across interior Downeast areas...storm total snow accumulations generally ranged from 10 to 20 inches...with localized totals to around 24 inches. Across central and northern areas...storm total snow accumulations generally ranged from 16 to 24 inches with localized totals to around 30 inches. The 27.3 inch storm total at Caribou ( 27.1 inches of which fell during the 15th ) represented the second greatest snowfall ever recorded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: More than 40 kayakers became stranded for several hours along the banks of the Wailua River's north fork.  Water levels began to quickly rise from rain that had fallen in central parts of Kauai, near Mt. Waialeale.  All the people involved in the outing made in safely back to the mouth of the river, and there was no serious property damage.
A tornado touched down in rural areas betwen Bunkie and Evergreen, several homes and barns. The tornado primarily remained in sugarcane fields.
A large tree fell through a mobile home in Morgan City, destroying it. At the airport, winds gusted to 85 mph. Several trees fell across the region.
Trees were blown down throughout the parish.
Trees were blown down.

Gusty northwest winds around an intensifying low pressure system produced wind gusts to around 50 mph during the afternoon of the 29th in New Jersey. In Burlington County in Shamong Township, a 2-year-old girl was killed when a limb fell on her from a 40 foot tall tree. She apparently wandered into the area as her father was removing a wind damaged tree. Peak wind gusts included 52 mph in Cape May (Cape May County), 50 mph at the Marina within Atlantic City, 48 mph in Barnegat (Ocean County), 46 mph in Belmar (Monmouth County) and Wrightstown (Burlington County) and 39 mph in Trenton (Mercer County). The strong winds were caused by the difference in surface pressure between a powerful (about 975 millibars) low pressure system moving through the Saint Lawrence River Valley and a high pressure system building northeast from the Gulf Coast States.
A storm low in the southern hemisphere generated surf of 5 to 10 feet along the south-facing shores of all the Hawaiian Islands.  No serious injuries or property damage were reported.

An area of low pressure moved across the region and produced some heavy rainfall late the 10th and early on the 11th. This rain fell on top of snow covered grounds and led to melting. The combination of the heavy rainfall and the melting snow produced widespread road flooding of over portions of Maryland during the  morning and afternoon hours. Rainfall amounts averaged 2 to 3 inches. Three water rescues were necessary in Frederick County. 40 to 50 cars had to be moved from a parking lot in a low lying area to prevent damage to the vehicles in Laurel. Several rivers and creeks also flooded. Baltimore County authorities closed a number of roads along the Patapsco River due to flooding. The River flooding persisted through the 13th. In Washington County, the Conococheague Creek at Fairview crested nearly 5 feet above flood stage, and the Antietam Creek at Sharpsburg crested 1.5  ft above flood stage at 5:30 am. In Montgomery County, The Potomac River at Little Falls crested almost a foot above flood stage, and The Seneca Creek at Dawsonville rose 2 feet above flood stage before cresting. In Frederick County, the Monocacy River at Frederick rose 6 ft above flood stage at 3 am and fell below flood stage at 2:30 pm, and the Potomac River at Point of Rocks crested 3.5 ft above flood stage on the 12th and fell below flood stage early on the 13th.

Rapidly intensifying low pressure tracking through the Saint Lawrence River Valley produced strong damaging south to southeast winds across the region. Wind gusts of 50 to 60 mph were common...with gusts in excess of 60 mph occurring along the coast with onshore winds. A peak wind gust to 62 mph was reported at Stonington. The winds snapped branches and toppled trees which fell on powerlines contributing to power outages. Several thousand customers lost power at various times. The winds also damaged roofs and signs.

Rapidly intensifying low pressure tracking through the Saint Lawrence River Valley produced strong damaging south to southeast winds across the region. Wind gusts of 50 to 60 mph were common...with gusts in excess of 60 mph occurring along the coast with onshore winds. A peak wind gust to 62 mph was reported at Stonington. The winds snapped branches and toppled trees which fell on powerlines contributing to power outages. Several thousand customers lost power at various times. The winds also damaged roofs and signs.

Four Ohio visitors became stranded as a stream near Ulaino Road in Hana became swollen by heavy showers falling over the windward-facing slopes of Mt. Haleakala in East Maui.  Maui fire officials used a helicopter to rescue the group.  There were no serious injuries or property damage.
Heavy showers produced ponding of roadways, and drainage ditch and small stream flooding in windward sections of Oahu.  However, no serious injuries or property damage were reported.
A storm low southeast of New Zealand generated surf of 4 to 8 feet along the south-facing shores of all the Hawaiian Islands.  There were no reports of serious injuries or property damage.

A deep low far north of Hawaii and a strong trade wind swell caused surf of 10 to 20 feet along the north- and east-facing shores of all the islands.  No serious injuries or property damage were reported, though water coming ashore occasionally closed roads along affected shorelines.

Snow started to fall shortly after dawn Friday in far southwestern Kansas, then quickly spread north and east across other parts of southwest and south central Kansas.  This snow basically fell south of a line from Johnson City to Garden City to Jetmore to Larned.  The heaviest snow reported was in the Medicine Lodge area, where 9 inches fell.  6 to 8 inches of new snow fell east of a Jetmore to Greensburg to Coldwater line, including the communities of Pratt and St. John.  From 2 to 4 inches of snowfall was reported across the remainder of southern sections of southwest Kansas.  Numerous traffic accidents were reported in the Garden City area, but none with serious injury.

A cold front slowly moved northeast through the area on the 11th.  It brought 1.5 to 3 inches of rain to the county.  2.8 inches of rain fell in Tunkhannock.  The rain and warmer weather also melted most of the snow that fell earlier in the week.  The water equivalent of the snow was half an inch to an inch.  Many creeks and streams went out of their banks.  The stream gaged Tunkhannock Creek rose quickly but crested just below its flood stage at Tunkhannock.  The flooding caused multiple road closures, such as Route 87 in multiple locations, Route 6 in Skinners Eddy, and state route 4002 in Meshoppen.  Little damage occurred to buildings, but some basements flooded and some roads had damage.

A cold front slowly moved northeast through the area on the 11th.  It brought 1.5 to 2.5 inches of rain to the southwest quarter of the  county.  The rain and warmer weather also melted most of the snow that fell earlier in the week.  The water equivalent of the snow was half an inch to an inch.  Many creeks and streams went out of their banks.  Roads were flooded in Auburn, Springville and Dimock Townships.

CZ_NAME: BOULDER & JEFFERSON COUNTIES BELOW 6000 FEET / W BROOMFIELD COUNTY
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong downslope winds developed along the Front Range.  Peak wind reports included:  91 mph (89 kts) atop Blue Mountain, 80 mph (70 kts) at Pinewood Lake and Carter Lake, 75 mph (65 kts) in Boulder, 72 mph (63 kts) at Buckhorn Mountain and 64 mph (57 kts), 2 miles southwest of Loveland.  Damaging winds downed power lines over parts of Larimer and Boulder Counties.  At least 7000 residents in Boulder County alone lost power due to the strong winds.  The wind also caused two fires in Larimer County to quickly spread.  The larger fire near Masonville was human caused and threatened a dozen homes, forcing the evacuation of 65 homes.  The source of the smaller fire had not been determined.  A delivery truck was flipped onto a small van at the intersection of State Highways 72 and 93.  No one was injured in the accident.  In addition, blowing rocks shattered several car windows at an RTD Park and Ride at the same location.

An upper level disturbance moved across Lake Erie and into northern Ohio on the evening of December 17th.  This caused the light lake effect snow already falling to quickly intensify.  By late evening a band of moderate to heavy snow stretched from Lake County eastward across southern Ashtabula and northern Trumbull counties and into Pennsylvania.  Snowfall rates with this band exceeded two inches per hour.  Accumulations of up to 14 inches were reported in Geauga County by daybreak on the 18th with 8 to 12 inches of accumulation in southern Ashtabula and northern Trumbull Counties.   This activity diminished somewhat during the afternoon of the 18th, but not before another 4 to 8 inches of snow fell from Cuyahoga County eastward through the snowbelt.  Scattered lake effect snow showers then persisted through the 20th.  Thunder and lightning were observed in Cuyahoga County on the 19th.  Total snowfall accumulations from the 17th through the 20th ranged from 12 to 15 inches in eastern Cuyahoga County to over two feet in portions of Geauga and Ashtabula Counties.  A maximum of 26.1 inches was measured in northeastern Geauga County (Hambden Township).  Hundreds of accidents and significant travel delays resulted from this prolonged event.

A powerful storm low northwest of Hawaii generated surf of 15 to 30 feet along the northwest-facing shores of all the islands.  One man, visiting Hookena Beach in the South Kona District on the Big Island of Hawaii, drowned as he was pulled out to sea by a strong current caused by the high surf on the 5th.  A 20 year-old man from Switzerland suffered lacerations while boogie boarding in the high surf near   The Pines in North Kona on the 6th of January.  No other serious injuries were reported.Some damage occurred along beaches and beach-front properties, especially on the west side of the Big Island and the North Shore of Oahu.  However, no damage estimates were available.
A storm low far northwest of Hawaii produced surf of 10 to 20 feet along the northwest-facing shores of all the islands.  There were no reports of serious injuries or property damage.

Sleet and freezing rain began in the early morning of the 5th, and gradually changed to snow, which was heavy during the afternoon and evening of the 5th. From Pittsburgh south, the ice accumulation was noticeable, but further north, the precipitation was mainly snow. Snow accumulations by 7 AM on the 6th were (in inches): Glenshaw 11, Verona 9, Kittanning 10, Economy 9, Butler 6, Shippenville 9, Indiana 12, Brookville 10, New Castle 6, Mercer 7, Franklin 8, Canonsburg 8, Derry 10, and Irwin 10.

Heavy snow moved into the region from the northeast on Christmas Eve night, wrapping around a powerful upper level disturbance in the eastern Great Lakes.  The snow was enhanced by warmth and moisture off of Lake Huron.  Snowfall totals of over 6 inches were common in northeast Lower Michigan and far eastern Upper Michigan.  Ten to twelve inches of snow fell near Kinross, Hessel and Hawks.

Heavy snow moved into the region from the northeast on Christmas Eve night, wrapping around a powerful upper level disturbance in the eastern Great Lakes.  The snow was enhanced by warmth and moisture off of Lake Huron.  Snowfall totals of over 6 inches were common in northeast Lower Michigan and far eastern Upper Michigan.  Ten to twelve inches of snow fell near Kinross, Hessel and Hawks.

The snow was enhanced by warmth and moisture off of Lake Huron.  Snowfall totals of over 6 inches were common in northeast Lower Michigan and far eastern Upper Michigan.  Ten to twelve inches of snow fell near Kinross, Hessel and Hawks.

The combination of an extensive snowpack from an early winter storm and a rainstorm on December 11, produced minor flooding on the Esopus and Schoharie Creeks as well as the Mohawk River in eastern New York. One to 2 inches of rain fell over a snowpack with a water equivalent of around 2 inches, melting most of it. The result on the Esopus Creek in Ulster County was for the creek at Mount Tremper to crest at 11.9 feet, 0.9 over flood stage. The Esopus crested at 7.59 feet at Allaben, 0.59 above flood stage. On the Schoharie Creek, the excessive runoff did not happen until the following day, December 12. The creek at Breakabeen crested at 11.41 feet, 0.41 above flood stage. The creek at Burtonsville crested at 6.44 feet, 0.44 above flood stage. On the Mohawk River, the gage at Utica reached the 403.0 flood stage for a few hours on the 12th. No unusual problems were reported to the National Weather Service as a result of this minor flooding.

Heavy rain and runoff from the melting snow produced widespread poor drainage flooding on the morning of the 11th in Warren and Sussex Counties. In Sussex County, Vernon Crossing Road was closed in Vernon Township. Storm totals included 2.45 inches in Stewartsville (Warren County), 2.30 inches in Columbia (Warren County), 2.20 inches in Phillipsburg (Warren County) and 2.06 inches in Belvidere (Warren County), 1.87 inches in Andover (Sussex County), 1.53 inches in Newton (Sussex County) and 1.42 inches in Sussex (Sussex County). The heavy rain was caused by an intense low pressure system at both the surface and aloft that developed over the Southern Plains on the 9th. The primary low pressure system moved toward the Great Lakes on the morning of the 10th while a secondary low pressure system was forming near the upper air support over the Tennessee Valley. This secondary low pressure system continued to intensify and was located over North Carolina the evening of the 10th, near Philadelphia around 7 a.m. EST on the 11th and in western Connecticut early in the evening on the 11th. This secondary low pressure system helped wring the moisture in the atmosphere from the Gulf of Mexico and the Atlantic Ocean onto the region.

No unusual problems were reported to the National Weather Service as a result of this minor flooding.

The river forecast point, Cooks Falls on the Beaver Kill, started rising the morning of the 24th.  In 12 hours, the river rose over 7 feet to crest at 11.03 feet at 6:30 PM.  Flood stage is 10 feet.  Flooding was minor.  A cold front dropped 1 to 2 inches of rain combined with another inch of water equivalent from melted snow.  Snow started melting before the rain started saturating the already wet ground.  The rain started the morning of the 24th before ending that evening.  Little snow remained on the 25th.

A cold front moved through central New York the morning of the 1st.  Rain showers with the front changed to snow showers.  The cold air behind the front set off lake effect snow showers.  Lake effect snow bands off of Lake Ontario organized in the early afternoon of the 1st, then continued into the early morning of the 2nd when it ended.  Snowfall amounts were 6 to 10 inches.  Snowfall rates approached 2 inches an hour the evening of the 1st.

Lake effect snow bands off of Lake Ontario organized in the early afternoon of the 1st, then continued into the early morning of the 2nd when it ended.  Snowfall amounts were 6 to 10 inches.  Snowfall rates approached 2 inches an hour the evening of the 1st.
