In Burlington County in Shamong Township, a 2-year-old girl was killed when a limb fell on her from a 40 foot tall tree. She apparently wandered into the area as her father was removing a wind damaged tree. Peak wind gusts included 52 mph in Cape May (Cape May County), 50 mph at the Marina within Atlantic City, 48 mph in Barnegat (Ocean County), 46 mph in Belmar (Monmouth County) and Wrightstown (Burlington County) and 39 mph in Trenton (Mercer County). The strong winds were caused by the difference in surface pressure between a powerful (about 975 millibars) low pressure system moving through the Saint Lawrence River Valley and a high pressure system building northeast from the Gulf Coast States.

A strong storm on the gulf coast moved slowly northeast up the east coast on the 14th to be near the Delmarva peninsula late that day.  The storm continued up the coast on the 15th to be in southeast Canada late that evening.  Snow started from around 5 AM near the Pennsylvania border to 9 AM in Oneida County.  This was a widespread 8 to 12 inch snow event across south central New York.  Higher snow amounts of 10 to 18 inches were across Onondaga, Oneida, and Madison Counties.  Across south central New York, sleet and freezing rain mixed in with the snow lowering amounts.  The snow caused numerous automobile accidents and closed schools.

As a cold high pressure system settled over New England, a series of low pressure systems developed off the Mid Atlantic Coast during Friday, December 5th and Saturday, December 6th.The first low pressure system developed along the North Carolina Coast during Friday morning.  As this low moved northeast, it intensified.  Light snow developed and quickly spread northeast across the area during the morning.  Snowfall became heavy across Northeast New Jersey during the afternoon. Between 4 and 7 pm that evening, a 6 to 10 inch snowfall occurred across this area.  There were major impacts to mass transit operations during the evening's "rush" hours.  As this low moved southeast of Long Island, snowfall intensity decreased and became light across the region.The second low pressure system developed further north and west along the DELMARVA Coast during Saturday morning.  As this low rapidly intensified, it moved slowly northeast.  Light snow became heavy across the entire region by noon.  Near blizzard conditions developed across parts of the area from late morning through the evening hours.  Wind gusts up to 35 mph combined with heavy falling snow created near "white out" conditions that reduced visibility to between 1/4 and 1/2 mile.  Major impacts to mass transit occurred across the entire region.Storm Total Snowfall amounts for this 2 day episode ranged from around 9 to 18 inches.  Here are selected snowfall amounts for:Bergen County - from 10.0 inches at Teterboro Airport to 14.3 inches at Rutherford.Essex County - from 12.5 inches at Nutley and Bloomfield to 17.5 inches at Caldwell.  At Newark Airport, 16.4 inches of snow was measured.Hudson County - from 9.0 inches at Kearny to 12.4 inches at Harrison.Passaic County - from 9.3 inches at Bloomingdale to 15.5 inches at Little Falls.Union County - from 13.0 inches at Union Township to 13.2 inches at Roselle.

A deep storm low east of New Zealand generated surf of 6 to 16 feet along the south-facing shores of all the islands.  The unusually high surf for the south shores of the isles kept lifeguards busy, especially on the 18th of June and mainly on Oahu at Ala Moana Beach Park and Waikiki.  The lifeguards rescued around 400 swimmers and surfers, and assisted nearly 800 more.  More than 100 surfers had their boards broken by the pounding waves.  A small boat was overturned by the high waves as it left the Ala Wai Yacht Harbor, and four people were thrown overboard.  All were rescued by the Coast Guard, with one man sustaining minor injuries.  The boat harbor was later closed for the rest of the afternoon.  Two other individuals were hurt, one on Oahu and the other on Maui.  The person on Maui sustained a spinal injury, though its seriousness was not known.  No serious property damage was reported.

A deep low far northwest of the state generated surf of 10 to 15 feet along the north- and northwest-facing shores of all the Hawaiian Islands.  There were no reports of serious injuries or property damage.

CZ_NAME: W SUMMIT T NW/SE SALT LAKE/WASATCH X SC/E UTAH/P X E JUAB/X NW SAN PETE
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A mammoth 3-day winter storm blasted portions of Utah, just in time for Christmas travelers. The worst hit area was from the Tooele Valley east through Salt Lake and Davis Counties, and east into the Wasatch Mountains. Freeways and side streets alike were snow packed and slick, resulting in nearly 1500 accidents statewide. Amazingly, no fatalities were reported from the accidents and injuries were minor. The heavy wet snow knocked out power to at least 70,000 people, mainly in Salt Lake and Davis Counties, as tree limbs fell on power lines. Almost 10,000 people went without pour for 48 hours or more, causing emergency shelters to be opened in Salt Lake City and Ogden. The threat of avalanches closed Little Cottonwood Canyon and placed Snowbird and Alta on inter-lodge restrictions. An empty light rail train derailed near the University of Utah, with dozens of airline flights being delayed or cancelled at the Salt Lake City International Airport, though one runway was kept open throughout the storm. The 10.6 inches of snow that fell at the Salt Lake Airport on the 26th smashed the record snowfall for the date of 4.3 inches set in 1936, and was the second snowiest December day on record. Some of the impressive snow totals included, Snowbird 65 inches, Alta 64 inches, Farmington Canyon 63 inches, Spruces 53 inches, Solitude 47 inches, Snowbasin 45 inches, The Canyons 40 inches and Brian Head 30 inches. And in the lower elevations, Upper Millcreek had an amazing 40 inches, East Layton 32 inches, Bountiful 30 inches, Centerville 28 inches, Kimball Junction 26 inches, South Ogden 24 inches, Tooele 23 inches, Salt Lake City Airport 19 inches, Spanish Fork 15 inches, Logan 14 inches, Brigham City 13 inches and Alpine, Fillmore and Morgan with 10 inches. It was a skiers dream, but a travelers nightmare.

A winter storm brought heavy snow and slick roads to much of Northern Utah, causing several accidents. The snow was also blamed for a fatality, as a driver lost control of his vehicle on the snowy roads between Grantsville and Wendover, rolling it into the medium. Some snow totals for this storm were 16 inches at Snowbird and Solitude, 14 inches at Alta, 12 inches at Sundance, 8 inches in Centerville, Bountiful and East Layton, 6 inches in South Ogden and the SLC Avenues, and 4 inches in Clearfield, Alpine, Heber City, Morgan and Laketown.

Locally heavy bands of snow fell across portions of the North-Central Mountains, Front Range Foothills and Middle Park as a winter storm moved through the state.  Snowfall totals included 10 inches near Buckhorn Mountain, Middle Fork Camp and Tabernash.

Locally heavy bands of snow fell across portions of the North-Central Mountains, Front Range Foothills and Middle Park as a winter storm moved through the state.  Snowfall totals included 10 inches near Buckhorn Mountain, Middle Fork Camp and Tabernash.

The combination of an extensive snowpack from an early winter storm and a rainstorm on December 11, produced minor flooding on the Housatonic River in northwestern Connecticut. One to 2 inches of rain fell over a snowpack with a snow equivalent of around 2 inches, melting most of it. The net result was that Stevenson gage crested at 11.1, 0.1 of a foot above flood stage on the 11th. The following day the gage at Still crested at 12.8 feet, 0.6 of a foot above normal. No problems were reported to the National Weather Service as a result of this minor flooding.

A long lasting winter storm brought blizzard conditions to much of southeast Idaho beginning the night of the 28th and peaking on December 29th and drawing to a close on the 30th.  The worst conditions occurred on the 29th and many major interstates closed due to the blizzard conditions.  Interstate 86 was closed from Pocatello to the interstate 84 interchange.  Interstate 84 was closed from Burley to the Utah state line.  Interstate 15 shut down south of Pocatello and State highway 37 was closed from Oneida County to American Falls.  Some details from the storm including snow totals were 13 inches at Galena Summit, 8 inches at Minidoka with 4 foot drifts, 12 inches at Driggs and 18 inches at Palisades with 4 feet drifts, 16 inches at Holbrook, 8 inches at Malad with 2 foot drifts, 12 inches at Kilgore with 3 foot drifts, 50 to 60 mph wind gusts in Pocatello, 12 to 14 inches at Hailey, 18 to 20 inches at Ketchum, over 300 road slideoffs and 60 crashes reported by the Idaho State Police, 12 inches at Sublett with whiteout conditions on the 29th, blizzard conditions on highway 91 at Swan Lake on the 29th, 9 inches at Swan Valley, 10 inches at Shoshone, 6 inches at McCammon with 2 foot drifts, 6 inches on the east benches of Pocatello, 6 inches at Burley with 3 foot drifts, 24 inches at Ashton, 10 inches at Bone, 12 inches at Springfield, 7 inches at Malta, 12 inches at Stone, 1 to 3 feet in Buist, 2 feet in Spencer, 18 inches at Island Park, 10 inches at Richfield, and 8 inches at Henry.  In addition to the interstate closures, several state highways and local roadways were closed during the day on the 29th.

An area of low pressure moved east across southern Ohio on December 5th.  Precipitation began during the early mornings hours of the 5th and ended around midnight on the 6th.  The precipitation started as a mixture of freezing rain, sleet and snow at most locations.  A quick transition to all snow occurred around daybreak.  By 9 am a band of moderate snow had developed along the U.S. Route 30 corridor from Mansfield to Canton.  The greatest snowfall rates occurred during the late afternoon and early evening hours as wrap around moisture from the low moved into the region.  A total of 6 to 9 inches of snow was reported across the area with the greatest amounts along and just south of U.S. 30.  Most locations also received a light glaze of ice from the freezing rain early in the storm.  Significant traffic delays and numerous accidents resulted from this storm.
Intensifying low pressure tracking across Maine produced wind gusts of 60 to 65 mph along portions of the Maine coast.

Gusty northwest winds around an intensifying low pressure system produced wind gusts to around 50 mph during the afternoon of the 29th in New Jersey. In Burlington County in Shamong Township, a 2-year-old girl was killed when a limb fell on her from a 40 foot tall tree. She apparently wandered into the area as her father was removing a wind damaged tree. Peak wind gusts included 52 mph in Cape May (Cape May County), 50 mph at the Marina within Atlantic City, 48 mph in Barnegat (Ocean County), 46 mph in Belmar (Monmouth County) and Wrightstown (Burlington County) and 39 mph in Trenton (Mercer County). The strong winds were caused by the difference in surface pressure between a powerful (about 975 millibars) low pressure system moving through the Saint Lawrence River Valley and a high pressure system building northeast from the Gulf Coast States.

A strong storm on the gulf coast moved slowly northeast up the east coast on the 14th to be near the Delmarva peninsula late that day.  The storm continued up the coast on the 15th to be in southeast Canada late that evening.  Snow started from around 5 AM near the Pennsylvania border to 9 AM in Oneida County.  This was a widespread 8 to 12 inch snow event across south central New York.  Higher snow amounts of 10 to 18 inches were across Onondaga, Oneida, and Madison Counties.  Across south central New York, sleet and freezing rain mixed in with the snow lowering amounts.  The snow caused numerous automobile accidents and closed schools.

A storm low southeast of New Zealand generated surf of 4 to 8 feet along the south-facing shores of all the Hawaiian Islands.  There were no reports of serious injuries or property damage.

As a cold high pressure system over New England moved east, a low pressure system developed off the Mid Atlantic Coast on Sunday morning, December 14th.  This low intensified as it moved north to northeast along the coast and passed over Cape Cod, MA on Monday morning, December 15th.Light snow developed during the morning and became heavy at times before it mixed with and changed to sleet during the afternoon.  Storm Total Snowfall amounts ranged from 5 to 7 inches across the region.  Here are selected snowfall amounts for:Northern Fairfield County:  from 5 inches at Bethel to 6 inches at New Canaan and Danbury.Northern New Haven County:  from 5 inches at Beacon Falls to 7 inches in Meriden.

Heavy snow moved into the region from the northeast on Christmas Eve night, wrapping around a powerful upper level disturbance in the eastern Great Lakes.  The snow was enhanced by warmth and moisture off of Lake Huron.  Snowfall totals of over 6 inches were common in northeast Lower Michigan and far eastern Upper Michigan.  Ten to twelve inches of snow fell near Kinross, Hessel and Hawks.

A major winter storm brought heavy snow and strong winds to southern New England, dumping 1 to 3 feet of snow over a large area as it tracked slowly off the coast.  In northern Connecticut, snowfall amounts averaged between 12 and 20 inches, and had a major disruption on transportation due to the combination of poor visibility and snow covered roads.  Dozens of minor accidents were reported.Officially, the snowfall total at Bradley International Airport in Windsor Locks was 19.0 inches.  Other snowfall totals, as reported by trained spotters, included 20 inches in East Killingly and Dayville; 19 inches in Stafford Springs; 18 inches in Woodstock; 14 inches in Manchester, Eastford, and Putnam; and 12 inches in East Hartford, New Britain, and Vernon.

A major winter storm brought heavy snow and strong winds to southern New England, dumping 1 to 3 feet of snow over a large area as it tracked slowly off the coast.  In Massachusetts, snowfall amounts averaged1 to 2 feet across most of the state, with as little as 6 to 12 inches near Cape Cod and the Islands, where most of the snow fell early in the storm before an eventual change to rain.  Pockets of 28 to 35 inch amounts fell near Interstate 95 in Boston's southwest suburbs, as well as to the north of Boston from Everett to Peabody.  The highest snowfall total reported was 36 inches in Peabody.Seas as high as 30 feet just off the eastern Massachusetts coast combined with an astronomically high tide to produce minor coastal flooding from Cape Ann through Scituate and Hull to Provincetown.A peak wind gust of 58 mph was reported at Provincetown during the height of the storm.There was one death indirectly attributed to the storm.  A commuter-rail worker was struck by a freight train as he was clearing snow from the tracks near the Wellesley Hills station.Official snowfall totals from the storm included 25.9 inches at the National Weather Service Office in Taunton, 24.3 inches at Blue Hill Observatory in Milton, 16.9 inches at Logan International Airport in Boston, and 14.2 inches at Worcester Airport.Other snowfall totals, as reported by trained spotters, included 32 inches in Beverly; 30 inches in Topsfield; 29 inches in Everett; 27 inches in Swampscott; 25 inches in Malden and Wakefield; 24 inches in Brockton, East Mansfield, Foxborough, Needham, Randolph, and North Andover; 23 inches in Beverly, Manchester, Reading, East Cambridge, Westwood, and Norwood; 21 inches in Ashfield, Easton, Dover, Dedham, Walpole, and Jamaica Plain; 18 inches in Monson, West Brookfield, Stoneham, Bridgewater, and Seekonk; 14 inches in Leverett, Montgomery, Springfield, Warren, Fitchburg, Littleton, Billerica, Framingham, Gloucester, and Somerset; 12 inches in Whately, Ware, Worthington, Longmeadow, Southwick, Granville, Leicester, Spencer, Southbridge, Tewksbury, Lincoln, and Duxbury; 11 inches in West Falmouth; 8 inches in Eastham; 7 inches on Nantucket; and 6 inches in West Tisbury.

Moderate to heavy rainfall late on the 18th and on the 19th resulted in flash flooding and small stream flooding. In addition, an isolated severe thunderstorm knocked down large tree limbs in Huddleston.Runoff from heavy rainfall resulted in numerous creeks and streams out of their banks, some of which flooded roads in Grayson, Roanoke, Bath, Alleghany, Tazewell, Wythe, Carroll, and Bland Counties and in and near Sugar Grove. In Bland County, sections of some roads were washed away by the flood waters. In Pembroke, Doe Creek flooded and damaged a barber shop. Near Lexington route 11 was closed because flood waters pushed debris into the road. In Tazewell county, businesses were damaged as creeks overflowed their banks, especially in Bluefield. In Rockbridge County, Kerrs Creek flooded all along it's reach. In the town of Kerrs Creek it reached its highest level since 1985. Some houses had minor damage.  15 people were trapped on Big Springs Rd between Kerrs Creek and Lexington. There was damage to driveways and fences.  South river had significant flash flooding that caused minor damage to homes, and necessitated a water rescue.In Grayson County, Beaver Creek washed out a culvert (72" pipe), and damaged Rt 625.  There was significant flash flooding in the Fairview area along Chestnut Creek. A woman in her vehicle in the Daleheart area was washed into Meadow Creek and had to be rescued.

Intensifying low pressure tracking along the Maine coast to central Nova Scotia produced heavy snow across the region. The snow started during the early morning hours of the 15th. Very heavy snow fell during the 15th with snowfall rates of 2 to 3 inches per hour at times...particularly across northern portions of the region. Strong winds produced near blizzard conditions at times with extensive blowing and drifting snow along with visibilities reduced below a quarter mile at times. Storm total snow accumulations generally ranged from 6 to 12 inches along the Downeast coast...with localized totals to around 18 inches. Across interior Downeast areas...storm total snow accumulations generally ranged from 10 to 20 inches...with localized totals to around 24 inches. Across central and northern areas...storm total snow accumulations generally ranged from 16 to 24 inches with localized totals to around 30 inches. The 27.3 inch storm total at Caribou ( 27.1 inches of which fell during the 15th ) represented the second greatest snowfall ever recorded.

A High Wind Warning was issued for the coastal headlands of ORZ021/022 at 1434 PST on 12/23 and expired at 0400 PST on 12/24.  The spotter report above did not give a specific time, but judging from other nearby observations, it almost certainly occurred within the warning window.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Gold Beach recorded a gust to 64 mph at this time.

An upper level disturbance moved across Lake Erie and into northwestern Pennsylvania on the evening of December 17th.  This caused the light lake effect snow already falling to quickly intensify.  By late evening a band of moderate to heavy snow stretched from Lake Erie across Northeast Ohio and into Erie and Crawford Counties.  Snowfall rates with this band exceeded two inches per hour.  Accumulations of 6 to 10 inches were reported by daybreak on the 18th.  This activity diminished somewhat during the afternoon of the 18th, but not before another 4 to 8 inches of snow fell across northwestern Pennsylvania.  Scattered lake effect snow showers continued to affect the area on the 19th and 20th.  Total snowfall accumulations from the 17th through the 20th ranged from 12 to nearly 18 inches.  A maximum of 17.8 inches was measured at Corry in southeastern Erie County.  Hundreds of accidents and significant travel delays resulted from this prolonged event.

CZ_NAME: NE BOX ELDER T X NE/W WEBER/DAVIS
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A mammoth 3-day winter storm blasted portions of Utah, just in time for Christmas travelers. The worst hit area was from the Tooele Valley east through Salt Lake and Davis Counties, and east into the Wasatch Mountains. Freeways and side streets alike were snow packed and slick, resulting in nearly 1500 accidents statewide. Amazingly, no fatalities were reported from the accidents and injuries were minor. The heavy wet snow knocked out power to at least 70,000 people, mainly in Salt Lake and Davis Counties, as tree limbs fell on power lines. Almost 10,000 people went without pour for 48 hours or more, causing emergency shelters to be opened in Salt Lake City and Ogden. The threat of avalanches closed Little Cottonwood Canyon and placed Snowbird and Alta on inter-lodge restrictions. An empty light rail train derailed near the University of Utah, with dozens of airline flights being delayed or cancelled at the Salt Lake City International Airport, though one runway was kept open throughout the storm. The 10.6 inches of snow that fell at the Salt Lake Airport on the 26th smashed the record snowfall for the date of 4.3 inches set in 1936, and was the second snowiest December day on record. Some of the impressive snow totals included, Snowbird 65 inches, Alta 64 inches, Farmington Canyon 63 inches, Spruces 53 inches, Solitude 47 inches, Snowbasin 45 inches, The Canyons 40 inches and Brian Head 30 inches. And in the lower elevations, Upper Millcreek had an amazing 40 inches, East Layton 32 inches, Bountiful 30 inches, Centerville 28 inches, Kimball Junction 26 inches, South Ogden 24 inches, Tooele 23 inches, Salt Lake City Airport 19 inches, Spanish Fork 15 inches, Logan 14 inches, Brigham City 13 inches and Alpine, Fillmore and Morgan with 10 inches. It was a skiers dream, but a travelers nightmare.

CZ_NAME: JEFFERSON & W DOUGLAS COUNTIES ABOVE 6000 FEET / GILPIN / CLEAR CREEK / NE PARK COUNTIES BELOW 9000 FEET
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong downslope winds developed along the Front Range.  Peak wind reports included:  91 mph (89 kts) atop Blue Mountain, 80 mph (70 kts) at Pinewood Lake and Carter Lake, 75 mph (65 kts) in Boulder, 72 mph (63 kts) at Buckhorn Mountain and 64 mph (57 kts), 2 miles southwest of Loveland.  Damaging winds downed power lines over parts of Larimer and Boulder Counties.  At least 7000 residents in Boulder County alone lost power due to the strong winds.  The wind also caused two fires in Larimer County to quickly spread.  The larger fire near Masonville was human caused and threatened a dozen homes, forcing the evacuation of 65 homes.  The source of the smaller fire had not been determined.  A delivery truck was flipped onto a small van at the intersection of State Highways 72 and 93.  No one was injured in the accident.  In addition, blowing rocks shattered several car windows at an RTD Park and Ride at the same location.

The combination of an extensive snowpack from an early winter storm and a rainstorm on December 11, produced minor flooding on the Housatonic River in northwestern Connecticut. One to 2 inches of rain fell over a snowpack with a snow equivalent of around 2 inches, melting most of it. The net result was that Stevenson gage crested at 11.1, 0.1 of a foot above flood stage on the 11th. The following day the gage at Still crested at 12.8 feet, 0.6 of a foot above normal. No problems were reported to the National Weather Service as a result of this minor flooding.

On December 18, the second major rainstorm of the month took place after the second major winter storm of the season. Once again, copious rain (ranging from 2 to 4 inches), fell over an extensive snowpack. In northwestern Connecticut it was warm enough for all liquid rain. The excessive runoff once again caused minor flooding on the Housatonic River in Litchfield County. The river crested at 8.1 feet at Gaylordsville, 0.1 of a foot above flood stage. The crest at Stevenson was 11.14 feet, 0.14 above flood stage and the river at Still crested at 12.1 feet, 0.1 above flood stage. No unusual problems were reported to the National Weather Service as a result of this minor flooding.

The combination of runoff from the heavy rain during the first half of the day on the 11th, higher than normal tides from the recent full moon and a southeasterly flow into Delaware Bay and the Delaware River caused tidal flooding along the Delaware River and tidal sections of its tributaries during the morning and afternoon. The incoming afternoon tide also slowed the discharge from the inland rivers. Admiral Wilson Boulevard in Camden (Camden County) was under water for several hours. Several drivers were rescued by the Camden Police. The tide on the Delaware River in Burlington reached 10.37 feet above mean lower low water. Minor tidal flooding begins at 9.0 feet. In Philadelphia, the tide on the Delaware River reached 8.73 feet above mean lower low water. Minor tidal flooding begins at 8.2 feet. The low pressure system passed near Philadelphia during the morning of the 11th and a south to southeast flow preceded the low pressure system.

Intensifying low pressure tracking from the Mid Atlantic Coast...through the Gulf of Maine...to Nova Scotia brought heavy snow and near blizzard conditions to the region. Snow began during the evening of the 6th then continued...heavy at times...through the 7th before tapering to snow showers during the early morning hours of the 8th. Winds of 20 to 30 mph combined with the heavy snow to produce near blizzard conditions at times during the height of the storm. Storm total snow accumulations ranged from 8 to 14 inches.

The circulation around a low pressure system moving northeast along the Eastern Seaboard and a high pressure system which begrudgingly moved away from New England produced onshore flow during the day on the 14th. This led to minor tidal flooding along tidal sections of the Delaware River and its tributaries during the late afternoon and early evening of the 14th. The high tide in Burlington reached 10.35 feet above mean lower low water. Minor tidal flooding starts at 9.0 feet above mean lower low water. The high tide in Philadelphia reached 9.00 feet above mean lower low water. Minor tidal flooding starts in Philadelphia at 8.2 feet above mean lower low water. The high tide at Reedy Island (Delaware) reached 7.49 feet above mean lower low water. Minor flooding at Reedy Island starts at 7.2 feet above mean lower low water. The low pressure system responsible for the tidal flooding developed in the Gulf of Mexico on the 13th and moved northeast reaching the Alabama coastal waters on the evening of the 13th, the southern North Carolina coast the morning of the 14th, near Norfolk during the early afternoon of the 14th, crossed Delaware Bay during the early evening of the 14th and crossed across coastal New Jersey during the rest of the evening of the 14th.

The circulation around a low pressure system moving northeast along the Eastern Seaboard and a high pressure system which begrudgingly moved away from New England produced onshore flow during the day on the 14th. This led to minor tidal flooding along tidal sections of the Delaware River and its tributaries during the afternoon of the 14th. The high tide at Reedy Island reached 7.49 feet above mean lower low water. Minor flooding at Reedy Island starts at 7.2 feet above mean lower low water. The low pressure system responsible for the tidal flooding developed in the Gulf of Mexico on the 13th and moved northeast reaching the Alabama coastal waters on the evening of the 13th, the southern North Carolina coast the morning of the 14th, near Norfolk during the early afternoon of the 14th, crossed Delaware Bay during the early evening of the 14th and crossed across coastal New Jersey during the rest of the evening of the 14th.

A strong fall storm system moved across the Upper Midwest during the day. Between 0900 CST and 1500 CST the surface low deepened at about 1 mb per hour.  The strongest winds across Eastern Iowa and Northern Illinois coincided with the surface geostrophic maximum winds and a tropospheric fold that reached down to about 450 Mb.  During the high wind event, about 15,000 people were without power and at least 4 radio stations (WXLP, KBEA, KBOB, and KORB) were known to be off the air.  In Bettendorf, Iowa, part of the wall at Bowe Manufacturing collapsed around 1500 CST.  Fortunately the building was evacuated and police closed down U.S. 67 before the failure occurred.  Many observing sites recorded peak wind gusts in the 52 to 56 mph range (45 to 49 knots) with sustained winds of 30 to 40 mph (26 to 35 knots).  Maximum measured winds were 53 knots (61 mph) by KWQC TV in Davenport, Iowa and 54 knots (62 mph) in Pearl City, Illinois.  At Lock and Dam 11 in Dubuque, Iowa, wind equipment there carried a sustained wind of 49 knots (56 mph) at 1630 CST for about 5 to 10 minutes.  Given the magnitude of the event, known damage appeared to be minimal.  This may be due to the fact that most trees had already shed their leaves for the coming winter.

A wide area of 4-7 inches of snow, accompanied by strong and gusty winds of 20 to 30 mph with gusts to 40 mph at times, created difficult travel conditions and brief periods of whiteout across much of northwest Kansas.  The heaviest band of 6-7 inch snowfall occurred along a line from Russell Springs to Oakley to Selden to Lenora Kansas.

An upper level disturbance moving through southern Michigan intensified lake effect snows in northwest Lower Michigan.  Snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 inches were widespread across the Mancelona/Kalkaska/Kewadin area.
A band of heavy lake effect snow produced 6 to 10 inches of accumulation from Alden through Kalkaska to just north of Lake City.

An area of surface low pressure over the central plains moved northeast into northern Wisconsin, spreading snow across portions of southeast North Dakota.  One band of snow over central North Dakota merged with another band moving north out of northeast South Dakota.  This produced a finger of 6 to 8 inches of snow from eastern Sargent county in North Dakota, through the Fargo-Moorhead area, and into southwest Norman county in Minnesota.  Wind speeds increased after the heaviest snow ended.  The strong wind gusts did lower the visibility to near zero at times.  School and after school activities were cancelled in West Fargo, Fargo, Moorhead, and in Ransom county.  The North Dakota Highway Patrol advised no travel in rural Cass and Richland counties and flights out of Hector Airport were cancelled.

A surface low pressure system in the central plains tracked northeast into northern Wisconsin, producing snowfall over portions of northwest and west central Minnesota.  The most snow, about 6.5 inches, fell in Moorhead.  5 to 6 inches fell from Moorhead northeast toward the Lake of the Woods.  Wind speeds increased after the heaviest snow ended.  The visibility did lower to near zero at times, especially across the southern Red River Valley.  This caused school and after school activities to be cancelled in Moorhead.

Heavy lake effect snow impacted parts of Chippewa County, especially near Kinross during the daylight hours of the 1st (7 inches), and Sault Ste Marie and DeTour Village that night (both also around 7 inches).  Gusty winds produced substantial blowing and drifting.  Mackinac County had an isolated lake effect snow band produce 7 inches of snow in Curtis during the early morning hours of the 1st.

A band of heavy lake effect snow dumped around a foot of snow on central and northern Kalkaska County.  As the band pivoted north, Antrim County got into the act, with estimated snowfall amounts of 6 to 10 inches.

An area of low pressure moved across the region and produced some heavy rainfall late the 10th and early on the 11th. This rain fell on top of snow covered grounds and led to melting. The combination of the heavy rainfall and the melting snow produced widespread road flooding of over portions of Maryland during the  morning and afternoon hours. Rainfall amounts averaged 2 to 3 inches. Three water rescues were necessary in Frederick County. 40 to 50 cars had to be moved from a parking lot in a low lying area to prevent damage to the vehicles in Laurel. Several rivers and creeks also flooded. Baltimore County authorities closed a number of roads along the Patapsco River due to flooding. The River flooding persisted through the 13th. In Washington County, the Conococheague Creek at Fairview crested nearly 5 feet above flood stage, and the Antietam Creek at Sharpsburg crested 1.5  ft above flood stage at 5:30 am. In Montgomery County, The Potomac River at Little Falls crested almost a foot above flood stage, and The Seneca Creek at Dawsonville rose 2 feet above flood stage before cresting. In Frederick County, the Monocacy River at Frederick rose 6 ft above flood stage at 3 am and fell below flood stage at 2:30 pm, and the Potomac River at Point of Rocks crested 3.5 ft above flood stage on the 12th and fell below flood stage early on the 13th.

Moderate to heavy rainfall late on the 18th and on the 19th resulted in flash flooding and small stream flooding. In addition, an isolated severe thunderstorm knocked down large tree limbs in Huddleston.Runoff from heavy rainfall resulted in numerous creeks and streams out of their banks, some of which flooded roads in Grayson, Roanoke, Bath, Alleghany, Tazewell, Wythe, Carroll, and Bland Counties and in and near Sugar Grove. In Bland County, sections of some roads were washed away by the flood waters. In Pembroke, Doe Creek flooded and damaged a barber shop. Near Lexington route 11 was closed because flood waters pushed debris into the road. In Tazewell county, businesses were damaged as creeks overflowed their banks, especially in Bluefield. In Rockbridge County, Kerrs Creek flooded all along it's reach. In the town of Kerrs Creek it reached its highest level since 1985. Some houses had minor damage.  15 people were trapped on Big Springs Rd between Kerrs Creek and Lexington. There was damage to driveways and fences.  South river had significant flash flooding that caused minor damage to homes, and necessitated a water rescue.In Grayson County, Beaver Creek washed out a culvert (72" pipe), and damaged Rt 625.  There was significant flash flooding in the Fairview area along Chestnut Creek. A woman in her vehicle in the Daleheart area was washed into Meadow Creek and had to be rescued.
A strong low in the southern hemisphere near New Zealand produced surf of 4 to 8 feet along the south shores of Kauai and Oahu.  There were no reports of serious injuries or property damage.

A strong trade wind swell generated surf of 6 to 12 feet along the east- and southeast-facing shores of the Big Island of Hawaii and Kauai.  There were no reports of serious property damage or injuries.

Sleet and freezing rain began in the early morning of the 5th, and gradually changed to snow, which was heavy during the afternoon and evening of the 5th. From Pittsburgh south, the ice accumulation was noticeable, but further north, the precipitation was mainly snow. Snow accumulations by 7 AM on the 6th were (in inches): Glenshaw 11, Verona 9, Kittanning 10, Economy 9, Butler 6, Shippenville 9, Indiana 12, Brookville 10, New Castle 6, Mercer 7, Franklin 8, Canonsburg 8, Derry 10, and Irwin 10.

Gusty northwest winds around an intensifying low pressure system produced wind gusts to around 50 mph during the afternoon of the 29th in New Jersey. In Burlington County in Shamong Township, a 2-year-old girl was killed when a limb fell on her from a 40 foot tall tree. She apparently wandered into the area as her father was removing a wind damaged tree. Peak wind gusts included 52 mph in Cape May (Cape May County), 50 mph at the Marina within Atlantic City, 48 mph in Barnegat (Ocean County), 46 mph in Belmar (Monmouth County) and Wrightstown (Burlington County) and 39 mph in Trenton (Mercer County). The strong winds were caused by the difference in surface pressure between a powerful (about 975 millibars) low pressure system moving through the Saint Lawrence River Valley and a high pressure system building northeast from the Gulf Coast States.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Locally heavy bands of snow fell across portions of the North-Central Mountains, Front Range Foothills and Middle Park as a winter storm moved through the state.  Snowfall totals included 10 inches near Buckhorn Mountain, Middle Fork Camp and Tabernash.

The combination of spring astronomical tides associated with the new moon and a weak southeast flow caused by an approaching cold front from the west in conjunction with a high pressure system over the nearby Atlantic Ocean produced minor tidal flooding along the Delaware River. Minor tidal flooding also occurred along the tributaries of the Delaware River. At Reedy Island (Delaware), the tide on the Delaware River crested at 7.39 feet above mean lower low water at 1124 a.m. EST. Minor flooding begins at 7.2 feet above mean lower low water. Farther upstream, the Delaware River in Philadelphia crested at 8.47 feet above mean lower low water at 154 p.m. EST. Minor flooding begins at 8.2 feet above mean lower low water.

Snowfall of 6 to 12 inches was accompanied by freezing rain in some areas early in the event...and by winds strong enough to cause blowing and drifting snow as the snow accumulated. The 12 inch report was from Lake Andes. Schools were delayed or closed, and several school related athletic events were postponed. Travel was severely hampered.

Snowfall of 6 to 12 inches was accompanied by freezing rain in some areas early in the event...and by winds strong enough to cause blowing and drifting snow as the snow accumulated. The 12 inch report was from Lake Andes. Schools were delayed or closed, and several school related athletic events were postponed. Travel was severely hampered.
Snowfall of 6 to 10 inches was accompanied by areas of blowing and drifting snow, mainly late in the event. The snowfall caused numerous school closings and delays, and hampered travel.

A strong storm on the gulf coast moved slowly northeast up the east coast on the 14th to be near the Delmarva peninsula late that day.  The storm continued up the coast on the 15th to be in southeast Canada late that evening.  Snow started from around 5 AM near the Pennsylvania border to 9 AM in Oneida County.  This was a widespread 8 to 12 inch snow event across south central New York.  Higher snow amounts of 10 to 18 inches were across Onondaga, Oneida, and Madison Counties.  Across south central New York, sleet and freezing rain mixed in with the snow lowering amounts.  The snow caused numerous automobile accidents and closed schools.

A major winter storm brought heavy snow and strong winds to southern New England, dumping 1 to 3 feet of snow over a large area as it tracked slowly off the coast.  In northern Connecticut, snowfall amounts averaged between 12 and 20 inches, and had a major disruption on transportation due to the combination of poor visibility and snow covered roads.  Dozens of minor accidents were reported.Officially, the snowfall total at Bradley International Airport in Windsor Locks was 19.0 inches.  Other snowfall totals, as reported by trained spotters, included 20 inches in East Killingly and Dayville; 19 inches in Stafford Springs; 18 inches in Woodstock; 14 inches in Manchester, Eastford, and Putnam; and 12 inches in East Hartford, New Britain, and Vernon.

A long lasting winter storm brought blizzard conditions to much of southeast Idaho beginning the night of the 28th and peaking on December 29th and drawing to a close on the 30th.  The worst conditions occurred on the 29th and many major interstates closed due to the blizzard conditions.  Interstate 86 was closed from Pocatello to the interstate 84 interchange.  Interstate 84 was closed from Burley to the Utah state line.  Interstate 15 shut down south of Pocatello and State highway 37 was closed from Oneida County to American Falls.  Some details from the storm including snow totals were 13 inches at Galena Summit, 8 inches at Minidoka with 4 foot drifts, 12 inches at Driggs and 18 inches at Palisades with 4 feet drifts, 16 inches at Holbrook, 8 inches at Malad with 2 foot drifts, 12 inches at Kilgore with 3 foot drifts, 50 to 60 mph wind gusts in Pocatello, 12 to 14 inches at Hailey, 18 to 20 inches at Ketchum, over 300 road slideoffs and 60 crashes reported by the Idaho State Police, 12 inches at Sublett with whiteout conditions on the 29th, blizzard conditions on highway 91 at Swan Lake on the 29th, 9 inches at Swan Valley, 10 inches at Shoshone, 6 inches at McCammon with 2 foot drifts, 6 inches on the east benches of Pocatello, 6 inches at Burley with 3 foot drifts, 24 inches at Ashton, 10 inches at Bone, 12 inches at Springfield, 7 inches at Malta, 12 inches at Stone, 1 to 3 feet in Buist, 2 feet in Spencer, 18 inches at Island Park, 10 inches at Richfield, and 8 inches at Henry.  In addition to the interstate closures, several state highways and local roadways were closed during the day on the 29th.

As a cold high pressure system settled over New England, a series of low pressure systems developed off the Mid Atlantic Coast during Friday, December 5th and Saturday, December 6th.The first low pressure system developed along the North Carolina Coast during Friday morning.  As this low moved northeast, it intensified.  Light snow developed and quickly spread northeast across the area during the morning.  Snowfall became heavy across Northeast New Jersey during the afternoon. Between 4 and 7 pm that evening, a 6 to 10 inch snowfall occurred across this area.  There were major impacts to mass transit operations during the evening's "rush" hours.  As this low moved southeast of Long Island, snowfall intensity decreased and became light across the region.The second low pressure system developed further north and west along the DELMARVA Coast during Saturday morning.  As this low rapidly intensified, it moved slowly northeast.  Light snow became heavy across the entire region by noon.  Near blizzard conditions developed across parts of the area from late morning through the evening hours.  Wind gusts up to 35 mph combined with heavy falling snow created near "white out" conditions that reduced visibility to between 1/4 and 1/2 mile.  Major impacts to mass transit occurred across the entire region.Storm Total Snowfall amounts for this 2 day episode ranged from around 9 to 18 inches.  Here are selected snowfall amounts for:Bergen County - from 10.0 inches at Teterboro Airport to 14.3 inches at Rutherford.Essex County - from 12.5 inches at Nutley and Bloomfield to 17.5 inches at Caldwell.  At Newark Airport, 16.4 inches of snow was measured.Hudson County - from 9.0 inches at Kearny to 12.4 inches at Harrison.Passaic County - from 9.3 inches at Bloomingdale to 15.5 inches at Little Falls.Union County - from 13.0 inches at Union Township to 13.2 inches at Roselle.

Rain bands associated with Tropical Storm Jimena, which was passing more than 100 miles south, moved over coastal and upslope sections of the Hamakua, Hilo, Puna, and Kau districts on the Big Island of Hawaii, from near Hopokaa all the way southward to near Ka Lae (South Point).  The heavy rain and showers caused stream and drainage ditch flooding, and ponding of roadways in populated areas over the eastern half of the isle.  The rain and occasional easterly wind gusts of 35 to 40 mph caused isolated power outages as well.  However, no serious injuries or property damage were reported.
A weather spotter on the Big Island of Hawaii sighted a waterspout off the Kona coast.  No serious property damage or injuries were reported.
A strong low in the southern hemisphere near New Zealand produced surf of 4 to 8 feet along the south shores of Kauai and Oahu.  There were no reports of serious injuries or property damage.

An area of low pressure moved east across southern Ohio on December 5th.  Precipitation began during the early mornings hours of the 5th and ended around midnight on the 6th.  The precipitation started as a mixture of freezing rain, sleet and snow at most locations.  A quick transition to all snow occurred around daybreak.  By 9 am a band of moderate snow had developed along the U.S. Route 30 corridor from Mansfield to Canton.  The greatest snowfall rates occurred during the late afternoon and early evening hours as wrap around moisture from the low moved into the region.  A total of 6 to 9 inches of snow was reported across the area with the greatest amounts along and just south of U.S. 30.  Most locations also received a light glaze of ice from the freezing rain early in the storm.  Significant traffic delays and numerous accidents resulted from this storm.

Snow and ice fell across most of southwest and south central Kansas.  Snow mixed with sleet or ice pellets occurred southeast of a line from Ashland to Greensburg to Kinsley to Larned.  Strong north winds of 30 to 45 MPH caused plenty of blowing and drifting snow, with every county in the CWA reporting less than a quarter mile visibility for several hours, with occasional white out conditions.  Snowfall amounts were banded, with the two highest reports both being 6 inches, from southern Gray county and central Stanton county.  A 30 to 40 mile wide band of snowfall amounts from 4 to 5 inches fell from just north of Scott City southwest through northern Kearny county to southwest of Johnson City in Stanton County.  Another swath of snow 35 to 45 miles wide, also with snow amounts from 4 to 5 inches, fell from near Meade to Cimarron through Dodge City and Greensburg to near Medicine Lodge.  One more band of 4 to 5 inch amounts fell from extreme northwest Hodgeman County to just northwest of Ness City to near Hays.  Many schools and other planned activities were cancelled due to the weather, especially the low visibilities.  Numerous traffic accidents were reported in Liberal, Dodge City, Pratt, and Medicine Lodge.  Two jack-knifed semi-trailers, on a portion of Kansas Highway 96 between Scott City and Leoti, caused the highway to be closed for an hour and a half.  Zero visibility conditions closed U.S. Highway west of Ulysses for about 3 hours Tuesday afternoon on the 10th.
Snowfall of 6 to 10 inches was accompanied by areas of blowing and drifting snow, mainly late in the event. The snowfall caused numerous school closings and delays, and hampered travel.

The winter storm over central North Dakota began moving northeast producing strong northwest winds over western North Dakotain its wake. The winter storm warning for the west was upgraded to a blizzard warning due to the strong winds. Winds of 30 to45 mph with gust around 50 mph were producing near zero visibilities in blowing snow. No travel was advised by the North Dakota Highway Patrol over much of western North Dakota.

Strong northeast winds behind a cold front, sustained at 30 to 40 mph with gusts to over 65 mph, downed trees and power poles, and damaged roofs on several homes, across the island chain.  A 30-foot kiawe tree on the Big Island of Hawaii fell onto a housing unit and knocked it off its foundation at the Kawaihae Transitional Housing Program on the Kohala coast.  Cost of damages was not available.  No serious injuries were reported.
A storm low far northwest of the state produced surf of 10 to 20 feet along the northwest-facing shores of all the islands.  No serious property damage or injuries were reported.
A storm low far northwest of the state produced surf of 10 to 20 feet along the northwest-facing shores of all the islands.  No serious property damage or injuries were reported.

Strong south to southeast winds preceding an approaching cold front knocked down several trees, numerous tree limbs and wires in Eastern Pennsylvania. The wind damage was then further exacerbated in Chester County by a line of severe thunderstorms. In Philadelphia, three workers were injured when the wind knocked down a tarp and scaffolding on Arch Street. Two workers fell forty feet and the third worker was struck by debris. One worker broke his shoulder, the other two suffered cuts and bruises. Five vehicles on the street were damaged. In Upper Darby Township (Delaware County), the wind blew debris from the roof of the Tower Theater. After school activities in Delaware County were cancelled. About 500 homes and businesses in Delaware County lost power. Several trees and numerous limbs were knocked down in Bucks and Montgomery Townships. About 14,000 homes and businesses lost power in Bucks County and another 8,200 in Montgomery County. In Lehigh County, about 1,500 homes and businesses lost power. In Carbon County, a downed tree caused power outages to 1,500 homes and businesses in Jim Thorpe. A canopy was knocked down onto a parked van in Lehighton. Peak wind gusts included 49 mph at the Philadelphia International Airport, 45 mph in Gladwyne (Montgomery County) and 40 mph at the Lehigh Valley International Airport.

A High Wind Warning was issued for the coastal headlands of Oregon zones ORZ021/022 at 0345 PST on 12/04 and cancelled at 2054 PST on 12/04.  The observations listed above were the strongest verifying sustained winds and gusts recorded at each station.  Cape Blanco exceeded the warning criteria continuously from 0900 PST until 1700 PST.  Gold Beach exceeded warning criteria continuously from 1100 PST until 1500 PST.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Cape Arago recorded a gust to 58 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A High Wind Warning was issued for the coastal headlands of Oregon zones ORZ021/022 at 0345 PST on 12/04 and cancelled at 2054 PST on 12/04.  The observations listed above were the strongest verifying sustained winds and gusts recorded at each station.  Cape Blanco exceeded the warning criteria continuously from 0900 PST until 1700 PST.  Gold Beach exceeded warning criteria continuously from 1100 PST until 1500 PST.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Cape Blanco recorded a sustained wind of 44 mph.

A strong upper level storm moved into the Southern Plains resulting in a very strong pressure gradient over West Texas.  Westerly winds increased to 40 to 45 mph and gusted to as high as 67 mph over the South Plains area.  The high wind turned over several tractor trailers on Interstate 27 between Lubbock and Plainview, blew down power lines, and produced minor damage to homes.  Widespread blowing dust reduced the visibility to less than one quarter of a mile across much of the region.  The West Texas Mesonet recorded a number of high wind events across the region during the late morning through mid afternoon hours.  The measured peak wind gust at each of the stations exceeding high wind criteria follows: 67 mph gust 1 NE Morton in Cochran County, 65 mph gust at Reese Center in Lubbock County, 65 mph gust 3 N Plains in Yoakum County, 64 mph gust 2 NE Friona in Parmer County, 62 mph gust 1 NE Amherst in Lamb County, 62 mph gust 2 S Muleshoe in Bailey County, 61 mph gust 7 E Silverton in Briscoe County, 61 mph gust 3 N Hart in Castro County, 61 mph gust 2 NE Dimmitt in Castro County, 60 mph gust 6 S Anton in Hockley County, 60 mph gust 4 S Levelland in Hockley County, 60 mph gust 6 S Olton in Lamb County, and a 59 mph gust 1 S Plainview in Hale County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Clear skies and light winds behind a cold front lead to the first hard freeze of the season for parts of west central Florida. Overnight low temperatures in the low to mid 20s were found in Levy, Citrus, Hernando, and Sumter counties. Low temperatures included 20 degrees in Brooksville, 22 in Chiefland, 25 in Inverness, and around 30 degrees along the Hillsborough/Polk county line.

A major winter storm passed across Eastern Oregon and Southwestern Idaho Sunday and Monday December 28th and 29th. This system brought with it copious amounts of snow to the region. Snow fall amounts ranged from a few inches in the lower valleys to nearly a foot near Sumpter in  Baker County Oregon and  nearly 2 feet near Pine in the central mountains of Idaho. There were numerous reports of 6 to 12 inches of new snow. Strong winds on the 29th caused blowing and drifting snow across the Magic Valley.

Snow fall amounts ranged from a few inches in the lower valleys to nearly a foot near Sumpter in  Baker County Oregon and  nearly 2 feet near Pine in the central mountains of Idaho. There were numerous reports of 6 to 12 inches of new snow. Strong winds on the 29th caused blowing and drifting snow across the Magic Valley.

Snow started to fall shortly after dawn Friday in far southwestern Kansas, then quickly spread north and east across other parts of southwest and south central Kansas.  This snow basically fell south of a line from Johnson City to Garden City to Jetmore to Larned.  The heaviest snow reported was in the Medicine Lodge area, where 9 inches fell.  6 to 8 inches of new snow fell east of a Jetmore to Greensburg to Coldwater line, including the communities of Pratt and St. John.  From 2 to 4 inches of snowfall was reported across the remainder of southern sections of southwest Kansas.  Numerous traffic accidents were reported in the Garden City area, but none with serious injury.

Intensifying low pressure tracking along the Maine coast to central Nova Scotia produced heavy snow across the region. The snow started during the early morning hours of the 15th. Very heavy snow fell during the 15th with snowfall rates of 2 to 3 inches per hour at times...particularly across northern portions of the region. Strong winds produced near blizzard conditions at times with extensive blowing and drifting snow along with visibilities reduced below a quarter mile at times. Storm total snow accumulations generally ranged from 6 to 12 inches along the Downeast coast...with localized totals to around 18 inches. Across interior Downeast areas...storm total snow accumulations generally ranged from 10 to 20 inches...with localized totals to around 24 inches. Across central and northern areas...storm total snow accumulations generally ranged from 16 to 24 inches with localized totals to around 30 inches. The 27.3 inch storm total at Caribou ( 27.1 inches of which fell during the 15th ) represented the second greatest snowfall ever recorded.

The combination of an onshore flow and higher than normal tides from the recent full moon caused minor tidal flooding during the morning high tide on the 11th from Atlantic County northward. Heavy rain was also falling during the high tide. This slowed the discharge of rain water into the ocean and exacerbated the poor drainage flooding. Poor drainage street flooding occurred in Atlantic City and Margate (Both Atlantic County). The high tide reached 7.22 feet above mean lower low water in Atlantic City and 7.01 feet above mean lower low water at Sandy Hook. Minor tidal flooding begins at 6.7 feet above mean lower low water. The onshore flow was caused by the combination of a high pressure system that was over the Canadian Maritimes and a low pressure system that formed over the Tennessee Valley on the 10th and passed near Philadelphia and through New Jersey during the morning of the 11th.

The precipitation started as a mixture of freezing rain, sleet and snow at most locations.  A quick transition to all snow occurred around daybreak.  By 9 am a band of moderate snow had developed along the U.S. Route 30 corridor from Mansfield to Canton.  The greatest snowfall rates occurred during the late afternoon and early evening hours as wrap around moisture from the low moved into the region.  A total of 6 to 9 inches of snow was reported across the area with the greatest amounts along and just south of U.S. 30.  Most locations also received a light glaze of ice from the freezing rain early in the storm.  Significant traffic delays and numerous accidents resulted from this storm.

A Winter Storm Warning was issued for the above zones above 3500 feet effective at the above listed times.  The warning for CAZ080 was downgraded to a Snow Advisory at 1005 PST on 12/09.  No verifying reports were recieved for these warnings.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: See below.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A non-thunderstorm high wind event from late on the 12th to the early morning hours on the14th knocked down trees and power lines in portions of Franklin County and knocked down trees across Patrick, Carroll, Grayson, Bedford, Botetourt, Craig, Smyth, Roanoke, Montgomery, Bland, Tazewell, and Amherst Counties, as well as in Lexington, Rural Retreat, Laurel Fork, Willis, and 2 miles east of Covington.In Patrick County, trees were toppled onto power lines. In Grayson County, the roof was blown off of a building. In Roanoke County, winds downed a large tree limb which damaged a vehicle. In Floyd County, wind blew out a window at a business.A wind gust of 60 mph was measured at Hot Springs Airport in Bath County.

A non-thunderstorm high wind event from late on the 12th to the early morning hours on the14th knocked down trees and power lines in portions of Franklin County and knocked down trees across Patrick, Carroll, Grayson, Bedford, Botetourt, Craig, Smyth, Roanoke, Montgomery, Bland, Tazewell, and Amherst Counties, as well as in Lexington, Rural Retreat, Laurel Fork, Willis, and 2 miles east of Covington.In Patrick County, trees were toppled onto power lines. In Grayson County, the roof was blown off of a building. In Roanoke County, winds downed a large tree limb which damaged a vehicle. In Floyd County, wind blew out a window at a business.A wind gust of 60 mph was measured at Hot Springs Airport in Bath County.

The circulation around a low pressure system moving northeast along the Eastern Seaboard and a high pressure system which begrudgingly moved away from New England produced onshore flow during the day on the 14th. This led to minor tidal flooding along tidal sections of the Delaware River and its tributaries during the late afternoon and early evening of the 14th. The high tide in Burlington reached 10.35 feet above mean lower low water. Minor tidal flooding starts at 9.0 feet above mean lower low water. The high tide in Philadelphia reached 9.00 feet above mean lower low water. Minor tidal flooding starts in Philadelphia at 8.2 feet above mean lower low water. The high tide at Reedy Island (Delaware) reached 7.49 feet above mean lower low water. Minor flooding at Reedy Island starts at 7.2 feet above mean lower low water. The low pressure system responsible for the tidal flooding developed in the Gulf of Mexico on the 13th and moved northeast reaching the Alabama coastal waters on the evening of the 13th, the southern North Carolina coast the morning of the 14th, near Norfolk during the early afternoon of the 14th, crossed Delaware Bay during the early evening of the 14th and crossed across coastal New Jersey during the rest of the evening of the 14th.

The river forecast point, Cooks Falls on the Beaver Kill, rose to its flood stage of 10 feet briefly on the 11th.  The crest was at 10.01 feet at 6:30 PM EST.  A cold front slowly moved northeast through the area on the 11th.  It brought 1 to 2 inches of rain, basin averaged.  The rain and warmer weather also melted most of the snow that fell earlier in the week.  This added up to another inch of runoff.  The flooding was minor.

Intensifying low pressure tracking from the Mid Atlantic Coast...through the Gulf of Maine...to Nova Scotia brought heavy snow and near blizzard conditions to the region. Snow began during the evening of the 6th then continued...heavy at times...through the 7th before tapering to snow showers during the early morning hours of the 8th. Winds of 20 to 30 mph combined with the heavy snow to produce near blizzard conditions at times during the height of the storm. Storm total snow accumulations generally ranged from 12 to 20 inches at lower elevation areas. Persistent upsloping winds into the mountains enhanced accumulations across higher terrain areas where total snow accumulations of 20 to 35 inches were reported.

Snow started to fall shortly after dawn Friday in far southwestern Kansas, then quickly spread north and east across other parts of southwest and south central Kansas.  This snow basically fell south of a line from Johnson City to Garden City to Jetmore to Larned.  The heaviest snow reported was in the Medicine Lodge area, where 9 inches fell.  6 to 8 inches of new snow fell east of a Jetmore to Greensburg to Coldwater line, including the communities of Pratt and St. John.  From 2 to 4 inches of snowfall was reported across the remainder of southern sections of southwest Kansas.  Numerous traffic accidents were reported in the Garden City area, but none with serious injury.

Snow started to fall shortly after dawn Friday in far southwestern Kansas, then quickly spread north and east across other parts of southwest and south central Kansas.  This snow basically fell south of a line from Johnson City to Garden City to Jetmore to Larned.  The heaviest snow reported was in the Medicine Lodge area, where 9 inches fell.  6 to 8 inches of new snow fell east of a Jetmore to Greensburg to Coldwater line, including the communities of Pratt and St. John.  From 2 to 4 inches of snowfall was reported across the remainder of southern sections of southwest Kansas.  Numerous traffic accidents were reported in the Garden City area, but none with serious injury.

Moderate to heavy rainfall late on the 18th and on the 19th resulted in flash flooding and small stream flooding. In addition, an isolated severe thunderstorm knocked down large tree limbs in Huddleston.Runoff from heavy rainfall resulted in numerous creeks and streams out of their banks, some of which flooded roads in Grayson, Roanoke, Bath, Alleghany, Tazewell, Wythe, Carroll, and Bland Counties and in and near Sugar Grove. In Bland County, sections of some roads were washed away by the flood waters. In Pembroke, Doe Creek flooded and damaged a barber shop. Near Lexington route 11 was closed because flood waters pushed debris into the road. In Tazewell county, businesses were damaged as creeks overflowed their banks, especially in Bluefield. In Rockbridge County, Kerrs Creek flooded all along it's reach. In the town of Kerrs Creek it reached its highest level since 1985. Some houses had minor damage.  15 people were trapped on Big Springs Rd between Kerrs Creek and Lexington. There was damage to driveways and fences.  South river had significant flash flooding that caused minor damage to homes, and necessitated a water rescue.In Grayson County, Beaver Creek washed out a culvert (72" pipe), and damaged Rt 625.  There was significant flash flooding in the Fairview area along Chestnut Creek. A woman in her vehicle in the Daleheart area was washed into Meadow Creek and had to be rescued.

A High Wind Warning was issued for the coastal headlands of ORZ021/022 at 1434 PST on 12/23 and expired at 0400 PST on 12/24.  The spotter report above did not give a specific time, but judging from other nearby observations, it almost certainly occurred within the warning window.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Cape Blanco recorded a gust to 77 mph at this time.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Snow started to fall shortly after dawn Friday in far southwestern Kansas, then quickly spread north and east across other parts of southwest and south central Kansas.  This snow basically fell south of a line from Johnson City to Garden City to Jetmore to Larned.  The heaviest snow reported was in the Medicine Lodge area, where 9 inches fell.  6 to 8 inches of new snow fell east of a Jetmore to Greensburg to Coldwater line, including the communities of Pratt and St. John.  From 2 to 4 inches of snowfall was reported across the remainder of southern sections of southwest Kansas.  Numerous traffic accidents were reported in the Garden City area, but none with serious injury.

A major winter storm passed across Eastern Oregon and Southwestern Idaho Sunday and Monday December 28th and 29th. This system brought with it copious amounts of snow to the region. Snow fall amounts ranged from a few inches in the lower valleys to nearly a foot near Sumpter in  Baker County Oregon and  nearly 2 feet near Pine in the central mountains of Idaho. There were numerous reports of 6 to 12 inches of new snow. Strong winds on the 29th caused blowing and drifting snow across the Magic Valley.

An area of low pressure moved east across southern Ohio on December 5th.  Precipitation began during the early mornings hours of the 5th and ended around midnight on the 6th.  The precipitation started as a mixture of freezing rain, sleet and snow at most locations.  A quick transition to all snow occurred around daybreak.  By 9 am a band of moderate snow had developed along the U.S. Route 30 corridor from Mansfield to Canton.  The greatest snowfall rates occurred during the late afternoon and early evening hours as wrap around moisture from the low moved into the region.  A total of 6 to 9 inches of snow was reported across the area with the greatest amounts along and just south of U.S. 30.  Most locations also received a light glaze of ice from the freezing rain early in the storm.  Significant traffic delays and numerous accidents resulted from this storm.

The combination of spring astronomical tides associated with the new moon and a weak southeast flow caused by an approaching cold front from the west in conjunction with a high pressure system over the nearby Atlantic Ocean produced minor tidal flooding along the Delaware River. Minor tidal flooding also occurred along the tributaries of the Delaware River. In Camden County, the Cooper River flooded Admiral Wilson Boulevard near Baird Boulevard. Traffic was limited to one lane in each direction and traffic was backed up for up to one mile in each direction during the afternoon of the 24th. At Reedy Island (Delaware), the tide on the Delaware River crested at 7.39 feet above mean lower low water at 1124 a.m. EST. Minor flooding begins at 7.2 feet above mean lower low water. Farther upstream, the Delaware River in Philadelphia crested at 8.47 feet above mean lower low water at 154 p.m. EST. Minor flooding begins at 8.2 feet above mean lower low water. In Burlington City (Burlington County), the Delaware River crested at 9.89 feet above mean lower low water. Minor flooding begins at 9.0 feet above mean lower low water.

The combination of runoff from the heavy rain during the first half of the day on the 11th, higher than normal tides from the recent full moon and a southeasterly flow into Delaware Bay and the Delaware River caused tidal flooding along the Delaware River and tidal sections of its tributaries during the morning and afternoon. The incoming afternoon tide also slowed the discharge from the inland rivers. Admiral Wilson Boulevard in Camden (Camden County) was under water for several hours. Several drivers were rescued by the Camden Police. The tide on the Delaware River in Burlington reached 10.37 feet above mean lower low water. Minor tidal flooding begins at 9.0 feet. In Philadelphia, the tide on the Delaware River reached 8.73 feet above mean lower low water. Minor tidal flooding begins at 8.2 feet. The low pressure system passed near Philadelphia during the morning of the 11th and a south to southeast flow preceded the low pressure system.

The circulation around a low pressure system moving northeast along the Eastern Seaboard and a high pressure system which begrudgingly moved away from New England produced onshore flow during the day on the 14th. This led to minor tidal flooding along tidal sections of the Delaware River and its tributaries during the late afternoon and early evening of the 14th. The high tide in Burlington reached 10.35 feet above mean lower low water. Minor tidal flooding starts at 9.0 feet above mean lower low water. The high tide in Philadelphia reached 9.00 feet above mean lower low water. Minor tidal flooding starts in Philadelphia at 8.2 feet above mean lower low water. The high tide at Reedy Island (Delaware) reached 7.49 feet above mean lower low water. Minor flooding at Reedy Island starts at 7.2 feet above mean lower low water. The low pressure system responsible for the tidal flooding developed in the Gulf of Mexico on the 13th and moved northeast reaching the Alabama coastal waters on the evening of the 13th, the southern North Carolina coast the morning of the 14th, near Norfolk during the early afternoon of the 14th, crossed Delaware Bay during the early evening of the 14th and crossed across coastal New Jersey during the rest of the evening of the 14th.

The third major December rainstorm of 2003 took place on Christmas Eve across northwestern Connecticut. One to two inches of rain fell on very saturated ground. The rain melted additional snow which caused more excessive runoff and some minor flooding again on the Housatonic in Litchfield County on Christmas Day. The river at Gaylordsville crested at 8.85 feet, 0.85 above flood stage. The river at Stevenson crested at 11.53 feet, 0.53 above flood stage. Finally, the river at Falls Village crested at 7.79 feet, 0.79 above flood stage.

A deep low far north of Hawaii and a strong trade wind swell caused surf of 10 to 20 feet along the north- and east-facing shores of all the islands.  No serious injuries or property damage were reported, though water coming ashore occasionally closed roads along affected shorelines.

A powerful winter storm affected Southern Montana and Northern Wyoming during a three day period from December 26, 2003 through December 28, 2003.  A strong arctic front ushered in colder air across the area as a deep trough moved across Montana. A moist southwest flow aloft moved over this cold airmass at the surface and produced a prolonged period of snow across the area.  In addition...a deep surface low moved across Wyoming into South Dakota resulting in strong northerly winds of 25 to 40 mph which produced significant blowing and drifting snow. Polar high pressure settled into Florida producing clear skies and near calm winds.  Strong radiational cooling dropped low temperatures to 31 degrees in Bronson, 28 in Chiefland, 30 in Inverness, and 28 near Brooksville.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Light winds and clear skies allowed temperatures to drop to 30 degrees near Bronson.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A non-thunderstorm high wind event from late on the 12th to the early morning hours on the14th knocked down trees and power lines in portions of Franklin County and knocked down trees across Patrick, Carroll, Grayson, Bedford, Botetourt, Craig, Smyth, Roanoke, Montgomery, Bland, Tazewell, and Amherst Counties, as well as in Lexington, Rural Retreat, Laurel Fork, Willis, and 2 miles east of Covington.In Patrick County, trees were toppled onto power lines. In Grayson County, the roof was blown off of a building. In Roanoke County, winds downed a large tree limb which damaged a vehicle. In Floyd County, wind blew out a window at a business.A wind gust of 60 mph was measured at Hot Springs Airport in Bath County.

Intensifying low pressure tracking along the Maine coast to central Nova Scotia produced heavy snow across the region. The snow started during the early morning hours of the 15th. Very heavy snow fell during the 15th with snowfall rates of 2 to 3 inches per hour at times...particularly across northern portions of the region. Strong winds produced near blizzard conditions at times with extensive blowing and drifting snow along with visibilities reduced below a quarter mile at times. Storm total snow accumulations generally ranged from 6 to 12 inches along the Downeast coast...with localized totals to around 18 inches. Across interior Downeast areas...storm total snow accumulations generally ranged from 10 to 20 inches...with localized totals to around 24 inches. Across central and northern areas...storm total snow accumulations generally ranged from 16 to 24 inches with localized totals to around 30 inches. The 27.3 inch storm total at Caribou ( 27.1 inches of which fell during the 15th ) represented the second greatest snowfall ever recorded.

The combination of runoff from the heavy rain during the first half of the day on the 11th, higher than normal tides from the recent full moon and a southeasterly flow into Delaware Bay and the Delaware River caused tidal flooding along the Delaware River and tidal sections of its tributaries during the afternoon. The incoming afternoon tide also slowed the discharge from the inland rivers and streams, many of which were flooding. The tide on the Delaware River in Burlington (Burlington County, New Jersey) reached 10.37 feet above mean lower low water. Minor tidal flooding begins at 9.0 feet. In Philadelphia, the tide on the Delaware River reached 8.73 feet above mean lower low water. Minor tidal flooding begins at 8.2 feet. The low pressure system passed near Philadelphia during the morning of the 11th and a south to southeast flow preceded the low pressure system.

The combination of an onshore flow and higher than normal tides from the recent full moon caused minor tidal flooding during the morning high tide on the 11th from Atlantic County northward. Heavy rain was also falling during the high tide. This slowed the discharge of rain water into the ocean and exacerbated the poor drainage flooding. Poor drainage street flooding occurred in Atlantic City and Margate (Both Atlantic County). The high tide reached 7.22 feet above mean lower low water in Atlantic City and 7.01 feet above mean lower low water at Sandy Hook. Minor tidal flooding begins at 6.7 feet above mean lower low water. The onshore flow was caused by the combination of a high pressure system that was over the Canadian Maritimes and a low pressure system that formed over the Tennessee Valley on the 10th and passed near Philadelphia and through New Jersey during the morning of the 11th.

Intensifying low pressure tracking from the Mid Atlantic Coast...through the Gulf of Maine...to Nova Scotia brought heavy snow and near blizzard conditions to the region. Snow began during the night of the 6th then continued...heavy at times...through the 7th before tapering to snow showers during the early morning hours of the 8th. Winds of 20 to 30 mph combined with the heavy snow to produce near blizzard conditions at times during the height of the storm. Storm total snow accumulations generally ranged from 8 to 14 inches...though localized totals ranging from around 18 inches to less than 8 inches were also reported.

Rapidly intensifying low pressure tracking through the Saint Lawrence River Valley produced strong damaging south to southeast winds across the region. Wind gusts of 50 to 60 mph were common...with gusts in excess of 60 mph occurring along the coast with onshore winds. A peak wind gust to 62 mph was reported at Stonington. The winds snapped branches and toppled trees which fell on powerlines contributing to power outages. Several thousand customers lost power at various times. The winds also damaged roofs and signs.

Rapidly intensifying low pressure tracking through the Saint Lawrence River Valley produced strong damaging south to southeast winds across the region. Wind gusts of 50 to 60 mph were common...with gusts in excess of 60 mph occurring along the coast with onshore winds. A peak wind gust to 62 mph was reported at Stonington. The winds snapped branches and toppled trees which fell on powerlines contributing to power outages. Several thousand customers lost power at various times. The winds also damaged roofs and signs.

Freezing rain caused widespread icing of roads and other surfaces. The icing severely hampered travel, with numerous accidents reported. The freezing rain was followed by 1 to 3 inches of snow, with areas of blowing snow as winds increased. Numerous schools were closed or delayed, and some other events were cancelled.
Snowfall varied from 2 to 5 inches. The snow was accompanied by a little freezing rain at the start of the event. Travel was hampered, and some schools were closed or delayed.
Snowfall varied from 2 to 5 inches. The snow was accompanied by a little freezing rain at the start of the event. Travel was hampered, and some schools were closed or delayed.
Snowfall varied from 2 to 5 inches. The snow was accompanied by a little freezing rain at the start of the event. Travel was hampered, and some schools were closed or delayed.
