EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms along a strong cold front produced damaging winds that knocked down several trees and power lines at the intersection of Nicholas Parkway and 4th Avenue Southeast.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of heavy rain between 5 a.m. and Noon EST on the 11th and runoff from the melting snow produced widespread poor drainage flooding. It eventually led to flooding along the Maurice River two days later. Storm totals averaged 2.0 to 2.5 inches. The Maurice River at Norma was above its 4 foot flood stage from 230 a.m. EST on the 13th through 1 a.m. EST on the 14th. It crested at 4.10 feet at 830 a.m. EST at 830 a.m. EST on the 13th.      Storm totals included 2.50 inches in Newport, 2.12 inches in Millville and 2.00 inches at Seabrook. The heavy rain was caused by an intense low pressure system at both the surface and aloft that developed over the Southern Plains on the 9th. The primary low pressure system moved toward the Great Lakes on the morning of the 10th while a secondary low pressure system was forming near the upper air support over the Tennessee Valley. This secondary low pressure system continued to intensify and was located over North Carolina the evening of the 10th, near Philadelphia around 7 a.m. EST on the 11th and in western Connecticut early in the evening on the 11th. This secondary low pressure system helped wring the moisture in the atmosphere from the Gulf of Mexico and the Atlantic Ocean onto the region.

A second storm developed quickly on the heels of the first winter storm . This storm affected the region from the evening of the 5th through the morning of the 6th. The second storm produced another 5 to 6  inches of snow across North and Central Maryland. A medical condition rendered a Frederick, MD woman unconscious after  she walked outside to check her mailbox on the 6th. The elderly woman died of hypothermia on the 7th.

Gusty northwest winds around an intensifying low pressure system produced wind gusts to around 45 mph during the afternoon of the 29th in Eastern Pennsylvania. In Monroe County, in Brodheadsville, shingles were torn away from one home. Glass was shattered at another home. Pennsylvania State Route 715 was closed because of downed trees and wires. In Carbon County, much of Hauto lost power. In Berks County, about 2,500 homes and businesses lost power, with the greatest concentration in and around Hamburg. In Montgomery County in Upper Merion Township, a snapped pole caused power outages that affected nearby businesses. Peak wind gusts included 46 mph at the Philadelphia International Airport, 45 mph in Doylestown (Bucks County), 44 mph in Reading (Berks County), 43 mph in Mount Pocono (Monroe County), 41 mph at the Lehigh Valley International Airport and 40 mph in Pottstown (Montgomery County). The strong winds were caused by the difference in surface pressure between a powerful (about 975 millibars) low pressure system moving through the Saint Lawrence River Valley and a high pressure system building northeast from the Gulf Coast States.

A non-thunderstorm high wind event from late on the 12th to the early morning hours on the14th knocked down trees and power lines in portions of Franklin County and knocked down trees across Patrick, Carroll, Grayson, Bedford, Botetourt, Craig, Smyth, Roanoke, Montgomery, Bland, Tazewell, and Amherst Counties, as well as in Lexington, Rural Retreat, Laurel Fork, Willis, and 2 miles east of Covington.In Patrick County, trees were toppled onto power lines. In Grayson County, the roof was blown off of a building. In Roanoke County, winds downed a large tree limb which damaged a vehicle. In Floyd County, wind blew out a window at a business.A wind gust of 60 mph was measured at Hot Springs Airport in Bath County.

The combination of heavy rain between 3 a.m. and 10 a.m. EST on the 11th and the additional runoff from the melting snow produced widespread poor drainage and some isolated creek flooding in Gloucester County. The incoming tide during the afternoon slowed the runoff and exacerbated the flooding. Storm totals averaged 1.5 to 2.0 inches. The Raccoon Creek in Swedesboro was above its 13 foot flood stage from 101 p.m. EST through 815 p.m. EST on the 11th. It crested at 13.31 feet at 315 p.m. EST.      Storm totals included 1.78 inches in West Deptford. The heavy rain was caused by an intense low pressure system at both the surface and aloft that developed over the Southern Plains on the 9th. The primary low pressure system moved toward the Great Lakes on the morning of the 10th while a secondary low pressure system was forming near the upper air support over the Tennessee Valley. This secondary low pressure system continued to intensify and was located over North Carolina the evening of the 10th, near Philadelphia around 7 a.m. EST on the 11th and in western Connecticut early in the evening on the 11th. This secondary low pressure system helped wring the moisture in the atmosphere from the Gulf of Mexico and the Atlantic Ocean onto the region.

The combination of heavy rain between 3 a.m. and 10 a.m. EST on the 11th and the additional runoff from the melting snow produced widespread poor drainage flooding and creek flooding in Montgomery County. Storm totals averaged between 1.0 and 2.0 inches. Many creeks in the southeastern part of the county flooded. The flood waters also loosened the soil and knocked over several trees.Flooding along the Pennypack Creek affected Horsham Township, Upper Moreland Township, Lower Moreland Township and Hatboro Borough. In Horsham Township, flooding from the Pennypack Creek swept one vehicle from Blair Mill Road. A school bus became stranded in flood waters on Norwyn Drive. Four roads in the township were closed including Pennsylvania State Route 611. The worst property damage occurred in the Hidden Creek development near Meetinghouse Road as homes were flooded.  In Upper Moreland Township, flooding along the Pennypack Creek caused the evacuation of tenants at the Robert Bruce Apartments after flood waters reached the electrical boxes in the basements. Flooding also closed several roads in the township. In Hatboro Borough, flooding along the Pennypack caused the evacuation of twenty units in the Woodwinds Condominiums. Another school bus became stuck in flood waters. In Lower Moreland Township, firefighters had to use boats to rescue motorists that drove around barricades, particularly along Philmont Avenue. In the Wissahickon River Basin, flooding along the Sandy Run forced the closure of the Pennsylvania Turnpike at the Fort Washington Interchange in Upper Dublin Township. The interchange turned into a lake. Vehicles became stuck on the ramps. The Sandy Run Creek displaced a foot bridge in the Fort Washington State Park. Five hundred acres of rye was flooded along the Wissahickon Creek in Whitemarsh Township. Wissahickon flooding also forced the closure of several roads in Springfield Township.    The East Branch of the Perkiomen Creek in Schwenksville was above its 7 foot flood stage from 850 a.m. through 620 p.m. EST on the 11th. It crested at 7.69 feet at 1130 a.m. EST. The Wissahickon Creek at Fort Washington crested at 10.68 feet. Storm totals included 1.76 inches in Willow Grove, 1.31 inches in Green Lane, 1.23 inches in Palm and 1.07 inches in Pottstown. The heavy rain was caused by an intense low pressure system at both the surface and aloft that developed over the Southern Plains on the 9th. The primary low pressure system moved toward the Great Lakes on the morning of the 10th while a secondary low pressure system was forming near the upper air support over the Tennessee Valley. This secondary low pressure system continued to intensify and was located over North Carolina the evening of the 10th, near Philadelphia around 7 a.m. EST on the 11th and in western Connecticut early in the evening on the 11th. This secondary low pressure system helped wring the moisture in the atmosphere from the Gulf of Mexico and the Atlantic Ocean onto the region.

The first in a pair of low pressure systems moved across the region late on the 4th through midday on the 5th. This system produced 5 to 9 inches of snow across North and Central Maryland. As a result the roads were treacherous in many places. Several automobile accidents were reported. One death was recorded due to injuries from car a accident. Several non-life threatening injuries were also reported across Maryland. Power outages were also reported in Allegany County.

The first in a pair of low pressure systems tracked across the region on the 4th and 5th. This system brought light snowto portions of Lower Southern Maryland. Snow totals averaged 1 to 2 inches.  Three fatalities were reported, two from shoveling snow and one from an automobile accident. Other minor, non life threatening injuries were also reported by the Emergency and Law Enforcement Officers.

The third of three major December rainstorms of 2003 took place on Christmas Eve across eastern New York. One to two inches of rain on very saturated ground. The rain melted additional snow causing more excessive runoff and some minor flooding on the Esopus Creek, the Wappingers Creek. as well as the Mettawee and Hoosic Rivers. The flooding lingered into Christmas day. On the Esopus Creek in Ulster County, a crest of 11.97 feet took place at  Mount Tremper, nearly a foot above flood stage. The gage at Allaben reported a crest of 7.87 feet, 0.87 above flood stage. The Mettawee at Granville in Washington County reported a crest of 8.91 feet, nearly 2 feet above the flood stage. On the Hoosic in Rensselaer County, the river crested at 12.26 feet, slightly above the 12-foot flood stage. Despite this flooding being a bit more significant than the previous two during this month, no unusual problems were reported to the National Weather Service.

High surf, in excess of 8 feet broke over the Ocean Beach pier. Wind gusts in excess of 45 mph also broke power poles and downed trees along the San Diego County Coast, the Inland Empire, and the Coachella Valley. A lightning strike near a soccer game caused a minor injury to an 18 year old male spectator.

High surf, in excess of 8 feet broke over the Ocean Beach pier. Wind gusts in excess of 45 mph also broke power poles and downed trees along the San Diego County Coast, the Inland Empire, and the Coachella Valley. A lightning strike near a soccer game caused a minor injury to an 18 year old male spectator.

High surf, in excess of 8 feet broke over the Ocean Beach pier. Wind gusts in excess of 45 mph also broke power poles and downed trees along the San Diego County Coast, the Inland Empire, and the Coachella Valley. A lightning strike near a soccer game caused a minor injury to an 18 year old male spectator.

An area of low pressure moved east across southern Ohio on December 5th.  Precipitation began during the early mornings hours of the 5th and ended around midnight on the 6th.  The precipitation started as a mixture of freezing rain, sleet and snow at most locations.  A quick transition to all snow occurred around daybreak.  By 9 am a band of moderate snow had developed along the U.S. Route 30 corridor from Mansfield to Canton.  The greatest snowfall rates occurred during the late afternoon and early evening hours as wrap around moisture from the low moved into the region.  A total of 6 to 9 inches of snow was reported across the area with the greatest amounts along and just south of U.S. 30.  Most locations also received a light glaze of ice from the freezing rain early in the storm.  Significant traffic delays and numerous accidents resulted from this storm.
Snowfall varied from 2 to 5 inches. The snow was accompanied by areas of blowing and drifting snow as winds increased. Travel was hampered, and some schools were closed or delayed.
Snowfall varied from 2 to 5 inches. The snow was accompanied by areas of blowing and drifting snow as winds increased. Travel was hampered, and some schools were closed or delayed.
Snowfall varied from 1 to 3 inches. The snow was accompanied by freezing rain at the start of the event. Travel was hampered because of icy roads, and some schools were closed or delayed.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Route 837 flooded.
Little Deer Creek flooded north of Russellton
Dodds Road flooded in Middlesex Twp.
Route 917 flooded in Fallowfield Twp.
2 roads flooded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The third major December rainstorm of 2003 took place on Christmas Eve across northwestern Connecticut. One to two inches of rain fell on very saturated ground. The rain melted additional snow which caused more excessive runoff and some minor flooding again on the Housatonic in Litchfield County on Christmas Day. The river at Gaylordsville crested at 8.85 feet, 0.85 above flood stage. The river at Stevenson crested at 11.53 feet, 0.53 above flood stage. Finally, the river at Falls Village crested at 7.79 feet, 0.79 above flood stage.

The third major December rainstorm of 2003 took place on Christmas Eve across northwestern Connecticut. One to two inches of rain fell on very saturated ground. The rain melted additional snow which caused more excessive runoff and some minor flooding again on the Housatonic in Litchfield County on Christmas Day. The river at Gaylordsville crested at 8.85 feet, 0.85 above flood stage. The river at Stevenson crested at 11.53 feet, 0.53 above flood stage. Finally, the river at Falls Village crested at 7.79 feet, 0.79 above flood stage.

A powerful winter storm affected Southern Montana and Northern Wyoming during a three day period from December 26, 2003 through December 28, 2003.  A strong arctic front ushered in colder air across the area as a deep trough moved across Montana. A moist southwest flow aloft moved over this cold airmass at the surface and produced a prolonged period of snow across the area.  In addition...a deep surface low moved across Wyoming into South Dakota resulting in strong northerly winds of 25 to 40 mph which produced significant blowing and drifting snow. The following is an extensive list of snowfall and drifting reports:6 inches 10E Baker ; 8 inches with 4-5ft drifts 15N Plevna; 6 inches with 2-3ft drifts 1NNW Baker; 10 inches with 4ft drifts and 50ft visibilities 6NE Albion;  12 inches with 4-5ft drifts 7W Ekalaka; 12-18 inches with 4ft drifts 14E Ashland; 18-24 inches with 4-5ft drifts 5E Lame Deer; 11 inches in Billings; 13 inches in Lockwood; 12 inches with 3ft drifts in Lavina; 7 inches with 2ft drifts and 500 yds visibility 4E Sumatra; 18 inches with 2-4ft drifts and 1/4 mile visibility in Pryor; 6 inches 2S Livingston; 6 inches with 4-6ft drifts in Springdale; 6 inches with 3ft drifts and 100ft visibilities in Melville; 10 inches with 6ft drifts and 100ft visibilities 13E Judith Gap; 13 inches with 4-5ft drifts 2E Ryegate; 8 inches with 3ft drifts 10N Hardin; 8 inches with 2-4ft drifts in Park City; 8 inches with 3ft drifts 11W Billings; 12 inches with 2ft drifts in Joliet; 15 inches with 6ft drifts in Judith Gap; 9 inches with 2-4ft drifts in Broadview; 6 inches with 2-3ft drifts 6N Fort Smith; 6 inches with 2-3ft drifts in Busby; 10 inches and winds 28G53 mph with frequent gusts above 35 mph 15N Pompeys Pillar; 6 inches with 1-2ft drifts 35SE Hardin; 8 inches 13N Roundup; 12 inches with 10ft drifts and zero visibility in Melstone; 6 inches with 1/4 mile visibilities 8SW Biddle; 6 inches in Miles City; 6 inches with frequent wind gusts to 35 mph and 50ft visibilities in Northern Crow Agency; 8 inches 5S Bighorn; 6 inches 2WSW Hardin; 7 inches with 4ft drifts 9NNE Reed Point; 20 inches 5ESE Klein; 10 inches West End Billings in Willshire Heights; 14 inches 5W Red Lodge with 16 inches at the Mountain Summit at 9400ft; 8 inches in Nye.

Snow started to fall shortly after dawn Friday in far southwestern Kansas, then quickly spread north and east across other parts of southwest and south central Kansas.  This snow basically fell south of a line from Johnson City to Garden City to Jetmore to Larned.  The heaviest snow reported was in the Medicine Lodge area, where 9 inches fell.  6 to 8 inches of new snow fell east of a Jetmore to Greensburg to Coldwater line, including the communities of Pratt and St. John.  From 2 to 4 inches of snowfall was reported across the remainder of southern sections of southwest Kansas.  Numerous traffic accidents were reported in the Garden City area, but none with serious injury.

The first in a pair of low pressure systems moved across the region late on the 4th through midday on the 5th. This system produced 5 to 6 inches of snow across the Eastern Panhandle of West Virginia. As a result the roads were treacherous in many places. Several automobile accidents with  non-life threatening injuries were reported across the Panhandle. Power outages were also reported in Berkeley and Jefferson Counties.

The first in a pair of low pressure systems moved across the region late on the 4th through midday on the 5th. This system produced 5 to 6 inches of snow across the Eastern Panhandle of West Virginia. As a result the roads were treacherous in many places. Several automobile accidents with  non-life threatening injuries were reported across the Panhandle. Power outages were also reported in Berkeley and Jefferson Counties.

A storm system deepened as it moved through eastern Quebec on the 25th and 26th of December. Cold air moved into northern Vermont changing rain to snow in the afternoon of December 25th. The snow became heavy at times the night of the 25th and tapered off to flurries on the 26th. Accumulations ranged from 10 to 20 inches in Franklin county, 8 to 16 inches in Orleans county and in eastern Chittenden county, around 7 inches in Essex county, and between 7 and 9 inches in Lamoille and Caledonia counties.

Clear skies and light winds behind a cold front lead to the first hard freeze of the season for parts of west central Florida. Overnight low temperatures in the low to mid 20s were found in Levy, Citrus, Hernando, and Sumter counties. Low temperatures included 20 degrees in Brooksville, 22 in Chiefland, 25 in Inverness, and around 30 degrees along the Hillsborough/Polk county line.

The first in a pair of low pressure systems tracked across the region on the 4th and 5th. This system brought light snowto portions of Lower Southern Maryland. Snow totals averaged 1 to 2 inches.  Three fatalities were reported, two from shoveling snow and one from an automobile accident. Other minor, non life threatening injuries were also reported by the Emergency and Law Enforcement Officers.

An area of low pressure moved east across southern Ohio and into Pennsylvania on December 5th.  Precipitation began just before daybreak on the 5th and ended during the early morning hours of the 6th.  Most of the precipitation fell as snow, but some sleet and freezing rain fell during the early stages of the storm.  The greatest snowfall rates occurred during the late afternoon and early evening hours as wrap around moisture from the low moved into the region.  A total of 6 to 8 inches of snow was reported in Crawford County with the highest amounts across the southern portion of the county.  Numerous accidents resulted from this storm.

A long lasting winter storm brought blizzard conditions to much of southeast Idaho beginning the night of the 28th and peaking on December 29th and drawing to a close on the 30th.  The worst conditions occurred on the 29th and many major interstates closed due to the blizzard conditions.  Interstate 86 was closed from Pocatello to the interstate 84 interchange.  Interstate 84 was closed from Burley to the Utah state line.  Interstate 15 shut down south of Pocatello and State highway 37 was closed from Oneida County to American Falls.  Some details from the storm including snow totals were 13 inches at Galena Summit, 8 inches at Minidoka with 4 foot drifts, 12 inches at Driggs and 18 inches at Palisades with 4 feet drifts, 16 inches at Holbrook, 8 inches at Malad with 2 foot drifts, 12 inches at Kilgore with 3 foot drifts, 50 to 60 mph wind gusts in Pocatello, 12 to 14 inches at Hailey, 18 to 20 inches at Ketchum, over 300 road slideoffs and 60 crashes reported by the Idaho State Police, 12 inches at Sublett with whiteout conditions on the 29th, blizzard conditions on highway 91 at Swan Lake on the 29th, 9 inches at Swan Valley, 10 inches at Shoshone, 6 inches at McCammon with 2 foot drifts, 6 inches on the east benches of Pocatello, 6 inches at Burley with 3 foot drifts, 24 inches at Ashton, 10 inches at Bone, 12 inches at Springfield, 7 inches at Malta, 12 inches at Stone, 1 to 3 feet in Buist, 2 feet in Spencer, 18 inches at Island Park, 10 inches at Richfield, and 8 inches at Henry.  In addition to the interstate closures, several state highways and local roadways were closed during the day on the 29th.

The combination of the already saturated soil and heavy rain during the morning of the 17th caused poor drainage flooding and flooding along the Christina River in New Castle County. The Christina River at Coochs Bridge was above its 10.5 foot flood stage (raised from 9.0 feet) from 1043 a.m. EST through 111 p.m. EST on the 17th. It crested at 10.81 feet at 1145 a.m. EST. Storm totals included 1.50 inches in Newark and 0.66 inches at the New Castle County Airport. The heavy rain preceded and accompanied an occluded frontal passage during the day on the 17th. Moisture from the Gulf of Mexico was entrained into this frontal system as it moved through Delaware.  The heavy rain during December was systemic of the whole calendar year. On a statewide average, 2003 was the fourth wettest December on record dating back to 1895 with an average annual precipitation total of 59.00 inches. On a statewide average, December 2003 was the 14th wettest on record in the state dating back to 1895 with a statewide average precipitation total of 5.69 inches.
Snowfall varied from 1 to 3 inches. The snow was accompanied by freezing rain at the start of the event. Travel was hampered because of icy roads, and some schools were closed or delayed.
Snowfall varied from 2 to 5 inches. The snow was accompanied by a little freezing rain at the start of the event. Travel was hampered, and some schools were closed or delayed.

A non-thunderstorm high wind event from late on the 12th to the early morning hours on the14th knocked down trees and power lines in portions of Franklin County and knocked down trees across Patrick, Carroll, Grayson, Bedford, Botetourt, Craig, Smyth, Roanoke, Montgomery, Bland, Tazewell, and Amherst Counties, as well as in Lexington, Rural Retreat, Laurel Fork, Willis, and 2 miles east of Covington.In Patrick County, trees were toppled onto power lines. In Grayson County, the roof was blown off of a building. In Roanoke County, winds downed a large tree limb which damaged a vehicle. In Floyd County, wind blew out a window at a business.A wind gust of 60 mph was measured at Hot Springs Airport in Bath County.

A powerful winter storm affected Southern Montana and Northern Wyoming during a three day period from December 26, 2003 through December 28, 2003.  A strong arctic front ushered in colder air across the area as a deep trough moved across Montana. A moist southwest flow aloft moved over this cold airmass at the surface and produced a prolonged period of snow across the area.  In addition...a deep surface low moved across Wyoming into South Dakota resulting in strong northerly winds of 25 to 40 mph which produced significant blowing and drifting snow. A second storm developed quickly on the heels of the first winter storm . This storm affected the region from the evening of the 5th through the morning of the 6th. The second storm produced another 5 to 6  inches of snow across North and Central Maryland. A medical condition rendered a Frederick, MD woman unconscious after  she walked outside to check her mailbox on the 6th. The elderly woman died of hypothermia on the 7th.

A second storm developed quickly on the heels of the first winter storm . This storm affected the region from the evening of the 5th through the morning of the 6th. The second storm produced another 5 to 6  inches of snow across North and Central Maryland. A medical condition rendered a Frederick, MD woman unconscious after  she walked outside to check her mailbox on the 6th. The elderly woman died of hypothermia on the 7th.

Snow and ice fell across most of southwest and south central Kansas.  Snow mixed with sleet or ice pellets occurred southeast of a line from Ashland to Greensburg to Kinsley to Larned.  Strong north winds of 30 to 45 MPH caused plenty of blowing and drifting snow, with every county in the CWA reporting less than a quarter mile visibility for several hours, with occasional white out conditions.  Snowfall amounts were banded, with the two highest reports both being 6 inches, from southern Gray county and central Stanton county.  A 30 to 40 mile wide band of snowfall amounts from 4 to 5 inches fell from just north of Scott City southwest through northern Kearny county to southwest of Johnson City in Stanton County.  Another swath of snow 35 to 45 miles wide, also with snow amounts from 4 to 5 inches, fell from near Meade to Cimarron through Dodge City and Greensburg to near Medicine Lodge.  One more band of 4 to 5 inch amounts fell from extreme northwest Hodgeman County to just northwest of Ness City to near Hays.  Many schools and other planned activities were cancelled due to the weather, especially the low visibilities.  Numerous traffic accidents were reported in Liberal, Dodge City, Pratt, and Medicine Lodge.  Two jack-knifed semi-trailers, on a portion of Kansas Highway 96 between Scott City and Leoti, caused the highway to be closed for an hour and a half.  Zero visibility conditions closed U.S. Highway west of Ulysses for about 3 hours Tuesday afternoon on the 10th.

Moderate to heavy rainfall late on the 18th and on the 19th resulted in flash flooding and small stream flooding. In addition, an isolated severe thunderstorm knocked down large tree limbs in Huddleston.Runoff from heavy rainfall resulted in numerous creeks and streams out of their banks, some of which flooded roads in Grayson, Roanoke, Bath, Alleghany, Tazewell, Wythe, Carroll, and Bland Counties and in and near Sugar Grove. In Bland County, sections of some roads were washed away by the flood waters. In Pembroke, Doe Creek flooded and damaged a barber shop. Near Lexington route 11 was closed because flood waters pushed debris into the road. In Tazewell county, businesses were damaged as creeks overflowed their banks, especially in Bluefield. In Rockbridge County, Kerrs Creek flooded all along it's reach. In the town of Kerrs Creek it reached its highest level since 1985. Some houses had minor damage.  15 people were trapped on Big Springs Rd between Kerrs Creek and Lexington. There was damage to driveways and fences.  South river had significant flash flooding that caused minor damage to homes, and necessitated a water rescue.In Grayson County, Beaver Creek washed out a culvert (72" pipe), and damaged Rt 625.  There was significant flash flooding in the Fairview area along Chestnut Creek. A woman in her vehicle in the Daleheart area was washed into Meadow Creek and had to be rescued.

Snow started to fall shortly after dawn Friday in far southwestern Kansas, then quickly spread north and east across other parts of southwest and south central Kansas.  This snow basically fell south of a line from Johnson City to Garden City to Jetmore to Larned.  The heaviest snow reported was in the Medicine Lodge area, where 9 inches fell.  6 to 8 inches of new snow fell east of a Jetmore to Greensburg to Coldwater line, including the communities of Pratt and St. John.  From 2 to 4 inches of snowfall was reported across the remainder of southern sections of southwest Kansas.  Numerous traffic accidents were reported in the Garden City area, but none with serious injury.

Intensifying low pressure tracking along the Maine coast to central Nova Scotia produced heavy snow across the region. The snow started during the early morning hours of the 15th. Very heavy snow fell during the 15th with snowfall rates of 2 to 3 inches per hour at times...particularly across northern portions of the region. Strong winds produced near blizzard conditions at times with extensive blowing and drifting snow along with visibilities reduced below a quarter mile at times. Storm total snow accumulations generally ranged from 6 to 12 inches along the Downeast coast...with localized totals to around 18 inches. Across interior Downeast areas...storm total snow accumulations generally ranged from 10 to 20 inches...with localized totals to around 24 inches. Across central and northern areas...storm total snow accumulations generally ranged from 16 to 24 inches with localized totals to around 30 inches. The 27.3 inch storm total at Caribou ( 27.1 inches of which fell during the 15th ) represented the second greatest snowfall ever recorded.

A High Wind Warning was issued for the coastal headlands of ORZ021/022 at 1434 PST on 12/23 and expired at 0400 PST on 12/24.  The spotter report above did not give a specific time, but judging from other nearby observations, it almost certainly occurred within the warning window.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotter CU07 at Sixes reported a peak wind of 60 mph from the south overnight.

The spotter report above did not give a specific time, but judging from other nearby observations, it almost certainly occurred within the warning window.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Cape Blanco exceeded High Wind Warning criteria continuously during this time period.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of heavy rain during the first half of the day on  the 11th and the additional runoff from the melting snow produced widespread poor drainage flooding and isolated creek flooding in Berks County. Storm totals averaged around 2.0 inches.Flooding along the Maiden Creek in Maiden Creek Township caused basement flooding. Low lying areas of Pennsylvania State Route 10 south of Reading were flooded. The Manatawny Creek at Spangville was above its 6 foot flood stage from 10 a.m. EST through 654 p.m. EST on the 11th. It crested at 6.48 feet at 445 p.m. EST. Storm totals included 2.56 inches in Pricetown, 2.30 inches in Hamburg, 1.87 inches in bethel, 1.75 inches in Gibraltar and 1.63 inches in Reading. The heavy rain was caused by an intense low pressure system at both the surface and aloft that developed over the Southern Plains on the 9th. The primary low pressure system moved toward the Great Lakes on the morning of the 10th while a secondary low pressure system was forming near the upper air support over the Tennessee Valley. This secondary low pressure system continued to intensify and was located over North Carolina the evening of the 10th, near Philadelphia around 7 a.m. EST on the 11th and in western Connecticut early in the evening on the 11th. This secondary low pressure system helped wring the moisture in the atmosphere from the Gulf of Mexico and the Atlantic Ocean onto the region.

The winter storm over central North Dakota began moving northeast producing strong northwest winds over western North Dakotain its wake. The winter storm warning for the west was upgraded to a blizzard warning due to the strong winds. Winds of 30 to45 mph with gust around 50 mph were producing near zero visibilities in blowing snow. No travel was advised by the North Dakota Highway Patrol over much of western North Dakota.

A powerfull storm moved through northeast California and northwest Nevada on the 28th and 29th.  This system brought very strong winds and heavy snow to the region.  Winds of over 80 mph in the higher elevations created blizzard conditions.  Strong winds mixed to the surface east of the Sierra.  Over three feet of snow was reported at some locations in the Sierra.Snowfall totals:South Lake Tahoe			12 inchesTruckee				10 inchesTahoe City (7000 ft)			24 inchesBoreal Ski Resort			48-56 inchesAlpine Meadows Ski Resort		26-36 inchesSierra at Tahoe Ski Resort		16-22 inchesNorthstar at Tahoe Ski Resort		19-24 inchesSquaw Valley Ski Resort (6200 ft)	6-8 inches		     (8200 ft)	10 inches

Six wildfires blackened about 3000 acres of mostly brush land in inaccessible parts of western and central Molokai.  However, one of the blazes did briefly threaten homes in Maunaloa and forced the temporary evacuation of Molokai Ranch campsites.  No other homes or structures were threatened by the fires.  A helicopter, one of three helping to fight the fires, crashed about 1315 on the 26th of June.  The pilot of the aircraft sustained injuries, but they were not life-threatening.  Firefighters from Molokai and Maui battled the fires; along with Molokai Ranch crews that used heavy equipment to make fire breaks.  The causes of the blazes were unknown, though a fire official said they were suspicious in nature.

A brush fire burned about 2500 acres of pasture land and gulches in Kahikinui on the south-facing slopes of Haleakala in East Maui.  State forestry officials said the blaze did not burn into a nearby forest reserve, but they did say that stands of koa and other native plants in the gulches were damaged.  The fire did not threaten homes or other structures.  Maui County firefighters, with help from state and Haleakala National Park specialists, battled the blaze.  Assistance was also provided by Ulupalakua Ranch workers, heavy equipment operators from Goodfellow Brothers, and state highway workers.  To help contain the blaze, county officials also used three helicopters to drop water on the fire.  There were no serious injuries or property damage.  The cause of the blaze was not known.

CZ_NAME: NORTHERN & EASTERN KLAMATH COUNTY & WESTERN LAKE COUNTY
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The above listed observation barely met the criteria for a Heavy Snow Warning.  This was the only report received that verified a warning.  A Snow Advisory was in effect for most of the previous day and was cancelled at 0445 PST on 12/14...nearly 4 hours before this report was received.  A snow advisory was likely the best product for covering this event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotter KL97 reported 6 inches of snow in 10 hours ending at 0800 PST.
Additional flooding developed during the afternoon around Spruce Pine, as excess water produced by early morning heavy rainfall flowed from the higher elevations into the valleys.
The Pigeon River flooded some property around Clyde.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of low pressure developed over the Gulf Coast region and tracked northeast into the Mid Atlantic region. The storm produced a mixture of snow, sleet and freezing rain. Snowfall totals across Central and Lower Southern Maryland averaged 1 to 3 inches. Some light ice accumulations were also reported.
A Flood Warning was issued for the lower Rogue River from Agness to Gold Beach, effective at the above times.  This warning did not verify as the Rogue did not reach flood stage.

A strong upper level storm system dove south out of Canada, and moved into Kentucky by early Thursday, December 18th.  Heavy snow fell over portions of eastern Kentucky beginning in the afternoon on Thursday, December 18th.  Snow began accumulating in areas north of the Mountain parkway, along with ridge tops over other areas during the mid-afternoon hours, with many valley locations not switching from rain to snow until 8 or 9 pm the same day.  While many locations accumulated 4 inches of snow or more, only eight counties recorded totals of 4 inches or more within a 12 hour period.  By about 10 am on Friday, December 19th, accumulating snow ended for locations north of Interstate 64 and along the Interstate 75 corridor.  Accumulating snow ended for the rest of eastern Kentucky by around 6 am on Saturday, December 20th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Four inches of snow were reported in Heidelberg, from a co-operative observer, and also about 4 miles northwest of Beattyville.

CZ_NAME: CAMERON LA TO HIGH IS TX OUT 20NM

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The West Texas Mesonet station located six miles northwest of White River Lake measured a 60 mph non-convective wind gust.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of heavy rain between 4 a.m. and Noon EST on the 11th and the additional runoff from the melting snow produced widespread poor drainage and creek flooding in Mercer County. Storm totals averaged around 2.0 inches. The Assunpink Creek in Trenton was above its 7 foot flood stage from 903 a.m. through 10 p.m. EST on the 11th. It crested at 8.52 feet at 315 p.m. EST. Flooding along the Stony Creek closed several roads in Princeton. The Harry Brook Bridge was also closed. Cars stalled in flood waters and several back yards were flooded in Princeton.    Storm totals included 2.10 inches in Princeton, 2.00 inches in Windsor, 1.93 inches in Washington's Crossing and 1.76 inches in Trenton. The heavy rain was caused by an intense low pressure system at both the surface and aloft that developed over the Southern Plains on the 9th. The primary low pressure system moved toward the Great Lakes on the morning of the 10th while a secondary low pressure system was forming near the upper air support over the Tennessee Valley. This secondary low pressure system continued to intensify and was located over North Carolina the evening of the 10th, near Philadelphia around 7 a.m. EST on the 11th and in western Connecticut early in the evening on the 11th. This secondary low pressure system helped wring the moisture in the atmosphere from the Gulf of Mexico and the Atlantic Ocean onto the region.

The combination of heavy rain during the first half of the day on the 11th and additional runoff from the melting snow produced widespread poor drainage flooding in the Lehigh Valley and Carbon County. Storm totals averaged between one and three inches. In Lehigh County, Spring Creek road was closed in Lower Macungie Township. In Northampton County, flooding along Lehigh Drive closed the roadway for most of the daytime hours in Easton. In Lower Saucon Township, the loosened soil caused several trees to topple. About 17,000 homes and businesses lost power. Storm totals included 2.70 inches in Forks Township (Northampton County), 2.20 inches in Easton (Northampton County), 1.85 inches in Lehighton (Carbon County) and 1.28 inches at the Lehigh Valley International Airport. The heavy rain was caused by an intense low pressure system at both the surface and aloft that developed over the Southern Plains on the 9th. The primary low pressure system moved toward the Great Lakes on the morning of the 10th while a secondary low pressure system was forming near the upper air support over the Tennessee Valley. This secondary low pressure system continued to intensify and was located over North Carolina the evening of the 10th, near Philadelphia around 7 a.m. EST on the 11th and in western Connecticut early in the evening on the 11th. This secondary low pressure system helped wring the moisture in the atmosphere from the Gulf of Mexico and the Atlantic Ocean onto the region.

Sleet and freezing rain began in the early morning of the 5th, and gradually changed to snow, which was heavy during the afternoon and evening of the 5th. Accumulations by 7 AM on the 6th were (in inches): 8 New Cumberland and Thomas; 7 Bruceton and Terra Alta; 6 Bethany, Coopers Rock, Limestone, Silver Hill, and Valley Grove.

Gusty northwest winds around an intensifying low pressure system produced wind gusts to around 45 mph during the afternoon of the 29th in Eastern Pennsylvania. In Monroe County, in Brodheadsville, shingles were torn away from one home. Glass was shattered at another home. Pennsylvania State Route 715 was closed because of downed trees and wires. In Carbon County, much of Hauto lost power. In Berks County, about 2,500 homes and businesses lost power, with the greatest concentration in and around Hamburg. In Montgomery County in Upper Merion Township, a snapped pole caused power outages that affected nearby businesses. Peak wind gusts included 46 mph at the Philadelphia International Airport, 45 mph in Doylestown (Bucks County), 44 mph in Reading (Berks County), 43 mph in Mount Pocono (Monroe County), 41 mph at the Lehigh Valley International Airport and 40 mph in Pottstown (Montgomery County). The strong winds were caused by the difference in surface pressure between a powerful (about 975 millibars) low pressure system moving through the Saint Lawrence River Valley and a high pressure system building northeast from the Gulf Coast States.

An area of low pressure moved east across southern Ohio on December 5th.  Precipitation began during the early mornings hours of the 5th and ended around midnight on the 6th.  The precipitation started as a mixture of freezing rain, sleet and snow at most locations.  A quick transition to all snow occurred around daybreak.  By 9 am a band of moderate snow had developed along the U.S. Route 30 corridor from Mansfield to Canton.  The greatest snowfall rates occurred during the late afternoon and early evening hours as wrap around moisture from the low moved into the region.  A total of 6 to 9 inches of snow was reported across the area with the greatest amounts along and just south of U.S. 30.  Most locations also received a light glaze of ice from the freezing rain early in the storm.  Significant traffic delays and numerous accidents resulted from this storm.

A prodigious winter storm affected nearly all of southeastern Idaho beginning Christmas evening and continuing until the morning of the 27th.  Generally 1 to 2 feet of snow were common across the Snake River Plain and southeastern Highlands with the storm.  In Pocatello, it set the one day December record for snowfall with 13 inches on the 26th.  The storm totaled 14.9 inches at the NWS office at the airport.  High winds accompanied the storms with blizzard conditions in Pocatello during the evening and overnight on the 26th.  Other specific snow amounts from the storm were 20 inches on the east benches of Pocatello with 4 feet drifts.  18 inches 8 miles east of Fort Hall, 1 foot in American Falls, 1 foot in the Idaho Falls area, 15 inches in Bone, 9 inches in Grace, 16 inches at Howell Canyon, 16 inches at Wild Horse Divide, 9 inches at Soda Springs, and 15 inches at Driggs.  The Pocatello airport shut down on the 26th and although not receiving heavy snow, blizzard conditions were reported in Burley on the morning of the 26th with whiteout conditions reported on interstate 84.

The combination of a rapidly deepening low pressure system moving through the Saint Lawrence Valley and a high pressure system building in from the Plains States produced high winds across New Jersey. The strongest winds occurred during two time periods: in the morning shortly after the low pressure system's cold frontal passage and during the afternoon. The peak wind gusts of the event mainly occurred during the afternoon. Several people were injured by downed trees. A couple of buildings collapsed. Numerous trees, tree limbs, transformers and wires were knocked down and damaged homes and vehicles. Scattered transformer fires occurred. In some instances poles were snapped. Numerous roads were closed including some major roadways. The afternoon and evening commute was difficult because of many closed roads. Emergency personnel had the added problem with road closures because the high winds were blowing away the plastic and wood road barriers.  Shingles, chimney covers, gutters and siding were ripped from houses and fences were damaged by downed limbs and trees.  Vehicles were damaged by fallen trees and/or flying debris. Awnings were torn away, store windows damaged, roadway business signs were knocked down as were overhead traffic signs and traffic signals. Trash and recycling cans were tossed in the middle of roads. Cart shelters tumbled in shopping centers. Some schools had early dismissal because of the lost power and many scholastic games were cancelled. The high winds made it very difficult to fight fires. It also led to blow out tides at times of low tide during the evening of the 13th and 14th along coastal areas and tidal sections of the Delaware River and its tributaries. Sections of many major roads were closed including the Garden State Parkway, U.S. Routes 202, 206 and 46 and New Jersey State Route 12. About 150,000 homes and business lost power in the state: Public Service Electric and Gas reported about 62,200 outages,  Conectiv Energy  reported about 54,000 outages and Jersey Central Power and Light about 23,000 outages and 400 poles down. All power was restored by the 15th. In Sussex County, a student at the Sussex County Community College was trapped in an elevator for 30 minutes after a brush fire occurred near the College and power was lost. About 1,600 county residents lost power with major outages in Newton and near the Stokes State Forest. In Warren County, a 45-year-old man was injured when a tree fell on him near the Econo-Court Motel on U.S. Route 46. The route itself was closed in several locations because of downed trees.  A house in the Vienna section of Independence Township suffered gutter damage after a tree fell on it. In Morris County, two homes were damaged by fallen trees in Pequannock Township. About 20 percent of Boonton Township lost power. Cranes were needed to remove the large trees. In Hunterdon County, a tree fell on a bus in Clinton Township. No injuries occurred. Sections of New Jersey State Routes 12, 31 and U.S. Route 202 were closed. About 8,000 homes and businesses in the county lost power. In Somerset County, several injuries occurred. In Somerville, seven utility poles snapped at 430 p.m. on South Bridge Street and crushed a vehicle. The 56-year-old driver cut his head. Another uninjured driver was temporarily trapped by the downed wires. In Raritan Borough, pieces of a roof tore away and caused leg injuries to an onlooker. In Bernardsville Borough, a 21-year-old man suffered leg and back injuries after the wind knocked him off his ladder. In the Basking Ridge section of Bernards Township, a postal worker was hit in the head by a tree limb. A tree fell through a house in Bernardsville. In Branchburg Township, students were evacuated from the Whiton School after winds downed a transformer and started a fire. Sections of New Jersey State Route 28 and U.S. Routes 202 and 206 were closed because of downed trees and wires. In Monmouth County in a reverse of the blowout tides, wind driven waters from Sandy Hook Bay washed over the access road to the Sandy Hook unit of the Gateway National Recreational Area. A similar effect caused by Barnegat Bay occurred in Ocean County. About 9,000 homes and businesses lost power in Ocean and Monmouth Counties. Elsewhere in Ocean County, the southbound lanes of the Garden State Parkway were backed up because of downed trees. Power outages were concentrated in the Holiday City section of Berkeley Township. In Mercer County, a roof partially tore off a home in Trenton and a tree fell on a Princeton home. In Burlington County, a driver was uninjured in spite of a tree that landed on his vehicle in Medford Township. The hardest hit locations in the county were Cinnaminson and Willingboro Townships. In Camden County, school children were not injured when a tree fell on their bus when leaving Saint Jude's School in Gloucester Township. In Camden, a large building in the process of being converted to housing collapsed in pieces between 7 a.m. and 9 a.m. EST.In Cherry Hill, the wind fanned a blaze at a warehouse. The wind carried embers to the Woodcrest Development. Oversized insulation panels caught fire apparently by a acetylene torch. In Gloucester County, an addition to a home in Woolwich Township collapsed. In Atlantic County, the Atlantic City Police and Fire Communication Center lost power for an hour. Nearly all of Absecon lost power. In Cape May County, a 28 foot empty boxcar overturned on the northbound lanes of the Garden State Parkway in Upper Township. The Cape May Lewes Ferry suspended service for the rest of the day on the 13th. The high wind damaged the roofs of the Sea Isle City Bar and Hotel and the Lollipop Motel in North Wildwood. In Cumberland County, a Shiloh Borough orchard's produce packing warehouse collapsed. The winds caused a concrete wall to topple sending it into a corrugated metal roof. Two duck hunters were rescued after becoming stranded on a mud flat after grounding their skiff near the mouth of the bay in Dividing Creek. About 20,000 homes and businesses lost power in the county including the county administration building, library and state police barracks in Port Norris.  Peak wind gusts included 67 mph in High Point (Sussex County) and Sandy Hook (Monmouth County), 65 mph in Cape May City (Cape May County), 62 mph in Barnegat (Ocean County), 61 mph in Lumberton (Burlington County) and Stone Harbor (Cape May County), 60 mph at the Atlantic City Marina,  55 mph in Belmar (Monmouth County), 54 mph in Hillsborough (Somerset County) and the Atlantic City International Airport, 53 mph in Hamilton (Mercer County), 52 mph in Morristown (Morris County) and Millville (Cumberland County) and 48 mph in Trenton (Mercer County). The high winds were caused by the pressure difference between the low pressure system in the Saint Lawrence Valley and a high pressure system in the Central Plains. The low intensified from a 1004 millibar system over Lake Superior the morning of the 12th, to a 982 millibar low near Montreal the morning of the 13th to a 970 millibar low in the mouth of the Saint Lawrence River the morning of the 14th. Some strong wind gusts also occurred on the 14th and hampered power restoration work. Winds diminished for good during the evening of the 14th.

The strongest winds occurred during two time periods: in the morning shortly after the low pressure system's cold frontal passage and during the afternoon. The peak wind gusts of the event mainly occurred during the afternoon. Several people were injured by downed trees. A couple of buildings collapsed. Numerous trees, tree limbs, transformers and wires were knocked down and damaged homes and vehicles. Scattered transformer fires occurred. In some instances poles were snapped. Numerous roads were closed including some major roadways. The afternoon and evening commute was difficult because of many closed roads. Emergency personnel had the added problem with road closures because the high winds were blowing away the plastic and wood road barriers.  Shingles, chimney covers, gutters and siding were ripped from houses and fences were damaged by downed limbs and trees.  Vehicles were damaged by fallen trees and/or flying debris. Awnings were torn away, store windows damaged, roadway business signs were knocked down as were overhead traffic signs and traffic signals. Trash and recycling cans were tossed in the middle of roads. Cart shelters tumbled in shopping centers. Some schools had early dismissal because of the lost power and many scholastic games were cancelled. The high winds made it very difficult to fight fires. It also led to blow out tides at times of low tide during the evening of the 13th and 14th along coastal areas and tidal sections of the Delaware River and its tributaries. Sections of many major roads were closed including the Garden State Parkway, U.S. Routes 202, 206 and 46 and New Jersey State Route 12. About 150,000 homes and business lost power in the state: Public Service Electric and Gas reported about 62,200 outages,  Conectiv Energy  reported about 54,000 outages and Jersey Central Power and Light about 23,000 outages and 400 poles down. All power was restored by the 15th. In Sussex County, a student at the Sussex County Community College was trapped in an elevator for 30 minutes after a brush fire occurred near the College and power was lost. About 1,600 county residents lost power with major outages in Newton and near the Stokes State Forest. In Warren County, a 45-year-old man was injured when a tree fell on him near the Econo-Court Motel on U.S. Route 46. The route itself was closed in several locations because of downed trees.  A house in the Vienna section of Independence Township suffered gutter damage after a tree fell on it. In Morris County, two homes were damaged by fallen trees in Pequannock Township. About 20 percent of Boonton Township lost power. Cranes were needed to remove the large trees. In Hunterdon County, a tree fell on a bus in Clinton Township. No injuries occurred. Sections of New Jersey State Routes 12, 31 and U.S. Route 202 were closed. About 8,000 homes and businesses in the county lost power. In Somerset County, several injuries occurred. In Somerville, seven utility poles snapped at 430 p.m. on South Bridge Street and crushed a vehicle. The 56-year-old driver cut his head. Another uninjured driver was temporarily trapped by the downed wires. In Raritan Borough, pieces of a roof tore away and caused leg injuries to an onlooker. In Bernardsville Borough, a 21-year-old man suffered leg and back injuries after the wind knocked him off his ladder. In the Basking Ridge section of Bernards Township, a postal worker was hit in the head by a tree limb. A tree fell through a house in Bernardsville. In Branchburg Township, students were evacuated from the Whiton School after winds downed a transformer and started a fire. Sections of New Jersey State Route 28 and U.S. Routes 202 and 206 were closed because of downed trees and wires. In Monmouth County in a reverse of the blowout tides, wind driven waters from Sandy Hook Bay washed over the access road to the Sandy Hook unit of the Gateway National Recreational Area. A similar effect caused by Barnegat Bay occurred in Ocean County. About 9,000 homes and businesses lost power in Ocean and Monmouth Counties. Elsewhere in Ocean County, the southbound lanes of the Garden State Parkway were backed up because of downed trees. Power outages were concentrated in the Holiday City section of Berkeley Township. In Mercer County, a roof partially tore off a home in Trenton and a tree fell on a Princeton home. In Burlington County, a driver was uninjured in spite of a tree that landed on his vehicle in Medford Township. The hardest hit locations in the county were Cinnaminson and Willingboro Townships. In Camden County, school children were not injured when a tree fell on their bus when leaving Saint Jude's School in Gloucester Township. In Camden, a large building in the process of being converted to housing collapsed in pieces between 7 a.m. and 9 a.m. EST.In Cherry Hill, the wind fanned a blaze at a warehouse. The wind carried embers to the Woodcrest Development. Oversized insulation panels caught fire apparently by a acetylene torch. In Gloucester County, an addition to a home in Woolwich Township collapsed. In Atlantic County, the Atlantic City Police and Fire Communication Center lost power for an hour. Nearly all of Absecon lost power. In Cape May County, a 28 foot empty boxcar overturned on the northbound lanes of the Garden State Parkway in Upper Township. The Cape May Lewes Ferry suspended service for the rest of the day on the 13th. The high wind damaged the roofs of the Sea Isle City Bar and Hotel and the Lollipop Motel in North Wildwood. In Cumberland County, a Shiloh Borough orchard's produce packing warehouse collapsed. The winds caused a concrete wall to topple sending it into a corrugated metal roof. Two duck hunters were rescued after becoming stranded on a mud flat after grounding their skiff near the mouth of the bay in Dividing Creek. About 20,000 homes and businesses lost power in the county including the county administration building, library and state police barracks in Port Norris.  Peak wind gusts included 67 mph in High Point (Sussex County) and Sandy Hook (Monmouth County), 65 mph in Cape May City (Cape May County), 62 mph in Barnegat (Ocean County), 61 mph in Lumberton (Burlington County) and Stone Harbor (Cape May County), 60 mph at the Atlantic City Marina,  55 mph in Belmar (Monmouth County), 54 mph in Hillsborough (Somerset County) and the Atlantic City International Airport, 53 mph in Hamilton (Mercer County), 52 mph in Morristown (Morris County) and Millville (Cumberland County) and 48 mph in Trenton (Mercer County). The high winds were caused by the pressure difference between the low pressure system in the Saint Lawrence Valley and a high pressure system in the Central Plains. The low intensified from a 1004 millibar system over Lake Superior the morning of the 12th, to a 982 millibar low near Montreal the morning of the 13th to a 970 millibar low in the mouth of the Saint Lawrence River the morning of the 14th. Some strong wind gusts also occurred on the 14th and hampered power restoration work. Winds diminished for good during the evening of the 14th.

Peak wind gusts included 67 mph in High Point (Sussex County) and Sandy Hook (Monmouth County), 65 mph in Cape May City (Cape May County), 62 mph in Barnegat (Ocean County), 61 mph in Lumberton (Burlington County) and Stone Harbor (Cape May County), 60 mph at the Atlantic City Marina,  55 mph in Belmar (Monmouth County), 54 mph in Hillsborough (Somerset County) and the Atlantic City International Airport, 53 mph in Hamilton (Mercer County), 52 mph in Morristown (Morris County) and Millville (Cumberland County) and 48 mph in Trenton (Mercer County). The high winds were caused by the pressure difference between the low pressure system in the Saint Lawrence Valley and a high pressure system in the Central Plains. The low intensified from a 1004 millibar system over Lake Superior the morning of the 12th, to a 982 millibar low near Montreal the morning of the 13th to a 970 millibar low in the mouth of the Saint Lawrence River the morning of the 14th. Some strong wind gusts also occurred on the 14th and hampered power restoration work. Winds diminished for good during the evening of the 14th.

The combination of a rapidly deepening low pressure system moving through the Saint Lawrence Valley and a high pressure system building in from the Plains States produced high winds across New Jersey. The strongest winds occurred during two time periods: in the morning shortly after the low pressure system's cold frontal passage and during the afternoon. The peak wind gusts of the event mainly occurred during the afternoon. Several people were injured by downed trees. A couple of buildings collapsed. Numerous trees, tree limbs, transformers and wires were knocked down and damaged homes and vehicles. Scattered transformer fires occurred. In some instances poles were snapped. Numerous roads were closed including some major roadways. The afternoon and evening commute was difficult because of many closed roads. Emergency personnel had the added problem with road closures because the high winds were blowing away the plastic and wood road barriers.  Shingles, chimney covers, gutters and siding were ripped from houses and fences were damaged by downed limbs and trees.  Vehicles were damaged by fallen trees and/or flying debris. Awnings were torn away, store windows damaged, roadway business signs were knocked down as were overhead traffic signs and traffic signals. Trash and recycling cans were tossed in the middle of roads. Cart shelters tumbled in shopping centers. Some schools had early dismissal because of the lost power and many scholastic games were cancelled. The high winds made it very difficult to fight fires. It also led to blow out tides at times of low tide during the evening of the 13th and 14th along coastal areas and tidal sections of the Delaware River and its tributaries. Sections of many major roads were closed including the Garden State Parkway, U.S. Routes 202, 206 and 46 and New Jersey State Route 12. About 150,000 homes and business lost power in the state: Public Service Electric and Gas reported about 62,200 outages,  Conectiv Energy  reported about 54,000 outages and Jersey Central Power and Light about 23,000 outages and 400 poles down. All power was restored by the 15th. In Sussex County, a student at the Sussex County Community College was trapped in an elevator for 30 minutes after a brush fire occurred near the College and power was lost. About 1,600 county residents lost power with major outages in Newton and near the Stokes State Forest. In Warren County, a 45-year-old man was injured when a tree fell on him near the Econo-Court Motel on U.S. Route 46. The route itself was closed in several locations because of downed trees.  A house in the Vienna section of Independence Township suffered gutter damage after a tree fell on it. In Morris County, two homes were damaged by fallen trees in Pequannock Township. About 20 percent of Boonton Township lost power. Cranes were needed to remove the large trees. In Hunterdon County, a tree fell on a bus in Clinton Township. No injuries occurred. Sections of New Jersey State Routes 12, 31 and U.S. Route 202 were closed. About 8,000 homes and businesses in the county lost power. In Somerset County, several injuries occurred. In Somerville, seven utility poles snapped at 430 p.m. on South Bridge Street and crushed a vehicle. The 56-year-old driver cut his head. Another uninjured driver was temporarily trapped by the downed wires. In Raritan Borough, pieces of a roof tore away and caused leg injuries to an onlooker. In Bernardsville Borough, a 21-year-old man suffered leg and back injuries after the wind knocked him off his ladder. In the Basking Ridge section of Bernards Township, a postal worker was hit in the head by a tree limb. A tree fell through a house in Bernardsville. In Branchburg Township, students were evacuated from the Whiton School after winds downed a transformer and started a fire. Sections of New Jersey State Route 28 and U.S. Routes 202 and 206 were closed because of downed trees and wires. In Monmouth County in a reverse of the blowout tides, wind driven waters from Sandy Hook Bay washed over the access road to the Sandy Hook unit of the Gateway National Recreational Area. A similar effect caused by Barnegat Bay occurred in Ocean County. About 9,000 homes and businesses lost power in Ocean and Monmouth Counties. Elsewhere in Ocean County, the southbound lanes of the Garden State Parkway were backed up because of downed trees. Power outages were concentrated in the Holiday City section of Berkeley Township. In Mercer County, a roof partially tore off a home in Trenton and a tree fell on a Princeton home. In Burlington County, a driver was uninjured in spite of a tree that landed on his vehicle in Medford Township. The hardest hit locations in the county were Cinnaminson and Willingboro Townships. In Camden County, school children were not injured when a tree fell on their bus when leaving Saint Jude's School in Gloucester Township. In Camden, a large building in the process of being converted to housing collapsed in pieces between 7 a.m. and 9 a.m. EST.In Cherry Hill, the wind fanned a blaze at a warehouse. The wind carried embers to the Woodcrest Development. Oversized insulation panels caught fire apparently by a acetylene torch. In Gloucester County, an addition to a home in Woolwich Township collapsed. In Atlantic County, the Atlantic City Police and Fire Communication Center lost power for an hour. Nearly all of Absecon lost power. In Cape May County, a 28 foot empty boxcar overturned on the northbound lanes of the Garden State Parkway in Upper Township. The Cape May Lewes Ferry suspended service for the rest of the day on the 13th. The high wind damaged the roofs of the Sea Isle City Bar and Hotel and the Lollipop Motel in North Wildwood. In Cumberland County, a Shiloh Borough orchard's produce packing warehouse collapsed. The winds caused a concrete wall to topple sending it into a corrugated metal roof. Two duck hunters were rescued after becoming stranded on a mud flat after grounding their skiff near the mouth of the bay in Dividing Creek. About 20,000 homes and businesses lost power in the county including the county administration building, library and state police barracks in Port Norris.  Peak wind gusts included 67 mph in High Point (Sussex County) and Sandy Hook (Monmouth County), 65 mph in Cape May City (Cape May County), 62 mph in Barnegat (Ocean County), 61 mph in Lumberton (Burlington County) and Stone Harbor (Cape May County), 60 mph at the Atlantic City Marina,  55 mph in Belmar (Monmouth County), 54 mph in Hillsborough (Somerset County) and the Atlantic City International Airport, 53 mph in Hamilton (Mercer County), 52 mph in Morristown (Morris County) and Millville (Cumberland County) and 48 mph in Trenton (Mercer County). The high winds were caused by the pressure difference between the low pressure system in the Saint Lawrence Valley and a high pressure system in the Central Plains. The low intensified from a 1004 millibar system over Lake Superior the morning of the 12th, to a 982 millibar low near Montreal the morning of the 13th to a 970 millibar low in the mouth of the Saint Lawrence River the morning of the 14th. Some strong wind gusts also occurred on the 14th and hampered power restoration work. Winds diminished for good during the evening of the 14th.

Snow and ice fell across most of southwest and south central Kansas.  Snow mixed with sleet or ice pellets occurred southeast of a line from Ashland to Greensburg to Kinsley to Larned.  Strong north winds of 30 to 45 MPH caused plenty of blowing and drifting snow, with every county in the CWA reporting less than a quarter mile visibility for several hours, with occasional white out conditions.  Snowfall amounts were banded, with the two highest reports both being 6 inches, from southern Gray county and central Stanton county.  A 30 to 40 mile wide band of snowfall amounts from 4 to 5 inches fell from just north of Scott City southwest through northern Kearny county to southwest of Johnson City in Stanton County.  Another swath of snow 35 to 45 miles wide, also with snow amounts from 4 to 5 inches, fell from near Meade to Cimarron through Dodge City and Greensburg to near Medicine Lodge.  One more band of 4 to 5 inch amounts fell from extreme northwest Hodgeman County to just northwest of Ness City to near Hays.  Many schools and other planned activities were cancelled due to the weather, especially the low visibilities.  Numerous traffic accidents were reported in Liberal, Dodge City, Pratt, and Medicine Lodge.  Two jack-knifed semi-trailers, on a portion of Kansas Highway 96 between Scott City and Leoti, caused the highway to be closed for an hour and a half.  Zero visibility conditions closed U.S. Highway west of Ulysses for about 3 hours Tuesday afternoon on the 10th.

Low pressure intensified as it moved from the Gulf Coast up the mid-Atlantic coast to New England and brought a general snow to the entire region. The event lasted 24 to 30 hours from the early morning of  Sunday the 14th through early Monday. Amounts across the Genesee Valley and western Finger Lakes ranged from six to twelve inches while across the eastern Lake Ontario region one to two feet of snow fell. Specific storm total amounts reported were:  21" in Brantingham; 20" in Lowville; 18" in West Monroe and Redfield; 17" in Fulton; 16" in Woodville and Hooker;  15" in Highmarket, Fairhaven and Macedon; 14" in Fort Drum; 13" in Oswego and Spencerport; 12" in Walworth and Greece; 11" in Webster and Fairport; 10" in Penfield and Rochester; 9" in Victor; 8" in Whitesville and Batavia; and 7" in Geneva, Dansville, Wellsville, Warsaw, Leroy and Albion.  The typical rash of automobile accidents occurred as a result of the wintry conditions. Several injuries, some serious, and one fatality (in Ira) were a reported in the accidents. At the Rochester International Airport, a small plane slid off a taxiway and got stuck in the snow.

The combination of a rapidly melting snowpack and 2.50 to 3.50 inches of rain caused flooding along the Piscataquis River at Dover - Foxcroft. The river crested at 11.1 feet...just above the flood stage of 11.0 ft. Several buildings near the river were evacuated...with water reported in the basements of several buildings. Snow that had been plowed into culverts and ditches disrupted the normal drainage of water. This produced standing and running water on several roads. The running water undercut and eroded several roads requiring road closures.

The combination of heavy rain between 3 a.m. and 10 a.m. EST on the 11th and runoff from the melting snow produced widespread poor drainage and some creek flooding in Camden County. The incoming tide during the afternoon slowed the runoff and exacerbated the flooding. Storm totals averaged around 2.0 inches. In Camden, about fifteen families from Westfield Gardens were evacuated by boat when their homes were flooded by five feet of water. In Cherry Hill Township, up to two feet of water accumulated on New Jersey State Route 38 in low lying areas. The Cooper River in Haddonfield was above its 2.8 foot flood stage from 759 a.m. through 715 p.m. EST on the 11th. It crested at 3.42 feet at 230 p.m. EST.     Storm totals included 2.35 inches in Pennsauken. The heavy rain was caused by an intense low pressure system at both the surface and aloft that developed over the Southern Plains on the 9th. The primary low pressure system moved toward the Great Lakes on the morning of the 10th while a secondary low pressure system was forming near the upper air support over the Tennessee Valley. This secondary low pressure system continued to intensify and was located over North Carolina the evening of the 10th, near Philadelphia around 7 a.m. EST on the 11th and in western Connecticut early in the evening on the 11th. This secondary low pressure system helped wring the moisture in the atmosphere from the Gulf of Mexico and the Atlantic Ocean onto the region.

At the Rochester International Airport, a small plane slid off a taxiway and got stuck in the snow.

The combination of heavy rain between 6 a.m. and Noon EST on the 11th and runoff from the melting snow produced widespread poor drainage and river flooding in Somerset County. Storm totals averaged around an inch and a half with the highest amounts toward Morris and Hunterdon Counties. Flooding along the North Branch of the Raritan River affected County Route 614. A motorist was rescued near the Millstone River after he drove around barricades. A 80-year-old man was rescued from his car by two Hillsborough Township police as his vehicle was being pulled into the South Branch of the Raritan River. Both the Griggstown and Blackwells Mills Causeways were closed. Roads were also closed in Raritan and Somerville Boroughs. The Millstone River in Griggstown reached its 10 foot flood stage at 655 a.m. EST on the 11th, crested at 18.2 feet at 7 p.m. EST on the 11th and was back within bankfull at 1042 p.m. EST on the 13th. Farther downstream at Blackwells Mills, it reached its 9 foot flood stage at 431 p.m. EST on the 11th, crested at 11.87 feet at 153 a.m. EST on the 12th and was back within bankfull at 945 p.m. EST on the 12th. Farther downstream at Weston, the river reached its 12.4 foot flood stage at 847 p.m. EST on the 11th, crested at 13.48 feet at 3 a.m. EST on the 12th and was back within bankfull at 720 a.m. EST on the 12th. Along the North Branch of Raritan River, at North Ranch the river was above its 12.3 foot flood stage from 131 p.m. through 7 p.m. EST on the 11th. It crested at 12.74 feet at 401 p.m. EST. Farther downstream at Raritan, it was above its 10 foot flood stage from 322 p.m. through 727 p.m. EST on the 11th. It crested at 10.16 feet at 5 p.m. EST. Farther downstream at South Branch, the river was above its 6.9 foot flood stage from 924 a.m. EST on the 11th through 559 a.m. EST on the 12th. It crested at 9.9 feet at Midnight EST on the 12th. Along the main stem of the Raritan River at Manville the river reached its 14 foot flood stage at 439 p.m. EST, crested at 16.6 feet at 1130 p.m. EST on the 11th and was back within bankfull at 706 a.m. EST on the 12th. Farther downstream at Bound Brook, the river reached its 28 foot flood stage at 828 p.m. EST on the 11th, crested at 30.02 feet at 230 a.m. on the 12th and was back within bankfull at 945 a.m. EST on the 12th.Storm totals included 1.84 inches in Somerville, 1.80 inches in Bound Brook, 1.56 inches in Belle Mead and 1.40 inches in North Plainfield. The heavy rain was caused by an intense low pressure system at both the surface and aloft that developed over the Southern Plains on the 9th. The primary low pressure system moved toward the Great Lakes on the morning of the 10th while a secondary low pressure system was forming near the upper air support over the Tennessee Valley. This secondary low pressure system continued to intensify and was located over North Carolina the evening of the 10th, near Philadelphia around 7 a.m. EST on the 11th and in western Connecticut early in the evening on the 11th. This secondary low pressure system helped wring the moisture in the atmosphere from the Gulf of Mexico and the Atlantic Ocean onto the region.

An area of low pressure moved east across southern Ohio on December 5th.  Precipitation began during the early mornings hours of the 5th and ended around midnight on the 6th.  The precipitation started as a mixture of freezing rain, sleet and snow at most locations.  A quick transition to all snow occurred around daybreak.  By 9 am a band of moderate snow had developed along the U.S. Route 30 corridor from Mansfield to Canton.  The greatest snowfall rates occurred during the late afternoon and early evening hours as wrap around moisture from the low moved into the region.  A total of 6 to 9 inches of snow was reported across the area with the greatest amounts along and just south of U.S. 30.  Most locations also received a light glaze of ice from the freezing rain early in the storm.  Significant traffic delays and numerous accidents resulted from this storm.

An area of low pressure moved across the region and produced some heavy rainfall late the 10th and early on the 11th. This rain fell on top of snow covered grounds and led to melting. The combination of the heavy rainfall and the melting snow produced widespread road flooding of over portions of Maryland during the  morning and afternoon hours. Rainfall amounts averaged 2 to 3 inches. Three water rescues were necessary in Frederick County. 40 to 50 cars had to be moved from a parking lot in a low lying area to prevent damage to the vehicles in Laurel. Several rivers and creeks also flooded. Baltimore County authorities closed a number of roads along the Patapsco River due to flooding. The River flooding persisted through the 13th. In Washington County, the Conococheague Creek at Fairview crested nearly 5 feet above flood stage, and the Antietam Creek at Sharpsburg crested 1.5  ft above flood stage at 5:30 am. In Montgomery County, The Potomac River at Little Falls crested almost a foot above flood stage, and The Seneca Creek at Dawsonville rose 2 feet above flood stage before cresting. In Frederick County, the Monocacy River at Frederick rose 6 ft above flood stage at 3 am and fell below flood stage at 2:30 pm, and the Potomac River at Point of Rocks crested 3.5 ft above flood stage on the 12th and fell below flood stage early on the 13th.

A strong upper level storm system dove south out of Canada, and moved into Kentucky by early Thursday, December 18th.  Heavy snow fell over portions of eastern Kentucky beginning in the afternoon on Thursday, December 18th.  Snow began accumulating in areas north of the Mountain parkway, along with ridge tops over other areas during the mid-afternoon hours, with many valley locations not switching from rain to snow until 8 or 9 pm the same day.  While many locations accumulated 4 inches of snow or more, only eight counties recorded totals of 4 inches or more within a 12 hour period.  By about 10 am on Friday, December 19th, accumulating snow ended for locations north of Interstate 64 and along the Interstate 75 corridor.  Accumulating snow ended for the rest of eastern Kentucky by around 6 am on Saturday, December 20th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Up to nine inches of snow was reported on some ridge tops in the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moderate to heavy rainfall late on the 18th and on the 19th resulted in flash flooding and small stream flooding. In addition, an isolated severe thunderstorm knocked down large tree limbs in Huddleston.Runoff from heavy rainfall resulted in numerous creeks and streams out of their banks, some of which flooded roads in Grayson, Roanoke, Bath, Alleghany, Tazewell, Wythe, Carroll, and Bland Counties and in and near Sugar Grove. In Bland County, sections of some roads were washed away by the flood waters. In Pembroke, Doe Creek flooded and damaged a barber shop. Near Lexington route 11 was closed because flood waters pushed debris into the road. In Tazewell county, businesses were damaged as creeks overflowed their banks, especially in Bluefield. In Rockbridge County, Kerrs Creek flooded all along it's reach. In the town of Kerrs Creek it reached its highest level since 1985. Some houses had minor damage.  15 people were trapped on Big Springs Rd between Kerrs Creek and Lexington. There was damage to driveways and fences.  South river had significant flash flooding that caused minor damage to homes, and necessitated a water rescue.In Grayson County, Beaver Creek washed out a culvert (72" pipe), and damaged Rt 625.  There was significant flash flooding in the Fairview area along Chestnut Creek. A woman in her vehicle in the Daleheart area was washed into Meadow Creek and had to be rescued.

Another potent winter storm hit much of Utah, with the northern part of the state the hardest hit. Weather was believed to be the main factor in 2 traffic fatalities. Several hundred minor accidents and fender benders occurred up and down the Wasatch Front, with no major injuries reported. Strong south winds ahead of the cold front caused blowing and drifting snow, forcing Hill Air Force Base and Weber State University to close for awhile. The winds and snow also closed Interstate 15 north of Ogden for several hours due to multiple accidents. Farmington Canyon reported a 3-day snowfall of 40 inches, with most Northern Mountain locations in the 20-30 inch range. The Wasatch Front valleys and benches along with the mountain valleys were generally in the 6-12 inch range, but East Layton came in with 19 inches of fresh snow.

Snowfall of 2 to 5 inches was accompanied by blowing and drifting snow as winds increased. Travel was hampered and some schools were closed or delayed.
Snowfall of 2 to 5 inches was accompanied by blowing and drifting snow as winds increased. Travel was hampered and some schools were closed or delayed.

A non-thunderstorm high wind event from late on the 12th to the early morning hours on the14th knocked down trees and power lines in portions of Franklin County and knocked down trees across Patrick, Carroll, Grayson, Bedford, Botetourt, Craig, Smyth, Roanoke, Montgomery, Bland, Tazewell, and Amherst Counties, as well as in Lexington, Rural Retreat, Laurel Fork, Willis, and 2 miles east of Covington.In Patrick County, trees were toppled onto power lines. In Grayson County, the roof was blown off of a building. In Roanoke County, winds downed a large tree limb which damaged a vehicle. In Floyd County, wind blew out a window at a business.A wind gust of 60 mph was measured at Hot Springs Airport in Bath County.
